MART HARRIS . Hannah Cain has been in my service four years and a half—about the 10th of August I paid her twenty sovereigns—she put it into a purse in her box—I afterwards saw the box was broken open. Cross-examined. Q. You paid her this for wages? A. No; it was money borrowed of her, and paid her—it was her wages, certainly—this is a lodging-house—there were two gentlemen.

THOMAS SOPER . I am a police-sergeant About twelve months ago Mrs. Cain applied to our station, and said that a man had robbed her of twenty sovereigns and a purse, and he was to be found at a public-house in Pimlico—I went, but could not find him—I never saw him till he was taken by the City constable.

JOSEPH TOD HUNTER (City police-constable 97.) I received inr
fomation, and went to No. 2, Philpot-lane, where I found the prisoner on the threshold of the door—Mrs. Cain asked him if his name was not Big
more—he said, "No"—"Well then," said the man who was with me,"it is Smith"—I found nothing on him but keys.
Cross-examined. Q. It was not Mrs. Cain that is here, that was with you? A. No; Soper was not with me.
JURY to HANNAH CAIN. Q. How soon after the robbery did you give information? A. Very soon after—I think about the same time.

COURT. Q. Did you give notice to the police? A. I did—I lost my purse about the middle of the week—I went to the police as soon as I had an opportunity to go out—it was in the course of that week, to the best of ray knowledge—I did not know he was married when I gave information.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined One Year.

2398.
HENRY STEPHENS was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of October, 2 pairs of shoes, value 2s. 8d., the goods of
Henry Wood.

HENRY WOOD . I am a shoemaker, and live in Broad-street, St. Giles. A little after five o'clock, on the 23rd of October, my boy saw the prisoner take the shoes down—I went out, and took him with them, two doors from my shop—he was not running—he said he would pay me for them—I did not know him before.

CHARLES BELLIAR . I am in the service of Mr. Wood. I saw the pri
soner take a pair of shoes off the nail, and I ran after him.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: First Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
2399.
RICHARD KIRBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of April, 2 pairs of breeches, value 2l., 3 pairs of trowsers, value 3l.; 3 waist
coats, value 2l.; 2 coats, value 2l.; 3 pairs of gaiters, value 18s.; 8 hand
kerchiefs, value 1l. 6s.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 2s.; the goods of
Henry Hilton, in the dwelling-house of
Henry Davidson.

HENRY HILTON . I live in the house of Mr. Henry Davidson, in Bruton-street, Berkeley-square, in the parish of St. George, Hanover-square. The prisoner came on trial to Mr. Davidson as groom, a few days before the 24th of April—I was the head groom until about ten days ago—all the property stated in the indictment is mine, and was taken out of the room over the stable—the prisoner slept there two or three nights—I went out and returned in half an hour—I missed the things at half-past six o'clock in the evening—the prisoner said he was going to his father, who had a job for him, and if he did not get the job, he should return again—he did not return—this was after the things were missed—I went to his father next morning and made inquiry, and then gave information to the police—the coat he had on when he was apprehended is mine—I never permitted him to take my property at all.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure the coat shown to you was the coat you had in April? A. To the best of my judgment—I never saw the prisoner after the 28th of April—I saw him go out of the room about ten minutes before six o'clock—I had seen my clothes in the room ten minutes before—to the best of my belief the coat is mine—I know it by a mark—I asked the tailor if he knew it—I always supposed it to be mine—it is worth 6s.—I lost 30l. worth of property altogether—I lost two coats—this was a blue coat—it is now a kind of mixture—it has been dipped since.
JOSEPH LEYBOURN . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on the 10th of October, in Little Chesterton-street, Grosvenor-place, in a skittle-ground—he had this coat on his back.
WILLIAM HART . I am a tailor. I mended this coat for the prosecutor, and turned it—I am certain it is his coat.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 23rd of April I engaged to go on trial—I remained there till the 28th—on the night of the robbery the prosecutor was ordered out with his master's cab, he promised me I should have the situation, but he kept on seeing different people, to see if he could get any body else, and I said to him,"As you seem to do business in this way, I shall not stop longer," and said I did not know whether I should return—I went away before he went out of the place.

HENRY HILTON
re-examined. He had not given me notice that he
would not stay—he was to come again and ride out the horses, till Mr. Davidson had made up his mind about him.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year; Two Months Solitary.

2400.
MARY LAST was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Septem
ber, at
St. Marylebone, 1 watch, value 7l., and 3 rings, value 7l., the goods of
Urania Matilda White, in her dwelling-house.

URANIA MATILDA WHITE . I live at No. 25, Wyndham-street, in the parish of St. Marylebone, and am single. I have gone by the name of Sharp for some years, but my real name is White—I have known the pri
soner better than twelve months—about a fortnight before the 12th of October, I was unwell, and the prisoner came to me, and said her sister and her had quarrelled—I employed her to attend me in my illness—she came backwards and forwards—I kept my purse and jewellery in a drawer—I occasionally sent her to that drawer—she was the only person I ever sent to it—the articles in question were safe in that drawer when the prisoner came to me—she left on Friday the 30th, having been with me nearly a fortnight, and I missed the articles on the Monday—I never authorised her to pawn them—I never had occasion to do it—I have bad occasion to pawn, I am sorry to say, but not while she was with me.

Cross-examined by MR. JERNINGHAM. Q. What sort of a house is it you live in—are you the proprietor of it? A. I am—I do not keep it open unusually late at night—I have gone by the name of Sharp for seven or ten years—I know the prisoner's sister—I do not know what she is—I have lived in the house for nearly two years—the prisoner's sister did not lire in my house twelvemonths ago with an old gentleman—I did not see any old gentleman—the prisoner herself came and took lodgings at my house—I will swear the prisoner's sister was not seduced by an old gen
tleman at my house twelve months ago—the prisoner has been in the habit, for the last fortnight, of going backwards and forwards from her own house to mine—she slept at my house.

Q. Has she not been in the habit of sitting up till a very late hour at night, expecting your return from places of amusement? A. When have gone—I may have gone once or twice a week—I do not think I have gone three times—I was very ill while the prisoner was with me—I once came home with a gentleman, and only once, while the prisoner was there—I placed implicit confidence in her—this is my watch—(looking at it)—it has my crest on it—it is worth 10l. or 12l.—and the ring attached to it is worth at least,5l.

JOHN BUTTON . I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this watch on the 30th of September, for 5l. 10s.—it is worth about 7l.—I have one ring which was pawned with my young man—it is worth 3l. or 4l.—I knew the prisoner before—she was in the habit of pawning for her sister—I have not a doubt of her pawning the watch.
RICHARD BRADSHAW . I took the prisoner into custody. She denied all knowledge of the watch or ring.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2401.
JOHN FARLEY and
MATILDA FARLEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October, 1 tea-pot, value 10l.; 1 cream-ewer, value 5l.; 21 spoons, value 13l.; 4 forks, value 4l.; 4 ladles, value 3l.; 1 waiter, value 3l.; 3 snuff-boxes, value 2l. 10s.; 5 sheets, value 2l.; 3 table-cloths, value 1l. 10s.; 4 pillow-cases, value 4s.; and 2 towels value 2s.; of
Edward Longdon M'Murdo, their master, in his dwelling-house.

EDWARD LONGDON M'MURDO . I am a wholesale druggist, and live in Finsbury-circus. The prisoners were both in my service, and I believe are husband and wife—about a quarter-past eleven o'clock on the night of the 1st of October, I went out—a friend had dined with me, and I accompa
nied him part of his way home—I took with me a patent latch key—I returned about twelve o'clock, and let myself in—I made the door fast in
side, as I always do—it was bolted and chained, and could not be opened from the outside by a skeleton key—I retired to bed—I had a particular wooden snuff-box, which I took out with me that night, and on returning home I put it on the mantel-shelf in my dining room, with two other silver snuff-boxes—I cannot be certain whether I saw the other two when I put it down—they are usually there, and I missed nothing—the male prisoner had the charge of my plate, and the key of my plate chest—next morning, about eight o'clock, I awoke, and the male prisoner came into my room, and said, "The plate is all gone, and the snuff-boxes are all gone"—I went down stairs, and saw the female prisoner, who appeared very agitated, and crying—she said she had picked up a telescope on the stair-case—I went down stairs to the butler's pantry, with the two prisoners, and the male pri
soner said the plate drawer had been found open, and the plate was gone—some of the plate had been in use at tea time, the night before—I sent the man for a constable—one came, and two other officers were called in—a search was made, but nothing was discovered—the plate chest was kept in the attic—I went up, and examined it with an inventory, and missed the plate stated, and also the wooden snuff-box, which I had put on the mantel-shelf—I something was afterwards said by the female prisoner—Reynolds, another servant, was present at the time, and I rather think the male prisoner was sufficiently near to overhear her, but I cannot answer to that.

LYDIA REYNOLDS . I am servant to Mr. M'Murdo. On the morning the robbery was discovered I saw the female prisoner, when she and my master were together—I think the male prisoner was present at the time, I but I am not certain.

MR. M'MURDO (continued.)The female prisoner said, "You may de
pend on it, the whole mischief has arisen from your latch key"—and she said the robbery must have been during my absence—I cannot say whether she knew the wooden snuff-box was gone at that time—I have not re
covered any of my plate.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are there any balconies outside your house? A. Yes; the balconies of the houses are near enough to each other for a person to get from one to the other—the prisoners have been in my service two years—the male prisoner went for the policeman at my desire.

COURT. Q. With the exception of the wooden snuff-box, is there any thing you could have said was not taken while you were out? A. No; I have a perfect recollection of putting the snuff-box on the shelf—I had been out about half an hour—the plate-drawer was in the butler's pantry below—nobody slept there—the servants slept in the attics—I lost a great many articles which ought to have been in the plate-chest—there wasa cream ewer, a great many spoons, and a silver waiter; but the prisoner tells me he had them down for cleaning.

HINEY CORSE . I am a policeman. I was called into the prosecutor's house on the morning of the 11th of October—I examined the premises with a view to ascertain whether any violence had been done by persons breaking in—I believe the robbery could not have been done by persons outside—there was no appearance of the house being broken.

LYDIA REYNOLDS re-examined. I was one of Mr. M'Murdo's servants. On coming down stairs, on the morning of the 11th, I went into the drawings-room, and found the windows all safely fastened inside—Mrs. Farley brought me a telescope—I shut the drawing-room door after me when I went out—the blinds were drawn down—there was no shutter—the catch of the window was not fast, and had not been for some time—the windows were shut as they had been for some time—a person could open them from the outside—all the servants slept up stairs—persons could come in at the window from the balcony—the drawing-room door was not locked when I went in.
NOT GUILTY .

2402.
JOHN FARLEY and
MATILDA FARLEY were again indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December, 11 spoons, value 7l.; and 1 coat, value 1l. 10s.; the goods of
Edward Longdon M'Murdo, their master

WILLIAM CLARK . I am shopman to Mr. Grant, a pawnbroker, in London-wall. On the 7th of December, 1836, the female prisoner pawned a tea-spoon, for 3s.—I am quite certain of her person—she afterwards pawned other things—I remember her coming to me on Wednesday, the 11th of October—she said that the house had been broken open, or a robbery had been committed, that the whole of the plate was gone, and she said, "If there is any inquiry made, you know nothing of it"—she was referring to the plate now produced—she said a robbery was committed and should the plate now produced be inquired for I was to know nothing of it—I said I could do no such thing—she said, "If you know nothing of it the plate would become your own"—I told her she had better redeem it, for if in
quiries were made I could do no otherwise than take the usual course—I went the next morning to the Mansion-house, and gave information—I have seen the female prisoner many times during the last two years—I have not the least doubt of her pawning the tea-spoon—she has taken things out of pawn which she has pledged—she always represented them to be her own—the spoon has the prosecutor's initials on it, and a crest—she gave me the name of Harley—I asked her where she lived, and she said in Broad-street—I believed her—this duplicate says Bell-alley, but she has been a customer of ours for two years, and the latter part of the time we have not asked her residence.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time of day did she come to you? A. About ten o'clock in the morning—there was no one present besides myself—she asked to see me in private—my master is not here—there are three persons in the house besides me—I am quite sure this took place on the Wednesday morning—the spoon remained in pawn from December, 1836, till October, 1837.
EDWARD LONODON M'MURDO . The prisoners were in my employ for two years—this is my tea-spoon—it has the initials of my late brother—he female prisoner was my cook.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know whether they had been out of a situation sometime before they came to you? A. I understood so—they have a daughter, I believe.
(The female prisoner received a good character.)

MATILDA FARLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Twelve Months.

JOHN FARLEY—
NOT GUILTY .

2403.
BRYAN HENDREY and
THOMAS SULLIVAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September, 1 iron chest, value is, 4s. 6d.; and 5 account-books, value 5s.; the goods of
Mary Bray.

MARY BRAY . I am single, and live in King-street, Holborn, in the house of Mr. Guthrie. Between twelve and one o'clock on the 29th of September I was in bed—there was a knock and ringing at the door and I saw two men—I spoke to the policeman, who came into the house—I went to the street door and let the men in—I afterwards went into the street, and saw an iron chest, containing some books, belonging to me—they had been taken from the front cellar of the house—there was a receipt of the Bank of England for 400l. in it—Sullivan came next morning, at half-past six o'clock, and I let him in to work.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Then he was there after you missed the chest? A. Yes.

WILLIAM GARLAND EDWARDS . I live with my father, in King-street, Holborn. On Friday evening, the 29th of September, between five and six o'clock, I was going to No. 15, King-street, and saw the two prisoners carrying an iron box—I knew it belonged to the prosecutrix—I have seen it in the cellar.

CHARLES JONES . I lodge in Eagle-street, Holborn. On Friday even
ing, the 29th of September, I was standing at the corner of Leigh-street, and saw the two prisoners go by with the chest—I afterwards saw the chest about half-past eight o'clock the same evening, at Deubarn's house, in Eagle-street—Denham was behind the counter—I opened it, and found some account books and other papers in it—I went to Miss Bray, and knocked at the door, but could not make her hear—I at last gave her no
tice of this.

WILLIAM DENHAM . I keep a marine-store shop in Eagle-street, Red Lion-square—between five and six o'clock, on the 29th of September, the chest was brought to my shop by the prisoners—they said it was their own—that their master had given them leave to sell rubbish, and one thing or another about the empty house, before they began to repair it, and that Mr. Guthrie was their master—I gave them 2s. 9d. for it—I bought it as old iron, at 2s. 4d. per cwt.
GEORGE COLLIER (police-constable E 38.) I assisted in taking the chest to Miss Bray's, and took Denham into custody.

JOHN LEE . I am a policeman. I took Sullivan into custody at Den
ham's.

ALEXANDER GUTHRIE . The house Miss Bray lives in is mine. Hen
drey had been employed there as a labourer—I saw Sullivan there on Friday—I saw the chest in the cellar on Thursday—I called Sullivan into the cellar on Friday, and gave him directions respecting some stones—I said nothing about the chest—I gave him no authority to take it away, but I spoke to the other prisoner, about some loose iron which was in the attic, that he might take it and sell it, to get him some beer—I said nothing about the chest, but that he might take away what was of no use—the chest was not in a part of the premises where I had control—I told Hend
rey, up in the attic, that he might take away any old iron he found about the house, and blacking bottles in the shop, and clear away the rubbish—I saw the chest the day before—it appeared to me as if it had been lying there a long time, and was decayed—I mentioned it to Miss Bray, and she said she kept her books there—the prisoners did not know of that con
versation—it had the appearance of going to decay, and was rusty, and in a very bad state.
NOT GUILTY ,

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2404.
JOHN BONNELL,
WILLIAM HENRY DAVIS , and
MARY DAVIS , were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

JOHN VICKERS HARRISON . I carry on the business of a glue-maker in Grange-road, Bermondsey, in partnership with Mr. Raymont. On the 28th of October, Bonnell came to my house and gave an order for 12cwt. of glue, to be sent to No. 21, New Church-street, Lisson-grove—I did not know him before—he said he should pay 10l. in cash and the remainder within the month—he referred me to Mr. Good, of Banner-street, St. Luke's—my partner Mr. Raymont went to make inquiry, and in consequence of that the goods were supplied—he said he should want more glue—the value of the 12cwt. was I believe 36l. 2s.—on the following day a person of the name of Clark came to the factory, he brought 10l. from Bonnell, and said he was his traveller—he said he travelled for other people, as one commission alone would not pay him in London—the goods were sent in pursuance of the order—on the 12th of November, Clark came to the factory again and produced a letter—he never left it at all—it was addressed to Clark from Bonnell—I did not read the whole of it—Clark pointed out what referred to the glue—I read what he pointed out—as far as I recollect, the contents were, that Bonnell had sold 10cwt. more glue in the country, and that he wished to have the dark glue—he said it would suit the country market best—Clark I asked me to have it ready for him that afternoon, and said he would come for it himself at the time—I said it should be ready—he went away and came about an hour before the time mentioned, and brought Isaac Anns, and a horse and cart, on which was the name of Sarah Martin, Wheat Sheaf-yard, Farringdon-street—the glue was packed in bag and delivered to him—he and Anns went away with it—there was 10cwt.—on the 9th of November Clark came again and produced this letter (No. 1,)—(Seethe letter No. 1, page 1000)—and told me that the glue was to be sent to Lisson-grove immediately—I did not refuse the order that time—after he left I turned to Bonnell's account, and in conse
quence of the state of that account I determined not to execute the whole I of the order—we sent 5cwt. to Lisson-grove, with a view of getting the 20l.—after that we received a caution from a gentleman named Sewell—in consequence of which I went to the house of the defendant Davis, in Brick-lane, the next day, after I had sent the 5cwt of glue—I believe it was sent the same day the order was given—this is the entry in our day-book—I copied it from it—I have no doubt I entered it myself—when I go to Davis's I saw the very 5cwt. of glue that I had sent to Bonnell by Clark's direction—(I took no further steps until the credit I usually gave, had expired—the amount then due was I believe 80l. 9s. 6d.—I never got that paid from Bonnell—I never could find him)—I waited a considerable, tune in Davis's shop—he was engaged with a person—it was a chandler's shop—I asked Davis if he was a buyer of glue—he said he was not—he said he had bought some glue, or I made the observation that he had some glue there—he said he had bought it—I said, "Yes, you have bought it either from Clark or Bonnell"—he said he had bought it from neither—I do not know any thing further that I said—something further passed.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not present your card to Davis, on going into his shop? A. It is very likely I did—that is the way I generally do introduce myself—I cannot say whether I did so or not—the glue was lying openly in the shop—it was one of the first things that presented itself—I presented him with a sample of glue while I was there and very likely it was before I began the conversation about glue—I asked Davis whether he was a purchaser of that article—his answer might be, "I am not now, as I have a stock on hand"—it was about eleven o'clock in the forenoon—on looking at the glue, I said, "This glue was bought of me"—I do not recollect that Davis said, "I did not buy it of you"—I do not remember saying,"I know who you bought it of, you bought it of Bonnell, "I said something to that effect—Davis did not then say,"I did so "—I did not add, "I do not blame you for buying it, but I shall never be paid by Bonnell "—I will swear that positively—I believe I did say, "I shall never get paid for it"—I did not mention Bonnell's name—I will not swear whether I did or not—Davis did not ask me how I came to trust Bonnell—I have no recollection of saying I had a reference to a person named Good, in Banner-street—I will not swear I did not—I believe I left the shop immediately—I do not recollect telling him I was going to make further inquiries respecting Bonnell—I will not swear I did not—it is very likely I told him I had been doing business with other people, by whom I had lost money, as I believed he had had all the glue—I do not recollect his saying "have nothing at all to do with that"—I will not swear he did not—I do not recollect that he asked me how I came to learn that any part of my glue was in his shop—I believe I said it was watched to his shop.

Q. Did you not give this reason for calling at his shop, that a person at Paddington had sent circular letters to the glue manufacturers in Bermond
sey, respecting Bonnell, cautioning them? A. I do not think I did—I cannot swear I did not—I was aware that such letters had been sent, but I have no recollection of having such a conversation—I was with him but a very short time—I had one of the letters at that time—I had not then been to Paddington, to the person by whom they were written, and did not tell Davis so—I will not swear it, but I believe I had not—it was within a day or two that I went there—I told him it was in consequence of the information that the writer's servant had watched the glue to his shop, that I called on him to ask for an explanation—I heard from the writer that he had sent his servant, who watched it—I do not know that I said the writer's servant, but Sewell's servant—Sewell had not told me that, but he had written—I cannot recollect whether I saw Sewell before I saw Davis—I believe I went to Paddington on that day, but that was after I had been to Davis—I will not swear that I did not go before—I never went before or since that time to Davis's shop, and held any communication with him—I left the glue behind—I did not write down the address of the person who gave Bonnell a character before I left the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How many parcels of glue are the subject of this proceeding altogether? A. Three—the first amounted to 36l. 2s.—that was sent by my own conveyance to Bonnell's house, with a bill of parcels—I received the 10l. the day before it went—I believe the amount of the second was 29l. 5s.—I delivered that to Clark, who brought a horse and cart—that was not in consequence of my stating the my own horse was ill—it was not ill—I am not aware of any thing of the kind—I will not undertake to swear it, but I have no reason to believe it

—not of that parcel of glue—it was of the last parcel—I am not aware the horse was ill at all—I told the carman as an excuse for not delivering the 20cwt., to say that the horse was ill, hut nothing had been said about the horse being ill before the third parcel—we did not get the 20l. that was to be paid—the 5 cwt. was delivered in New Church-street—I have issued a writ against Bonnell for the amount due—after I had been to Davis I caused Clark to be taken into custody—I charged him with having obtain
ed these goods by forged orders, but not in the name of Bonnell—he was tried and acquitted.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. The amount of the whole was 80l. 9s. 6d.? A. Yes; I have received nothing but the 10l. Clark brought me—I did not tell Davis I did not blame him for buying the glue of Bonnell, nor that I believed he had all the glue—I merely myself believed that.

JAMES VINCENT . I have known Mr. and Mrs. Davis for ten years—I was never regularly in his employ—I have been in the habit of selling goods for him and portering, for the last five years—I had no connexion or participation with him—if I sold any thing I had a commission, but no profit—I have known Mr. Bonnell two years, or two years and a half, by his coming to Davis—I never knew him before—I believe the first time that he came he sold some shirt-buttons in grosses—I believe Bonnell did not keep a shop, he was travelling—the buttons ran from 7s. to a guinea—I have seen him there almost every week, with haberdashery, cheese
mongery, paper, grocery, and bottled ale—various persons bought tthese things—Mills was Mr. Davis's carman upon pretty nearly all occasions—I remember Bonnell going with ale to Ascott Heath races—I believe Davis took it—Bonnell went to live at Paddington, I understand—he had taken a shop to open in the general line in Church-street, Paddington, but I never was there—I remember about the 2nd or 3rd of November last year, Clark coming there—I never knew him till I saw him with Mr. Bon
nell, about six months before—he kept a public-house in St. John-street—after that he let that house to Mr. Bonnell, and I believe the ale they took to Ascot Heath came from that house—I saw Bonnell come to Davis with a van full of ale—Clark and Bonnell were always partners together in busi
ness, as I have seen them divide the money after they went oat—I remember some glue coming to Davis—I cannot say the day, but it was just at dusk—I believe it was half a ton—it was not brought by Mills—I do not know the man who brought it—I saw the cart—I did not go out, but when Clark got out of the cart, he came in, and Mrs. Davis said, "Well, Clark, you have got it, then?"—he said, "Yes, I have; I am just the boy to fetch, if I go after it, I am sure to get it"—Mrs. Davis said, "What carman have you got?"—he said, "I have got a new carman"—she said, "I wish you had had our old carman, because we can put some dependence in him, I don't like new carmen, we had better had the old one, as he would never split"—Mr. Davis was behind the counter at this time—he made some observation himself—Clark said, there was no matter about that—Mrs. Davis said, "You have not brought it directly from the glue man, have you?"—he said, "Yes; what odds is it?"—she said, "We have got into some trouble before, and you had better have gone round with it"—Clark said, "O, never mind; I took care there was nobody touted us"—Mr. Davis said, "It is no odds, Clark, whatever; what you bring here, I will buy of you, bring what you like, I don't care where you get it"—the carman then put the goods down by the side of the counter—Davis said, "Clark, I believe I have got no money to-night"—he said, "Never mind;

Bonnell and I will be here in the morning, that will do"—Clark and Bon
nell came the next morning, I believe, about ten o'clock—some mention was made about the glue, and Davis said he thought they had given too much for it—some more conversation took place—Davis proceeded to pay—I saw some sovereigns—I believe he said he had given 48s. a cwt.—he paid the money—Bonnell, I, and Clark, went to the Coach and Horses, and several more persons, who were in the habit of selling goods to Davis—there was something had to drink, and Clark said, "I suppose you have got the money?"—Bonnell said, "Yes;" and took it out of his pocket, and laid it on the counter, and they proceeded to divide it—I came out—I had a glass of gin—in answer to the observation about too much, Bonnell said, "I think there is a sacrifice enough as it is"—Davis said, "You talk as though you were going to pay for it; it is all profit to you"—while they were in the house, there was some conversation respecting the glue—I said it was enough to give any person the yellow jaundice, seeing so much gold—Mr. Bonnell said, "We have got 200 more of them at home"—I did not see any receipt given—I think, nine or ten days after, in the morn
ing, a cart came with some glue, but a smaller quantity—I understood it was a quarter of a ton—there was half a ton the time before—it was unloaded and brought to Davis's shop—the cart did not come to the shop—it stopped two doors off—a man brought it up, and put it down by the side of the counter—it was in the same sort of bag that the half ton was in—I saw Bon
nell and Clark half an hour afterwards, with Davis—there was conversation about the glue, and Davis said he would not give such a price as he did be
fore—he proceeded to pay him for the glue, and I think some other things which he had before—I believe it was carpet-bags, but I cannot say—I do not know how long before they had been brought—I did not see them—Mr. Davis said, "I may as well pay you"—I believe it was 20l.—I saw a £10 note and some sovereigns—Davis took that out of his cash-box—he went over to the public-house again—Bonnell and Clark and I went with five or six more dealers that I knew—we then all went to the public-house—it was said there was more glue coming, and then it would be over, as all the fat would be in the fire—Clark said, "We have done pretty tidy with him, but he can afford to lose it, as he is worth from five to ten thousand pounds"—after Clark was given in charge I went to Union Hall, and saw him—I was sent by Mr. Davis—he was remanded, and a summons issued against Mr. Davis for his apprehension—I came back and told him of it—Clark said he was astonished that Bonnell did not come forward, whatever he had done, he had acted fairly and honestly, and he expected he would come forward and pay his share of the expenses—Mr. Davis did not appear to the summons—I went and brought him word that there was another summons—he said he would not appear to any sum
mons—I went again, and the Magistrate issued a warrant against him—I went and told him—he put on his hat, and said, "I will not be at home all night"—he went afterwards and met the officer, and surrendered—he was discharged, and Clark held to bail—I have heard Bonnell and Clark say that they paid some money—Clark told me that he took 10l. to Mr. Harrison—I was here when Clark was tried—he was acquitted—I remember Bonnell and Clark bringing some stationery to Davis before this transaction of the glue—there was writing-paper, account-books, copy-books, ledgers, day-books, wax and wafers—Bonnell was living at that time in Pad
dington, I understand—the things were brought sometimes in a cab—some
times in a cart, and sometimes under their arm—Clark and Bonnell used to

come together, and sometimes Clark by himself—I have teen the invoice of them—the original invoice from the stationer with the head of it turned down—Mr. Davis said, "I will not buy any goods without the original invoice, I have heard him say that on all occasions—I know a Mr. Pun
chard, of Bread-street-hill—he is a marine-store dealer—there was a lot of goods brought to Mr. Davis, and he had made an offer for them—they would not take that—Mr. Punchard came and bought them, and Mr. Davis said, "I won't have them opened in my shop, as I cannot buy them; take them over to the public-house," and I assisted in doing to—I went to the George in Smithfield, and there I saw Bonnell and Clark with Russia wallets—there were two dozen and six reams of brief paper at the same time—he asked if I could sell it—I said yes, I knew a gentle
man—I took a sheet as a specimen, to Mr. Wilson, and he offered me 16s. a ream for it—the first lot of stationery I saw, was paper—Davis bought the first lot, it consisted of ledgers and books of every description—when Davis was not in the way, I never saw any one else purchase—I never saw Mrs. Davis buy any stationery—she may have bad such a thing as a ream of paper, but I do not know—these wallets were sold to Mr. Wilson, of Cheapside, with six reams of brief-paper—I went and told Clark—he bought the brief-paper at 16s., but he did not buy the wallets at that time—he offered 35s. for them—Clark would not take it then—he brought them back to Bonnell, who said, "Why did you not take it? we don't know what to do with them—I would have taken it"—Clark said, "You do as you like with your part, I would sooner give them away"—when I was going, Clark said, "Don't you go near Budge-row"—I did not know then that Mr. Imray lived there—I went to the George, and they divided the books—I took part to Mr. Wilson—Miss Gray was in the bar—I understand her brother keeps the house—she had nothing to do with the stationery, except she put away the paper for them—the same week as I took away the books Clark said Punchard had given 2l. more than Davis offered, and he thought he had done very well—after this Clark had three reams of paper which I told to Mr. Harrison—Clark and Bonnell said, never mind sacrificing 1s. 3d., but they did not like to sacrifice more—it was brought in a cab to the George, but I carried what I sold on my shoulder—I sold to Mr. Harrison in St. John-street three reams of foolscap that I had from Clark—I brought the money out and gave it to Clark, who was waiting outside—I afterwards went to the George in Smithfield—Mr. Bonnell was there, and they divided the money—I believe they gave me 1s.—the night that I went to tell Davis there was a warrant again it him he went away, and Mrs. Davis sent for Spooner, who bought the half ton of glue, and she said, "I gave you a receipt at 50s. the hundred weight, if you will destroy that receipt I will give you another bearing a profit, for my husband has got into trouble "—he said, "Mr. Harrison, the glue man, has been to me, I have shown him this re
ceipt, and I should not like to part with it"—he put it into her hand and had some little difficulty in getting it back again—he said if he was put into a witness box he would not take a false oath for anybody; he had bought it fair and square at her house, and would not say any thing that was wrong—Davis's shop is in Brick-lane Old-street, near the corner of Mit
chell-street—it is a general shop, for there is tea and sugar, and bread and bacon, and every thing sold in a chandler's shop—there is no appearance of dealing in stationery and glue—there might be a small quantity of glue left, but it is not an oil-shop.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you never see any glue at Davis's shop? A. Yes; but never in a small quantity—I saw the 5 cwt. standing three or four days in front of the counter—the bags were sewed up close, so that they could not see what was in them—they are a coarse bag made I believe on purpose—the first bags I saw brought was on the 2nd or 3rd of November in the evening—I believe the gas was lighted—I was sitting in the yard during Clark's trial—I was not examined.
COURT. Q. Did the prosecutors know that you were waiting? A. They saw me, but did not know me.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Do you know the prosecutor? A. I know Mr. Harrison by sight—I communicated to him that I could give him some information when the trial commenced—I was here the day the bill was found, and three days before the trial was on—I am quite sure it was before Clark was put to the bar to be tried that I spoke to Mr. Harrison—I gave him my address, 15, Somers-street, Back-hill, and be sent for me—I live there now—I will swear the gas was lighted when the man brought the glue out of the cart on the 2nd of November—there were about six or seven different persons in the shop, men and women—Mr. Davis is in a very large way as a chandler—you seldom or ever go into the shop but there is somebody in it—Mr. and Mrs. Davis were serving in the shop—nobody else ever served in the shop that I saw—I am generally there morning or evening—sometimes they have got things to sell, or want work done, and I did it—the glue was brought in as quick as the man could put down the tail-board and bring it in—the customers were in the shop all the time—Clark was in the shop in front of the counter when the glue, was put down—Mr. and Mrs. Davis were both talking to him—there are two counters—I was between the two—this occupied about five mi
nutes—the carman came to the door—Clark paid him and he went away—Mrs. Davis might go round two or three times serving the customers—there was no whispering—it could be heard by all the customers—the conversation about the yellow jaundice was the next morning at the public-house—I forget the landlord's name—he was there—I have been at work at Mr. Martin's, the pork-butcher at Shore
ditch for nine months, till within the last six weeks, when an alteration took place—the last, six weeks the solicitor wished me to go and see if I could find Bonnell and Clark, and told me he would satisfy me—I have some little coming in extra, besides what the solicitor supplied me with, of my own money—I have never less than 18s. every Saturday night—I have a family of two boys who have 18s. a week, and a daughter—I have been supplied with money by the solicitor; when I have gone into the country I did not go at my own expense—I cannot say how much I have had—perhaps 3l. or 4l. during the last six weeks—I have had as much as 15l.—I have been to Southend and Margate, and other places—I have not made as much as 50l.—I have gone with an officer, and he has had the money and paid all my expenses; but that I do not consider I had—at the time I saw them in the shop, I lived by selling goods to different persons—I had lived five or six years in that way—I never kept a shop for five years—I do portering work or beat carpets—I have bought goods and sold them on my own credit, at times—on the 2nd of November I was living in Somers-street, Back-hill, and have for two years—before that 1 lived in Spring-street, Spafields, about 150 yards from where I live now, for more than two years, I think, and before that in Church-row, St. Luke's—I might be there twelve months, and before that in Hoxton, for a year or so—I

had a house No. 46 Hoxton Old-town, and let it out to the man who lives in it now—before that I lived in Hackney, and kept a stationer's shop, and moved from there to Hoxton, and kept a shop in the same line—stationery and different things—about eight or nine years ago, while I was in Hoxton, I took the benefit of the Insolvent Debtor's Act—that is about six years ago the 28th of last March—since that time I have lived as I can—I have gone by the name of James John Vincent all my life—I may sometimes have said James Vincent when I did business, but if I accepted a bill, or any thing, I wrote James John Vincent—I do not know that I contracted a debt in the name of James only—I lived at No. 140, St. John-street, in the general line, stationery and that, and let the shop to Mr. Davis, a tailor—I afterwards went to White Hart-place, Kingsland—I was there eighteen months, and let it to a man, and took 32l. for it—then I went to Mile-end-road, and staid there three or four months, till I got a shop—I then shifted to Essex-place, Mare-street, Hackney—I have been in this Court before, as a man that kept a public-house in Jewin-street, Aldgate, asked me if I could sell him a loaf of sugar—I was never charged with stealing it—I went with two men to Mr. Crewsden, to show them where to sell it, and the officer took them—we were taken to the watch-house, and before the Alderman—he said he should hold us all to bail; but the sessions were on, and we came here to take our trial—I was sent to Newgate—Mr. Sparrow on Ludgate-hill was aware he had sworn what was not right, and did not come forward—that was three years ago—I was never here again till now—I do not recollect appearing as a witness on any occasion except at the Court of Queen's Bench—I never attended here to give evidence—I was here at the time Clark was tried—I was asked if I would be a witness—I said "No"—I was here two Sessions on Clark's occasion—never at any other time—a man named George Coney used to come and sell goods to Mr. Davis—he was hanged—I believe it is four or five years since he was tried—I heard part of his trial—it lasted ten hours—Mrs. Davis was here—I was in the bottom of the Court—I was asked if I would give him a character—I went into the witness-box—I said I had known him some time, coming to Mr. Davis's shop to sell goods—I knew nothing else of his character—I did not speak a word in the witness-box—I never heard that the witnesses proved an alibi—I did not come for that purpose—I was not sworn—as soon as I stood up, Mr. Adolphus told me to stand down—my name was not called—I was in White Cross-street prison, and Old-street, and in the King's Bench, and in Clerkenwell, about the time that Davis was there—from the Saturday till the Monday—I was in prison for an assault, five years ago—I was only twice in Clerkenwell, once in White Cross-street, and the King's Bench, twenty-four or twenty-five years ago, and once in New
gate—I was once in the Marshalsea, about fifteen years ago—I was arrested and put in Horsemonger-lane, and moved by Habeas to the King's Bench—I kept what they call a tap-shop, and was sent to the New Prison, which is Horsemonger-lane, for selling gin in the Bench—I was never in a country gaol

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You were a mere porter employed in the way of your trade? A. I do any thing in that way whenever I can get a job—I was not aware that any thing was wrong in these purchases—I never knew where the goods came from till afterwards.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Was there any thing on the outside of these bags to enable an accidental observer to tell there was glue in them? A. You

could not, unless you took hold of it—Clark asked me to be here, and to take the information to Bonnell and Davis, that they might know how things were going on—Clark came up the first time, but did not render—Davis was at home, and the other was at a public-house, and heard of it—Davis's is a chandler's shop, where people come in for small dealings, and go out again in half a minute—little children come in—Mrs. Davis was serving from one counter to another, and if the people came in for half a minute they could not understand the conversation—they might hear from time to time, but could not tell what it was about—I was six weeks seek
ing after Bonnell and Clark—I cannot find Clark—I met Bonnell about a month ago in the Mile-end-road—the officer was with me—I said, "There goes Bonnell"—I received about 15l. in small sums, as my occasions de
manded it—I never received more than 5s. or 10s. at a time—once I received 25s.—that was at the time I went to Margate, and this extended from January to the middle of August—none of the money was given me to induce me to give evidence on this trial, but to find Bonnell and Clark—my name is James John, but sometimes I have given the name of James only; but when I accepted a bill, or any tiling, it was in both my names—I never concealed my second name with a view to do wrong to any one—I was once in the King's Bench, about twenty-five years ago—I was arrested for debt, taken to Horsemonger-lane, then removed to the King's Bench—I sold gin, and was sent back to Horsemonger-lane for one month, and came back to the King's Bench—I was arrested fifteen years ago, and paid the debt and costs, and then again I took the benefit of the Insolvent Debtors' Act—I was taken on a charge of stealing a loaf of sugar—the Alderman said he should hold us all to bail, but the Grand Jury were sitting—I went to Newgate, no bill was preferred, and I went out—I was in Clerk en well two days, for an assault, and taken for want of bail—this all amounts to one charge of larceny, and the rest debts and other transactions—I was outside this Court, Mr. Davis had been with Mr. Battle, and he pointed me out, and said, "There is Vincent," and gave me in charge for felony—I was taken that night before the Magistrate at Worship-street—Mr. Goddard, the solicitor, appeared for me—the Magistrate said I had better come up the next day, and I did, and was discharged.

WILLIAM FITCH . I am a wholesale stationer, in Budge-row, in partner
ship with John Imray. I know Bonnell—about the 6th of August he came to my counting-house, and stated that he wanted to purchase a miscellaneous lot of goods, such as I supplied; that he was occasionally travelling about the country, and could sell such goods as I supplied; and if I would furnish him with 10l. worth of articles he would pay me down half—he gave me a reference to Mr. Good and my partner called on him—he was supplied with nearly 10l. worth—about the 11th of August he came again, and paid 5l., and gave me a further order of about 12l. worth of goods—his man, Clark, came and fetched them—I understood that he had a cart wait
ing in Smithfield—Bonnell said they would be sent for as usual by the man Clark—Clark came for them and brought two or three baskets—there were day-books, memorandum books, and quills—that was the first order—the second was similar—he said the first goods did so well that he would give me a further order—that was about 12l.—I never saw him again—about the 17th Clark came and brought me this letter (No. 2)—the goods mentioned in it were rather above 2l.—Clark took them away—two days after that he came again—I do not know that he brought a letter that time—from

this time till the 29th of September Clark called for small parcels several times, and took them away—the amount of the debt up to the early part of October was about 40l., and I sent a letter or message by Clark—I received this letter in October—(No. 3)—I supplied him with two dozen wallets, one in red roan, and one dozen in Russia, and two ledgers and two day-books—on the 14th of October Clark called, and took all the goods, amounting to about 7l.—that made the whole of the account 41l. 4s. 4d.—I took off the two and a half per cent., and drew for the balance—I delivered the bill to Clark—he took it away and brought it—that was not paid—on the 26th of October Clark came again, and ordered six reams of brief paper—he said I had supplied him with two or three reams before, and the paper stood so well, that the parties wanted some more; that they were for an attorney, a friend of Mr. Bonnell's—Clark took away three reams first, and then the other three reams—on the 12th of November Clark called again, and wanted some laid foolscap for Mr. Bonnell—it was delivered to him—none of it was ever paid for—the amount now due to me is 60l. odd.
WILLIAM TAYLOR . I am carman to Messrs. Harrison and Raymont On the 9th of November I delivered 5cwt of glue at Bonnell's.

ISAAC ANNS . I am carman to Mrs. Sarah Martin, of Wheat Sheaf-yard. About the 2nd of November I was in my mistress's stable—a gentleman came to me—his name was Daniel James Clark—(I saw him here when he was to be tried)—he came and asked me if I had got a light cart—I said, "Yes"—he said, "Put the horse in, and come along with me"—we rode to Bermondsey, after ten bags of glue, to Mr. Harrison's premises—we got the glue, and went to Brick-lane, St. Luke's, to the corner of Mitchell-street, and left it there—as I threw the cloth over the horse, Clark said to me,"Draw it over the place where the name is," that he did not want any body to know but that it was his own cart, or something of that sort—I carried the goods into Davis's shop, but the shop was so full of customers that all I could do was to draw them from the cart, and put them down in the shop—Clark went with me.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What time was this? A. About three o'clock when I started from Farringdon-street—we walked slowly with the glue—we got to the shop about five or six o'clock.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was the gas lighted? A. It was.

JOHN SEWELL . I am a builder and carpenter, and live at the corner of Church-street, Edge ware-road. Bonnell's house was opposite to where I live—there was no name up—I never recollect seeing him in the shop—I have seen goods at different times brought in, and furniture, piano-fortes, and a van load of goods of various descriptions—I did not see the glue—it is a new house—I saw, the next day, or the day after, the looking —glasses being removed, and the piano-fortes; and one morning, as soon as it was light, I saw a cart loading with some glue—I did not know what it contained, but I passed by for that purpose—I told my servant, Rhodes, to watch that cart, and not to leave it till he saw where it went—I obtained from the Directory the names of the glue-makers, and sent about a dozen notes—I heard that my note went to Mr. Harrison.

SAMUEL RHODES . In November last I followed a cart that my master had called my attention to to Mr. Davis's shop, Brick-lane, St. Luke's,—it first went very slowly, but when they got to Marylebone church they went as hard as they could, till they got to Kings-cross—at a trot—I observed a man come out of a public-house, it was not Bonnell—I followed

the cart to Davis's shop—the glue was unloaded two doors before it came there—Davis said to the man with the cart, "You are just returned"—when the glue was delivered, Mr. Davis took a broom, and went to the corner of the shop, and remained there till the cart went away—Mrs. Davis was in the shop, and received it—I do not know whether it was money or apiece of paper passed between her and the carter—I was on the opposite side.

----SPOONER. I am an oilman, and live in Bath-street, St. Luke's. I know Davis, I have bought goods of him—in November last I purchased some hundreds weight of glue of him, at 50s. per cwt.—I took a receipt of him, but cannot find it—the bill contained the price per cwt. but not the receipt—some weeks after, Mr. Harrison called on me—I gave him information, and from some conversation I went to Davis's house—Mr. Davis was gone out—I saw Mrs. Davis—I communicated to her that I had seen Mr. Harrison about the glue—she seemed a little alarmed, and asked me to allow her to alter the bill—I said "No," of course—I said I paid a fair price, and bought it in a fair tradesman-like way—nothing was said about destroying it in my hearing—I think Mrs. Davis wanted to alter the receipt, but of course as Mr. Davis was not present, I did not pay much attention to that—I think Vincent was in the shop, I was in the parlour—Wall was there—I told her I should not allow my bill to be altered—if it was, I should seek my redress elsewhere—I had parted with the bill—Mrs. Davis got the bill from me—she said she wanted to alter the bill—she did not, because I would not allow it—something was said about writing a new receipt—Mrs. Davis asked Mr. Wall to make out another receipt—I said I had paid a good price for it, and a market price, and would not have it altered—I got it back—I had no difficulty about it, because I insisted upon it—I was not there half an hour the whole time—when I told them if they did not give the bill up I should take further proceedings, it was given to me immediately—the bill was taken into the shop—I was in the parlour—I jumped up and went into the shop, and said unless they gave it me I should take further proceedings—and then it was given to me, and I left.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What was the price you paid? A. 50s.—I walked into the parlour while the other people remained in the shop—Mrs. Davis had the bill about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—in the course of that time they had customers in the shop—Vincent was doing up goods in the shop—I am not aware that he joined in the conversation—I could see from the parlour into the shop—I took the bill and receipt away—I put them on my desk, but cannot find them now—I live in the neighbourhood—I think this was in November, as far as I can recollect—I purchased eight hundred weight of glue.
MR. CLARKSON to MR. HARRISON. Q. What sum does that glue cost you per cwt.? A. About 50s., to make—we charge our customers 60s.—at that time some of inferior quality we sold to Bonnell at 58s

THOMAS WILSON . I am a wholesale stationer, in Cheapside. On the 26th of October I bought of Vincent six reams of 15s. brief paper, which came to 6l. 10s., and six wallets at 3s.—I saw the receipt signed—I do not know Clark—this is the receipt.

JOHN SEWELL
re-examined. I went to Bonnell's shop to purchase a child's frock—there were a great many gentlemen's stocks and pocket-books, which had the effect of darkening the room—they had a shop and a parlour also—I went into the shop, and saw a person who represented herself as Mrs. Bonnell.

JOHN PUNCHARD . On the 29th of August I was sent for to go to Davis's, in Brick-lane—I went and saw Clark, Bonnell, and Davis there—I went there to look at a lot of books—Bonnell said they had got a lot of goods there to sell—I cannot say whether Davis heard that—the goods were in a box at the front of his counter—they were day-books, ledgers, memorandum-books, ciphering-books and copy-books—they were taken over to the public-house, by a couple of men—I think Vincent was one—I bought them—Clark was along with them—I do not know whether he helped to carry them—they were taken to my warehouse on Bread-street-hill, by Vincent, and Mrs. Punchard paid for them—I have found this note of it, 7l. 2s. 6d., beside the expenses—it was given me by Clark, who walked down with me—(see document No. 4.)
WILLIAM FITCH . I saw these goods at Punchard's—they were the goods I sold to Bonnell.

WILLIAM ROSSER . I was at the New York Coffee-house, in Sweetings
alley, and met Bonnell there promiscuously, calling for half a pint of beer—I had got a lot of goods going to Whitechapel—I think he went out before me—he asked me, as he knew I was in the stationery line, if I knew any body who. would buy some new account-books—I went and said there is no harm in looking at them—Bonnell sent a person I never saw before, of the name of Clark with me—I introduced Mr. Punchard to the gentleman Bonnell sent with the goods—we went to Davis's—Clark and Punchard went with me—I walked behind them—Bonnell was there nearly at the same time—I think the books laid by the side of the counter, in a box—I have said I saw them in Davis's cellar, but it was a mistake—I said Mr. Punchard went down stairs—I was not inside.

ROBERT REEVES (police-sergeant G 19.) On Monday, the 18th of September, I was attending these sessions, and Mr. Battle, an ale-brewer, came to me, and said in Davis's hearing, "Do you know a man named Vincent?"—I said, "No"—he said, "I want to give him in charge for felony, for obtaining some ale, and afterwards selling it 1l. a barrel less than he gave for it"—Davis then came up and said, "Do you know that party"—I said, "I cannot say I do know him"—he said, "If you should see him, take him into custody, he is one of the witnesses against me; he is one of the parties who has been riding about with your beautiful in
spector, Mr. M'Craw"—I mentioned this before the Magistrate—Vincent was taken before the Magistrate—Battle did not come forward, and Vincent was discharged.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you go to Mr. Battle? A. No—no one did—I knew where Battle lived—it was on his not ap
pearing that Vincent was discharged—this was on the 18th of September last—I never saw Vincent before, to my knowledge.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you at the office the following day? A. I cannot say—I do not remember Vincent coming again of his own accord the next day.

GODFREY GODDARD . I am the attorney for the prosecution. I have supplied Vincent with money, to go about to find the defendants—he has had 5s., 7s., and 10s.—I was present when he was taken before the Magis
trate—he was discharged the same evening—Battle did not attend—M'Craw desired Vincent to attend the next day—he did, and Battle at
tended, and Vincent was discharged.
The following are the letters read in the evidence.

(No. 1.) "To Messrs. Harrison and Co., Grange-road. 21, New Church-street, Lisson-grove. Gents.—The dark glue has not turned out so well as I expected. I had sold the whole, but was obliged to take some of it back and allow for the rest; it was not all the same sort, some of it was very black indeed. Now I want 20cwt. of the best as soon as pos
sible. I have left 20l. at home to pay you on account, and this day week I shall send you 20l. or 30l. more. Please to give my young man a sample of this. Please to be particular looking it out, and hope when I see you you will allow me a little on the last dark. I am, Gents, yours very respectfully, JOHN BONNELL."

(No. 2.) "Messrs. Imray and Fitch,—Please to let my young man have two reams of Bath post, the same as last; and likewise two reams of fools
cap, at 20s:. they are for an order for an old customer I received from them this morning; therefore, if you will get them ready as soon as you can this afternoon, I shall be obliged. Yours respectfully, J. BONNELL, Church-street, Lisson-grove.—I will call on you on Friday."

(No. 3.) "7th Oct. 1836. Messrs. Imray and Fitch. Gents.—I am just come home from a little journey, and find your account against me quite correct; but half the amount was bought in September, and that being a very short credit, (as I understand that stationery goods are four months credit goods,) 1 shall be obliged if you will draw on me for the amount of balance, 34l. 19s., with 2 1/2 off, at six weeks. I will accept it, and make it payable at my friend Mr. Grey's, George Tavern, West-street, Smithfield, where I make all my little accounts payable at, and when due it shall be regularly met. I should not have troubled you, but I find money very scarce just about this time. My young man will have a little order for books, which I hope you will charge me as low as you can. I remain, Gents., yours respectfully, J. BONNELL. 21, Church-street, Lisson-grove."
(No. 4.) "August 26. Received of Mr. Punchard the sum of 7l. 2s. 6d. for value received. DANIEL CLARK."

(Bill.) "London, October 8,1836. 41l. 4s. 4d. Six weeks after date pay to us or our order forty-one pounds four shillings and sixpence, value received. IMRAY AND FITCH.—To Mr. J. Bonnell, 21, Church-street, Lisson-grove.—Accepted, J. Bonnell, payable at the George Tavern, West-street, Smithfield, City"

BONNELL—
GUILTY .

WILLIAM HENRY DAVIS—
GUILTY .
Confined Two Years.

MARY DAVIS—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —

2405.
CHARLES LAYZELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of October, 1/2 a peck of wheat, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Gray, his master.

HENRY GRAY . I am a farmer, and live at Barking. On Tuesday, the 17th of October, I and my wife were in town, and when I went home my daughter informed me that the prisoner had taken some wheat out of the barn—that is all I know about it.
HARRIETT GRAY . A little after six o'clock on Tuesday evening I saw the prisoner hang his bag on the pales—he went in doors to take the key

of the barn in, and while he was gone I felt his bag and found some wheat in it—when he came out he took the bag off the pales—I asked what he had—he said he had not any thing but a basin—I said, "You have some
thing else"—he said he had—I said, "Let me see?"—I opened it and found the wheat—he said, "Let me take it back?"—I said, "No, you had better leave it for my father to see," and he left it—he had had the key of the barn, and there was wheat there.
JOHN GRAY . I am a constable. I took the prisoner, and have the property.

GEORGE BIGGS , I am a farmer. On Tuesday evening, about seven o'clock, I had business at Mr. Gray's, and Miss Gray stated about the wheat being stolen—I went up the road and met the prisoner with some wheat on his back in a sack—I stopped him and took it from him—he said it was what his wife had been gleaning—I gave him into custody—the wheat which he had was not owned by any one.

HENRY GRAY
re-examined. I have compared the wheat left with my daughter with what was in my barn—the prisoner said he took it, he could not tell why, he thought it must be the devil, who had very nearly got the upper hand of him the day before, but he beat him then—this was only the second day he had worked for me.

GUILTY. Aged 33.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined One Month.

2406.
CHARLES HOLL was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of October, 1 jacket, value 3s., the goods of
John Burrell; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Weeks.

2407.
ROBERT PURKISSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of October, 7 pecks of oats, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas French, his master.

ROBERT FRENCH . I drive a fish van for my brother, Thomas French. The prisoner was in his employ—my brother keeps horses at Chadwell—purchase all the corn for his horses there—I have compared some oats which Weston has with others which I keep of my brother's—I will not swear to them—they are white oats and very good—they are just like what was in the sack taken from the prisoner—we did not grow them—I did not authorise him to take any oats to London for my brother.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How long have you known him? A. Sixteen or seventeen years. The oats were taken from the stable at Chadwell in Essex.

GEORGE WESTON . I am one of the horse patrol stationed at Rom
ford. About a quarter past three o'clock in the morning of the 5th of October I saw the prisoner at Chadwell in Barking parish—he had a quantity of oats in a sack—I went across to him and asked what he had got there—he said, "Some oats"—I said, "What are you going to do with them?"—he said, "I brought them from master's stable for the van to take up"—I said, "Whose van?"—he said, "My master's, Thomas French"—I said, "Did your master give you orders to take the oats?"—he said, Yes he did"—I said, Does your master drive the van"—he said he did—I said should remain with him until I ascertained the truth—before French came he said it was not his master, but his brother who drove the van, and he had ordered him to take the oats to feed the horses—when Robert French

came I asked him if he had given him instructions to bring the corn—he was he had not—the prisoner then said it was not Robert French, but it not James Mooss—I then remained until Mooss came—he said he did said give them to him—the prisoner said he had brought them from his master's stable to take to London for his masters horses.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw him on the highroad, where the was would pass? A. Yes—French would have seen him if he had come up at the time—he came up about half an hour after—the prisoner was not waiting in the road—he had the oats on his back, going down the road—he went in the same direction as the van would come—the van was coming from Chelmsford, and he was going towards Chelmsford—he would have met the van if he had gone on—he was passing the public-house—he was just by the corner of the public-house—the van stops there, but he had nearly passed the house—he had passed the door—they change horses on the contrary side to where he was carrying the oats—the horses stop on the London side, and he was carrying them on the contrary side, away from where the horses would be—the prisoner said before Moss that Moss had authorized him to take them—he at first said French had sent him.

JAMES MOSS . I am in the employ of Thomas French, of Chelmsford—I never gave the prisoner orders to have the corn ready for the van—I change horses at Chadwell, on the London side of the house—the place the prisoner was stopped at was right by the house, not where we stop—he had no business to bring corn out of the stable—we always feed our horses with chaff and beans mixed.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you have corn at the stable? A. Yes—we send it from Romford to Chadwell on our way to London—we never feed the horses in London, except we put them up a bit, and then what we give them is at our own expense—I have told the prisoner that I paid 18d. out of my own pocket for corn to give the horses—he knew they always charge us 18d. in London—I never complained to him that there ought to be corn in London—master said if we put the horses up it must be at our own expense—we give them water and hay sometimes at White
chapel.

COURT. Q. Do you never feed them from Chadwell to London and back? A. Never, except giving them a little hay—we convey fish by land-carriage to Billingsgate from Lowestoff—we go ten miles an hour—we pay for the hay ourselves.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you mean your master makes you pay for feeding the horses? A. He said if we stop in London and feed them, we must feed them ourselves—I have never taken corn to feed them—we do not change at the public-house, but at a private stable down out of the road by the public-house—it is the next yard to it—there is a stable, and some houses between them—it is twenty yards from the public-house—we change in the road—we never stop there—I have known the prisoner from a child—I am sure he has got some bad tutors.

ROBERT FRENCH
re-examined, I have compared the sample the officer has produced with the sample in the stable—they appear to agree—the prisoner had got seven pecks—one peck would be plenty for the horses—we never give them clear corn.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you often put a whole sack of oats on the coach to bait the horses with? A. I never saw it done—we send more than enough for one bait—the public-house is called the Greyhound—it is on the right-hand side of the road—it is a night-house sometimes on market
mornings, and it is open early for the mail—it is about three miles from Romford.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

2408.
THOMAS LANE was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

THOMAS FLETCHER . I live at Stratford, in the parish of West Ham, and am an ironmonger. I did not know Mr. Young personally, but the pri
soner had been several times for goods in the name of Young—on the 11th of April he said be came from Mr. Young for two coppers, the largest copper tea-kettle we had, and an iron boiler—he brought a string for the size of the coppers—we had none of the size, but he took an iron boiler—I gave him the boiler, and said I would go to Mr. Young, and speak about the coppers, intending to do so, but was prevented by some customers coming in—I believed the story he told me—I gave it him, conceiving that Mr. Young would be my debtor for it—I received informa
tion that he was selling the boiler, and went and took him.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I pay 1s. on the article? A. No.
MATTHEW YOUNG . I have seen the prisoner—I never sent him to Mr. Fletcher, nor did I authorize any one to get these things.
Prisoner. I offered to pay for the things, if he would look over it
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 31,—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

2409.
GEORGE SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of October, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
James Smith, from his person.

JAMES SMITH . I live in George-place, Greenwich. On the afternoon of the 19th of October I was in Charlton-fair, between two and three o'clock, looking at a show—an officer came up and spoke to me—I put my hand to my coat, and missed my pocket-handkerchief—I told him so, and the prisoner was seized instantly and searched—a crowd gathered round, and a man produced the handkerchief to us—this is it—(looking at it.)

JAMES ADAMS . I am Superintendent of the Lewisham and Lee police. I was at Charlton-fair on the 19th of October, and saw the prisoner stand
ing close behind Mr. Smith—I saw him put his left hand into Mr. Smith's right-hand coat-pocket, and take a handkerchief out—then put it into his right hand, and attempt to shuffle it up his coat—I took hold him immediately—I tapped Mr. Smith on the shoulder, and asked if he had lost any thing—and while I was searching them prisoner the handkerchief was produced—I am positive the prisoner is the person who took it—Mr. Smith moved a little forward while he was taking it, and I saw the handkerchief—it was the same colour as the one produced.

Prisoners Defense. I was looking at one of the shows, and the policeman collared me—I had no knowledge of the handkerchief—he searched me, but found nothing on me—and when we moved about a hundred yards, a Person brought the handkerchief up, and asked if he had lost any thing.

JAMES ADAMS
re-examined. He had moved a very short distance before I took him—I could not have mistaken him for another man
GUILTY .* Aged 21.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2410.
REBECCA SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; and 1 shirt, value 3s.; the goods of
Charlotte Cutts.

CHARLOTTE CUTTS . I am a widow, and live in Burton-court, East-lane, Greenwich. On the 15th of August I missed a shirt and handker
chief from a box in my bed-room—the prisoner lodged in my house for nearly twelve months—I charged her with taking them—she denied it for—I told her there was no one else in the place but her could have them—she said she did not have them—and some time after she pulled a dupli
cate out and put it on a chair, I found it was the duplicate of the shirt—another duplicate for the handkerchief was found by the officer in her bed

Prisoner, Q. Do you think I pawned the things with intent to rob you of them? A. I do not think but when she got sober she would have got them out of pledge—she had the means of doing so about a month after
wards—I do not think she intended to steal them.
NOT GUILTY .

2411.
JOHN BANNATYNE was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of September, 1 looking-glass and frame, value 1s., the goods of
George Car
penter.

MARTHA CARPENTER . I am the wife of George Carpenter, a smith, and live in High-street, Woolwich. On the 26th of September, between four and five o'clock, I saw the prisoner in the shop, putting a looking-glass into a bag—I went into the shop, and he asked if I wanted any matches—I perceived the back of the glass on the floor—I said, "Give me my glass out of your bag"—he said, "I have not got it"—I said, "I will charge the constable with you; hand it over to me directly"—he said, "You are a pretty person to charge the constable with me," and gave it to me, and walked out—I told Chittenden, who pursued and took him.
JOHN THOMAS CHITTENDEN . I am a constable of Woolwich. I took the prisoner into custody, he had a bag with him—I found a book in the bag—he goes about with matches—the book was claimed that evening.
(Property produced, and sworn to

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2412.
WILLIAM SMITH was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of October, at Charlton, 1 mare, price 10l., the property of
James Strother; and
WILLIAM MATTHEWS
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

PHILIP DWYER . I was employed by Mr. James Strother. He had a black mare, which I turned out, between five and six o'clock in the morn
ing, on the 7th of October, in a field down in Charlton parish, in Kent, in the Manor-way—I put her into the field—you go down the Manor-way to get to the field—it is a public road, leading to the fields—I locked the gate safe and left her there—there was no other horse there—I went to the field again the same evening, between five and six o'clock, and found the gate broken open, the lock and chain taken off, and the mare gone—I saw her again on Monday, she was brought from London to our premises.

CHARLES HARDING . I am a labouring man, and life at Woolwich I know the prisoner Smith by sight—on Saturday, the 7th of October I saw him near four o'clock in the afternoon, down Charlton Manor-way—I saw him in the turnpike road first—I went down the Manor-way, and he came down there, having turned out of the road—he came down close to Mr. Strother's marsh-gate, took a halter out by the side of a bush, close to the gate, and undid it—I said to him, "That is Mr. Strother's marsh and mare," and he went into the marsh, and put the halter on a black mare in Mr. Strother's marsh—I said to him, "I think that mare belongs to Mr. Strother"—(he must have seen me before he went into the marsh)—he said, "No, it don't"—he brought the mare out of the marsh, and went right up the Manor-way, and turned towards Greenwich, when he got on the turnpike-road—I did not see him unfasten the gate when he went into the marsh, nor take any lock away when he went—I did not see whether any lock was left there—he did not appear to have any difficulty in opening the gate.

JAMES GIDDENS . I am a licensed horse-slaughterer, and live in Black
friars-road. I know the prisoner Matthews by having a horse from him about ten years ago—I went to his place and killed it—I have seen him since then, and have had transactions in business with him, but that was my first acquaintance with him—on Saturday, the 7th of October, he brought a black mare to my house, near upon seven o'clock in the even
ing—he came to my gate with it, and asked me to buy it—I asked him how much—he said 50s.—I got a light and looked round the horse, and asked him where he brought it from—he said he had come from Squire Fuller's, at Beckenham, and had brought it from there—that he came from there—his expression was, "It came from there"—he said he wanted it killed, and to have the tail cut off, which must go back—he went behind the mare, and said, "You must cut the tail off about here," pointing to the place—he said one of Mr. Fuller's men was coming to his house for the tail, next Sunday week—I looked round the mare—she appeared very fleshy, and had a rowel in the side as if it was under a doctor—it appeared too good to kill, as I thought—I told him I had my suspicion, and should stop the mare, and take her to the station-house, and he had better come too—he said he would—I took the mare to the station-house, and told the Inspector I had suspicion it was stolen—I left it there—I saw her after
wards at Woolwich, in possession of Mr. Strother, and am confident it was the same mare.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he make any objection to going to the station-house? A. Not the least—he lives at Dulwich—I dare say that is between six and seven miles from Charlton—I never heard any thing against him in my life—he was allowed to go away from the station-house that night—I went with the policeman to his house at Dul
wich, on Monday night, and left a message for him to come to the station house that night, and he did come of his own accord the same evening—the mare had a diseased leg—an inexperienced person might probably not know it was not fit to kill

GEORGE HORNSBY . I am a policeman. On Saturday, the 7th of Oc
tober, Giddens brought a black mare to the station-house—he was in company with the prisoner Matthews—Giddens told me that Matthews had brought the horse to be killed—Matthews said he bought it of a man of the name of Smith, who told him a gentleman had sent him with it to be sold and killed in consequence of the bad leg—that was the account

he gave me of it—Mr. Giddens said he had known him a number of years and I did not detain him that night—the mare was put into the Green-yard—Mr. Strother got the mare on the Monday morning—Matthews gave me a description of the dress and person of Smith, in consequence of which the prisoner Smith was apprehended while I was looking for him at Woolwich—I did not apprehend him myself—I found the description to be exactly correct

Cross-examined. Q. Did Matthews appear anxious to find Smith? A.Very much so—he came to the station-house in consequence of the mes
sage left at his house—he was admitted to bail after the case was investi
gated.

PHILIP DWYER
re-examined. I saw the mare after it was brought back—it was the same mare that was lost—one of Mr. Strother's men brought it back on the Monday following—she was stolen on the 7th, and reco
vered on the 9th—it was a black mare—it had a rowel on the side, and her off hind-leg was very much swollen.

JAMES GIDDENS
re-examined. It was the off hind-leg that was bad—it was as big as my body pretty well—it was a disorder called the fess.

CHARLES AUGUSTINE SMITH . I took the examination of the prisoners, (after the usual caution,) word for word, as they delivered it—they did not sign it—they were not asked to do so—we do not always ask them to do it—it is signed by the Magistrates—I read it over to the prisoners before the Magistrates signed it—(read)—"William Matthews says, 'On Satur
day morning I was up at Norwood, digging potatoes in a field, from seven o'clock until about three, or twenty minutes after three o'clock—I went to take some potatoes to Mr. Page, of Dulwich; and it was half-past three o'clock when I got to the George the Fourth, at Norwood-hill—I took the potatoes to Mr. Page, and then went home—about five o'clock Smith brought a horse, and asked me to buy it—he said it was to be killed, for it came from a gentleman, and he was to take the tail back—I said I did not kill horses—this took place in Dulwich-street, in the village—he asked 2l. for the horse—I offered 23s. for it—he said he must have the tail, and would come on the Sunday week for it—I borrowed 4s. of a young man to enable me to pay for the horse—we had some beer together, and then he went away, and I did not see him again—I afterwards tried all I could to find Smith—yesterday week I bought another horse of Smith, which I also sold to Mr. Giddens.'"
