"The prisoner, William Smith, says, 'On Saturday morning, about one o'clock, I was desired to stay under Greenwich-park wall, at the top of Maize-hill, with four horses—I was desired to do so by Thomas Smith, my master, James Batchelor's foreman—I staid there till two o'clock—this black cart-mare was brought to me, and I was directed to take it straight across the heath, through Lewisham, and take it to the man where I had taken the other to; and I was to ask him 40s., for it, but to take what he bid me—he bid me 23s., which I took, and gave to Thomas Smith, where they are making the railway, by the canal—he gave me 2s. for myself—he put me on a horse, and sent me to Croydon with four horses—I had seen Matthews twice before this.'"

HARRIET DUDMAN . I live opposite the prisoner Matthews at Dulwich. I remember on Saturday, the 7th of October, seeing a black horse in pos session of Smith—Matthews borrowed 4s. of me to pay for the horse—it was against Matthews's door, turning out of the high road—I was not

near enough to hear any conversation between them—I have known Mat
thews six years—he has always been an honest man, and bore a very good character.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

MATTHEWS—
NOT GUILTY .

2413.
WILLIAM SMITH and
WILLIAM MATTHEWS were again indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of October, 1 gelding, price 7l., the property of
Richard Lewis.

WILLIAM COOK . I am a constable of Woolwich. On Wednesday morning, the 11th of October, from information I received, about six I o'clock, I went to Plumstead Manor-way, in Kent, and saw the prisoner Smith nearly at the bottom of what they call the short Manor-way, stand
ing alongside a brown gelding—I clapped my hand on his shoulder, and told him to consider himself my prisoner—he said he was very glad of it—I conveyed him to the cage, and have had the horse in my possession ever since—it is here now—it has been claimed by Lewis, of Woolwich.

JAMES CARLEY . I am a shepherd. I saw the prisoner Smith on Wed
nesday, the 11th, coming along the top of Mr. Lewis's marsh—Edward Mears was with me—Smith had a brown gelding with him, with a halter, leading it—he came as far as the gate, which he opened, and led the horse into the Manor-way—he turned round and shut the gate after him—he walked a few yards with the horse into the Manor-way, and there stopped awhile, he then turned the horse round and opened the gate again, led the horse into the marsh, and shut the gate after him—he waited awhile, and then opened the gate again, came out, and shut it after him—he came a little way along the Manor-way, and stopped there till the officer Cook went up and took him prisoner—I think he saw me, for I was standing nearly in front of him—I think he saw me and my companion after he first came to the gate—when I first saw him come out of the gate it was about half-past six o'clock in the mornings—it was Mr. Lewis's horse—I am acquainted with the marsh, and am frequently down there, I and Lewis had asked me to look after his horse.
JURY. Q. Did he bring the same horse out the second time as the first? A. Yes—he never took the halter off.

RICHARD LEWIS . I live in New-road, Woolwich. The constable came to me on Wednesday, the 11th of October—he had a horse with him which was mine, and had been kept in my marsh—I had not given the prisoner Smith any authority to do any thing with it—he is a stranger to me.

WILLIAM COOK
re-examined. The horse I took from the prisoner was the same as I showed to Lewis.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

MATTHEWS—
NOT GUILTY .

2414.
CHARLES PARR was indicted
for that he, having been con
victed of uttering counterfeit coin, did afterwards, on the 21st of September, utter and put off to one
Ann Penniall a counterfeit half-sovereign, well know
ing it to be counterfeit; against the Statute, &c

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I produce a copy of the record of the con
viction of Charles Parr at this Court, in January, 1835—I have examined
it with the original record in Mr. Clark's office, and it is a true copy—(read.)
JOSEPH KENT . I was present here in January, 1835, when the prisoner was tried and convicted of uttering a gilt sixpence for half a sovereign.

JAMES ALLING . I am a watch-maker, and live in Red Lion-street Whitechapel. On the 6th of September, about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came to my shop and asked for a flat watch-key—he spoke like a foreigner—I showed him a card of keys—he put his finger on a white one, and threw down a sovereign—I cut the key off, and put it in paper—it came to two shillings—it was a plated one—I sent my daughter up stairs for change, which she brought down; and among it was half a sovereign, which I had taken half an hour before—I counted it over to him on the counter—I am sure the half-sovereign I put down to him was a good one—the prisoner said, "Red one, red one"—(I had put up the white one)—I looked him in the face, and said, This is the one you made choice of, do you want a chain or a seal?"—he said, "Red one, red one"—I turned round to get a red one off the card, brushed it, and put it on a piece of paper—he was moving the change about with his hand over it, apparently counting it, and said, "One shilling, one shilling"—I said, "The price it two shillings"—he said, "Too much"—I took him to be a foreigner—he was dressed very showily, with a ring, and blue steel spectacles on, and a very fashionable coat and hat—I was tired of him, being busy, and I swept the change all off the counter, and laid his sovereign down, and thought it best for him to go out of the shop; he went on saying, "Too much, too much," walking off with the sovereign—I looked at the half-sovereign half an hour afterwards, and found it was a spurious one—it was a gilt sixpence—this is it—(producing it)—I am quite certain the prisoner left this—I had noticed my own half-sovereign—my daughter stood while I counted it over to him—mine was darker, and I knew it to be a good one—about half an hour before a neighbors had come in, and paid me 4s. 6d.—I then saw the half-sovereign, and looked at it with my eye-glass, and put it in a paper into my tea-chest

Prisoner. Q. Did you go to the station-house in Spitalfields to look at a man now in custody? A. did not—I did not state in my deposition that I was busy in placing a movement in a pair of gold cases, and the gentleman that came in held his bead down.
(The witness's deposition being read, contained the following sentence: "he held his head down, and said, a flat watch-key.")

CHARLOTTE ALLING . I am the daughter of the last witness. On the 6th of September my father rang the bell for me—in consequence of what he said, I went up stairs to the tea-chest in the bed-room—I took out half a sovereign, two half-crowns, and three shillings—the half-sovereign was in paper—I brought them down to the shop, and laid it on the counter, close to where the prisoner stood—I am sure he is the man—shortly afterwards I took the coin in question off the work-board—it was not the same half I sovereign that I had brought down stairs—I went to the baker's shop to get I it changed, and when I got there I discovered that it was not the same—I returned to my father's, and the prisoner was then gone—I am sure I get the same from the baker's that I carried to him—he is not here, but it was not out of my sight—he had no opportunity of changing it.

ANN PENNIALL . My father is a waterman living at Greenwich. I was at Mr. Deer's boot and shoe-maker's shop at Greenwich, on Thurs
day evening, the 21st September, about seven o'clock—the prisoner was in

the shop at the time I went in—I am quite sure he is the person—he was dressed very respectably except his shoes, which were shabby—he had a chain outside his waistcoat—I heard him ask for a bottle of blacking, which came to 1s. 6d.—he said, "Will you give me 8s. 6d., and I will give you half a sovereign?"—Mrs. Deer was attending to him—she looked into the till, and said, "I have no change—I said, "I have some silver, I will give you change," intending to speak to Mrs. Deer—the prisoner produced the half-sovereign, and I gave him four half-crowns—I looked al the half-sovereign, and asked Mrs. Deer if she thought it was good—she said, she thought it was—I had no other half-sovereign in my possession it that time—Mrs. Deer then put it into her till, as I intended to buy a pair of shoes of her, but I found none to suit me, and so she returned me the half-sovereign—just about this time Mr. Deer came in—the half-sovereign was shown to him, and he said it was a gilt sixpence, and asked if I should know the man again—I said, "I should—Mr. Deer took care of the half-sovereign—I went with him in search of the prisoner to the Buffalo's head—I had given a description of the person before I got there—I found him there getting change in payment for a glass of ale—I said, "You have given me a bad half-sovereign—he said he never saw me with his eyes before—the Buffalo is about five minutes walk from Mr. Deer's—this was about twenty minutes or half an hour after—I said, "You purchased a bottle of blacking, and I gave you four half-crowns"—he said, "You must be mad, or something else"—a policeman was there and took him—I think only two half-crowns were found on him—I had noticed he had the remains of a black eye, as if it had been bad, and was going off, and I noticed a broad mourning ring on his hand—I mentioned those circumstances to Mr. Deer before I got to the Buffalo.

Prisoner. Q. When you told the Magistrate that the gentleman had very shabby shoes, did not I take off my shoes, and show that they were quite new, and then you said they were very dirty? A. They were covered with mud and dirt, which made them appear very shabby.

COURT. Q. Was the man at the Buffalo dressed like the man at the shop? A. Yes—there was no alteration—I am certain he is the man—speak to him from the black eye, the ring, the watch-chain, the shabby shoes, and his face—I am quite sure he is the man.

DOROTHY DEER . I am the wife of John Deer, a boot and shoe maker, in Nelson-street, Greenwich. On the 21st of September, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was in the shop with Penniall—the prisoner was there, and asked for a bottle of blacking—I have heard Penniall's evidence—it is quite correct—the prisoner is the man—Penniall gave me the half-sovereign—I looked at it and put it into the till—I had no other there—I am quite sure I gave her back the same.
Prisoner. Q. Did you state before the Magistrate that you placed the half-sovereign along with other gold? A. No.
(The witness deposition being read, at the prisoner desire contained the following statement.—"When I put the money into he till, there, was no other half-sovereign in it."

JOHN RANDALL DEER . I remember coming home, and finding Penniall in my shop—a piece of coin was shown to me—I examined it, and saw it was a gilt sixpence—I gave it to my wife, and she gave it to me again after going to a neighbour with it—I delivered it to Sherwood the policeman—Penniall gave me a description of the man, and mentioned particular cir
cumstances about him—I was present when he was taken at the Buffalo's

head—the appearances she mentioned corresponded in all respects—I did not notice his black eye—he had a mourning ring on his hand, and a chain on his waistcoat—his shoes were dusty, which gave them a shabby ap
pearance.

RICHARD SHERWOOD . I am a policeman. On the 21st of September I met Mr. Deer and Penniall, and went with them to the Buffalo's Head and saw the prisoner—he had a guard-chain round his neck, a mourning ring on his finger, and spectacles in his pocket—his shoes were very dirty and he had a mark under his eye, as if he had had a black eye—I received from Mr. Deer a piece of coin, which I have marked—I searched the prisoner, but found no other bad money on him—I found one half-crown on him.

JOHN TUBMAN . I am a hat-manufacturer, and live in South-street, Greenwich, about a quarter of a mile from Mr. Deer's shop. On Thursday evening, the 21st of September, the prisoner came into the Coach and Horses in the Market-place, which is about twenty yards from Mr. Deer's—it was about twenty minutes to eight o'clock—he came in with a pair of blue steel spectacles on, and asked the landlady to oblige him with a sovereign for silver—I saw her give him a sovereign, and she took up the silver—there were two half-crowns—I am perfectly satisfied he is the person.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. The coin first produced is a gilt sixpence—it has been altered as the sixpences of that coinage have the garter surrounding the shield—a certain portion of that has been erased, leaving the bottom, which to a certain extent resembles the rose and shamrock on the half-sovereigns—the other one is also a gilt sixpence, but of a different coinage—the obverse side of that is the same as a half-sovereign exactly—the other side is quite different to a half-sovereign—this coinage was called in in consequence of being so much like a sixpence.

Prisoner's Defence. I am rather awkwardly situated—if I had not an hour to live, I am not the man who committed either of the offences—I was not in the shops of any of the witnesses in Greenwich—Mrs. Dun
ford has not been examined, and I wished to ask her some questions.

MARGARET DUNFORD . I live in Church-street, Greenwich. My house is between Deer's and the Buffalo's Head—the prisoner came into my shop that evening with another person, and dealt with me for two pain of straps—he gave me a sovereign.

Prisoner. Q. When you first came into the Magistrate's office, and he told you to look at me, did not you say you should not like to swear to me? A. I did say so—I said I wished you to have your hat on, and then I should know you better—I am rather particular, and I had never seen him without his hat—I wished him to put it on to be more exact, and I then knew him to be the person.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not request to have a private communication with the Magistrate, and did you not point out a gentleman, a pawnbroker, one of the richest men in Greenwich, as my companion? A. I looked at the gentleman who was in the office, and I thought he very much resem
bled the person of the other man, and I asked the Magistrate if I could speak to him—he said, "If it concerns the offence, speak out," and I said. "Does any one know this gentleman?"—the Magistrate said, "Yes, I do;" and I then said, "I am quite wrong then;" but Mr. Powel was present, and said he could bear me out, for the man who was not in custody

was very much like the gentleman—my husband has two shops, one a broker's and the other a clothier's—I had seen the prisoner at my shop—he gave me a shilling—that was about eight o'clock, as near as can be—I should think my shop is not a hundred yards from either the Buffalo or the Coach and Horses—it is rather between them, and not a great way from Ailing or Deer's—it is all in the neighbourhood.

GUILTY .* Aged 26.—
Transported for Life.

2415.
JOHN WILCOX was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Oc
tober, 1 leaden pump, value 8s., the goods of
William Dawes, and fixed to a certain building; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable R 49.) On the 25th of October, in the morning, I was on duty in Lewisham-road, and saw the prisoner carry
ing a load on his shoulder—I asked what he had got—he said, "A roll of lead "—I asked him to let me look at it, and found it was the head of a pump—I asked where he was going to take it—he said, "To New Cross, to a plumber's named Thorpe"—I asked if it was his own—he said, no, it belonged to Mr. Whomes who had sent him with it—I asked if the plumber was aware he was going to bring it to him—he said he believed he was—I went to Lewisham, and found, in an empty house adjoining the one the I prisoner lived in, a pump without a head to it, and it fitted it—we exa
mined the prisoner's house, and found some more lead which fitted to the same pump—he had 39lbs. weight of lead in his bag, and 27lbs. weight in his house—he said he lived there—I inquired at New Cross, and could find no Thorpe a plumber and glazier there—the whole of the pump was taken away level to the ground—all the leaden part of it was taken away—it appeared as if it had been recently unfixed, by the white lead—it appeared fresh moved, for it had rained that morning, and it was not wet—the house is in Lewisham, and is the property of Mr. Dawes—I have known the pri
soner two years, and never knew any thing against him.

GEORGE ABBOTT . I accompanied the officer to the room occupied by the prisoner adjoining Mr. Whomes's house, and found a saw and some lead hid under some shoes in the room—the lead appeared to have been cut with a saw, and the saw I found had lead in the teeth—I have fitted the lead and the pump head, and can say they formed part of one pump.

ROBERT WHOMES . I am agent to Mr. William Dawes, of Lewisham. The prisoner occupied a house adjoining the one the pump was taken from—I saw the pump before it was fixed in the yard—it was fixed against the house by a holdfast let into the brick-work—the prisoner had no busi
ness to take it—I had not employed him to take it to Mr. Thorpe, of New Cross—I do not know such a person.
Prisoner. The pump was not fixed to the house when I took it—the boys had been all over the empty house and pulled the pump down. Witness. It was fixed when I saw it last.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Three Months.

2416.
AUGUSTUS SCOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th October, 1 shirt, value 3s.; the goods of
Charles Wise: to which he pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

2417.
MARIA SMITH was indicted
for feloniously stealing, and carry
ing away a female child named
Ann Jones, aged 17 months; and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

2418.
ALEXANDER VICKERY was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of July, 1 gown, value 2l. 10s.; 4 shirts, value 15s.; 4 table-cloths value 13s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; 1 night-gown, value 1s.; 2 petti-coats, value 3s.; 3 sheets, value 6s.; 5 towels, value 2s.; 3 knife-cloths value 1s.; 3 shifts, value 6s.; 1 curtain, value 6d.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s. 6d.; 1 bolster-case, value 6d.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 1 apron, value 1s.; 1 watch-guard, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 6d.; and 2 pinafores, value 1s.; the goods of
George Parker.

ESTHER PARKER . I am the wife of George Parker, of Ship-street, Deptford New Town, a coachmaker. I have known the prisoner some time by coming to visit a friend of ours—on the 25th of July, about five minutes past eleven o'clock, he came to my house and wanted me to go and borrow half a crown for him at Mrs. Knowldon's of High-street—he said she would have it all ready—I proposed my little girl should go, but he said he would rather I went—I went, but did not get the half-crown—I was absent ten or twelve minutes—when I returned my little girl was crying—I was in
duced to go up stairs, and missed all this property—he was not there—he had said he would wait for the half-crown—they were all safe when I went out.
FREDERICK NORMAN . I live at Mr. Nash's, pawnbroker, London-street, Greenwich. I have a pair of shoes which were pawned on the 25th of July by the prisoner.
Prisoner. I did not pawn any shoes that day.

GEORGE PARKER . I am the husband of Esther Parker. These are my shoes—I found them at the pawnbroker's in about an hour—I took the prisoner on the 11th of this month at Brixton tread-mill, where he had been committed—I told the constable to take him—he asked him, "Do you know that gentleman?"—he said, "I have seen him"—I have found nothing else.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2419.
JANE ANGEL was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Sep
tember, 1 pair of trowsers, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Phillips; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY PHILLIPS . I lived in Queen-street, Greenwich, in the same room with the prisoner. I missed a pair of trowsers and a jacket on Wednes
day, the 27th of September—I found the duplicate of the trowsers on the mantel-piece.
THOMAS ELLEY . I am shopman to Mr. Nash, a pawnbroker. These trowsers were pledged by the prisoner on the 28th of September for 6d.
WILLIAM CONWAY (police-constable R 82.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 28th.

(The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she cohabited with the prosecutor's father, that she had supported the prosecutor, and frequently pledged the clothes and redeemed them, to procure necessaries.)

HENRY PHILLIPS
re-examined. She did not lodge with my father; he lodged in the College—I did not authorise her to pledge them—I did not
know that she did do so—I pawned the jacket myself only the week before, and took it out—I never sent her with them, nor knew of it
JURY. Q. Did the woman keep you or give you victuals? A. No, my father gives me victuals.
Prisoner. Q. Do you mean to say he never slept with you and me? A. No, never.

THOMAS ELLEY
re-examined. I know the prisoner, but she never pawned these things before.

WILLIAM CONWAY
re-examined. I do not know whether the prosecutor's father lived with her.
Prisoner. He stopped the witnesses from coming to speak for me. Witness No, I did not.
GEORGE WILSON (police-constable R 179.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present at the trial—she is the woman.

GUILTY . Aged 37—
Confined One Year.

2420.
ELIZA LYTHALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of October, 1 shawl, value 3s., the goods of
Matthew Forbes.

MARY FORBES . I am the wife of Matthew Forbes, a pensioner at Greenwich, and live in Queen-street. I had a shawl in my chest, on Sa
turday the 7th of October—I went out and returned in half an hour, and missed it—this is it.

SARAH ANDERSON . I live in Queen-street. On the 7th of October saw the prisoner come out with something under her shawl—a person called to Mrs. Forbes and said she had stolen something—the prisoner was stopped, and I found the shawl on her.
Prisoner. I was in company with the prosecutrix and her husband—I asked her to lend me a shilling, she said I might take a shawl and pledge it—she had been in the habit of lending me things before.
MARY FORBES . I never did. I have sent her with things to pawn, but not these.

GUILTY . † Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

2421.
SUSAN HILLMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of September, 1 blanket, value 3s.; and 1 quilt, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
James Allen.

SARAH ALLEN . I am the wife of James Allen, of Union-street, Green
wich. I let the prisoner a lodging, with a quilt and blanket, and missed them—I know these are mine.
THOMAS ELLY . I am journeyman to Mr. Nash, a pawnbroker. I produce these articles which were pledged by the prisoner, on the 26th a blanket, on the 29th a quilt and shift.
Prisoner's Defence. I pledged them through distress—I was going to get them out—the shift was picked up on the stairs—I inquired, and nobody owned it.
GUILTY .

2422.
SUSAN HILLMAN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of September, 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 pinafore, value 6d.; and 1 candlestick, value 1s.; the goods of
Edward Hurley.
ELIZABETH HURLEY . I am the wife of Edward Hurley. We were removing—I had a gown, and pinafore, and petticoat, between the beds as
I was moving—I missed them and a candlestick—I was going to occupy the prisoner's room—she was about, and saw the things.
CHARLES BAKER . I am a pawnbroker at Deptford. I produce this gown, petticoat, pinafore, and candlestick, which were pledged by the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Three Months.

2423.
MARY WARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of Sept
ember, 1 sheet, value 2s., the goods of
John Radan; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE SMITH . I lodge at John Radan's. On the morning of the 29th of September the prisoner came down and walked out—the land
lady went up stairs and missed the sheet—I went after her and found her close by the station-house—this sheet was found on her—I know the sheet—I slept in the bed on which it had been—the mistress of the house died on Saturday last.
Prisoner. Distress and poverty drove me to do it.
GEORGE EVANS (police-constable 41.) I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 67.—
Confined Three Months.

2424.
JANE HARRINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of October, 2 purses, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Thomas Chitt
enden.

WILLIAM THOMAS CHITTENDEN . I live in High-street, Woolwich—my wife keeps a toy shop—I am a policeman. About four o'clock on Saturday afternoon I was at home, and saw the prisoner come in in a hurried manner and take something from the window—I called her back, and asked what she had taken—she said, "Nothing"—I said I thought she had taken some purses—she said she had not—I saw part of the property in her hand—I took it out—she produced one purse before I took her hand—when my wife came she asked for a halfpenny-worth of pins.
HARRIET ELIZA CHITTENDEN . I followed my husband and missed the leather purse, and accused the prisoner of it—she produced the brown silk purse—my husband saw the other in her hand and took it.

GUILTY. Aged 52.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prose
cutor. —
Confined Six Weeks.

2425.
JOHN KNIGHT was indicted
for embezzlement.

RUTLAND ELCOMBE . I am a baker, and live in Swan-street, Great Dover-road. The prisoner was in my employ as a journeyman—he car
ried out bread to customers, and received money from them—I have a customer named Sarah Pavior—I gave the prisoner a bill for her every Monday morning—he brought the money to me at different times, but not regularly—the sum he brought home did not always agree with the bill—Mrs. Pavior, according to my books, is indebted to me 1l. 9s. 10d.—she owed me for one week's bill 12s. 10d.—the prisoner has not paid me that sum, which he should have done the day he received it.

SARAH PAVIOR . I live in Whitby-place, Lock's-fields. I deal with the prosecutor for bread, and pay my bills weekly—I have one receipt for 12s. 10d. which I paid the prisoner on the 16th of October—I paid him 12s. 6d.—the 4d. was thrown off—the odd half pencehave always I been thrown off.
Prisoner's Defence. I have had money several times, and always paid him regularly every Monday—I have said so and so has paid, and given him the money—I never defrauded him.

MR. ELCOMBE re-examined. I pointed out to him that the 12s. 6d. was deficient, and he said he was very sorry for it—he ought to have given it to me on the 16th of October when he received it—I send the bills every week to Mrs. Pavior—the first week's bill he paid me the full amount—the next week he paid me nothing—and the next week I tent in the bill with, "bill delivered" on it—but that he never gave her, he received the money from her, and signed her book.

Q. How soon after did you call his attention to this 12s. 10d.? A. I was going round with him, and Mrs. Pavior called me in—while I was talk
ing to her he placed the basket by the door and absconded—he had been home after being at her house, and I recollect asking him if Mrs. Pavior paid him—he said no, she would pay next morning—he did not return after running away.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

2426.
ELIZABETH STEAD and
GEORGE GARMAN were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October, 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 half-crown, and 4 shillings, the goods and monies of
George Curtis, from his person.

JOHN COKER . I am a shoemaker, and live in Kent-street, Borough. On the 9th of October, about ten o'clock at night, I saw the prosecutor in Kent-street—he was drunk—there were a great many persons about him—the prisoners were among the mob, which was pushing him about—there was a female in company with him, and they pushed and knocked her about—the prosecutor had a bit of pork—the female said the people wished to steal it, and she said she was going to take care of the man, and take him home—Garman took him into the Crown public-house, and stead went in too—they had two pots of beer to drink—the prosecutor paid for them—he spilled the first one and paid for another—the prisoners came out with the prosecutor—they took hold of him, one of each arm, and took him to the corner of a turning almost by the Crown public-house, called Crown-yard—Garman then held him behind by his two arms, and Istead laid hold of him in front, lifted up his frock, put her hand into his pocket, and shook him, and said something, but what it was I cannot say—she took a bag out of his pocket—she walked on a little way, and then Garman led the man on and she walked behind—she took something out of the bag, and turned it inside out—it linked like silver, and she put it into her bosom—she then walked some steps further, and tore the bag up—I saw her chuck down two bits of it—she. chucked one down first, and stamped on it in the road, and covered it over with mud—I picked it up—she went a little further, and chucked down the second, and covered it with mud—I picked that up also, and followed them on a little further—they took the prosecutor down a turning called Sweep's-alley, down by a Sunday-school, and there they left him and went home—I saw a policeman, and told him of it, and he went and found the man down there, lying tipsy.
Istead. Q. Have you ever been convicted? A. Yes, have—it

was on the 24th of last October—I had six months—I was charged with stealing wet linen—I do not do any thing of the kind now—I have worked hard for my living—I had a month once besides—that was for stealing a pennyworth of pudding.
COURT Q. Did you know the female prisoner before? A. Yes—ever since I can recollect almost.

Istead. He has brought me here out of spite—his mother and I quar
relled—she struck me, and that young man ran out and struck Me. Witness. I never struck her at all—I know nothing about it.

THOMAS WATKINS (police-constable M 174.) About eleven o'clock at night, on the 9th of October, Coker came and gave me information—I saw the prisoners come up from Sweeps-alley about two minutes before, and there found the prosecutor drunk—Coker gave me two pieces of a torn bag—I took the prosecutor to the station-house, and apprehended the prisoners about three quarters of an hour afterwards—Istead resisted being searched—I said, "Well, give me the money out of your mouth," and she pulled out what she said was 5s. 6d., but I found it was 6s. 6d.—I found 2s. 11 1/2d. on Garman, in copper.
Garman. The money found on me was my own.

GEORGE CURTIS I was very drunk that night—I found myself lying down somewhere—I knew Garman well, and thought I could trust my life with him—we had been fellow-servants—I recollect seeing the woman that night, also, at the Crown, but after I came out of there, I know nothing—Coker came to me and asked if I had lost any thing—I said I had lost my bag, but did not know how much money there was—there was six or seven shillings in it—I could swear to the bag as soon as I saw it, as had sewn it myself.
Istead. Q. Were you in another public house besides the Crown? A. I cannot say—I was not with another woman to my knowledge—I cannot say whether I was at Mrs. Burridge's.

Istead. You were with another female, and she went to see you home, and you went up into a concert-room. Witness. I saw the female prisoner at the concert-room—both the prisoners were together—whether it was the Crown, or where, I cannot recollect—I recollect Garman telling me be would see me safe home, as I told him I was quite forward in liquor.

Garman. I found him in there drinking, and said, "What cheer, Curtis?"—he said, "What cheer, Sergeant? "which is the name I go by—he came, and shook hands with me—I said, "I am going up stairs to have a pot of beer, will you go?"—he said, yes, he would go any where with me—the woman who was with him was a prostitute—I knew that she was so, and said she should not go up, and when I said that he knocked me down—she had been with him all day—after we came down stairs, he knocked same down again—he said he had left the bit of pork he had behind—I a knocked at the door, and got it for him, and gave it him—he then said he would have some more beer—I said no, I would see him home—he said a the passed the Crown that he would have another pot of beer—we had some, and after drinking about a pint of it, he said he would stand the rest—he gave me half a crown, and I paid for it—I did not see that he had any more money—when we had drunk that, he said, "George, I had better go home "—I said I would see him home—when we came outside I saw him as far as the Sunday-school—the female who was with him per
suaded me to leave him with her—I said, "Will you find your way home? "he said, "Yes," and I bid him, "Good night" and left him—
I had no occasion to steal—I had a good situation in Barclay and Perkin's employ.

THOMAS WATKINS
re-examined. After I took the prosecutor to the station-house, I returned, and met Garman by the Crown—I said, "I want you to go down to the station-house along with roe, you have been in company with Istead at the Crown, and likewise other public-houses "—he denied that he had been in the public house, or with Istead at all—I met my sergeant and left him at Istead's door—I went in, and told her I wanted her to go with me—she said, What for?" I said, "For robbing a brewer's servant"—she said she would go with me, and did—I found her in her own house—it is a house bad girls use, a lodging-house—it is fourteen or fifteen houses from the Crown, nearer London-bridge—I never knew the prisoners were acquainted—I know nothing of them myself.

GEORGE CURTIS
re-examined. I did not think Garman would have done such a thing—I knew his brother and father—I know no more than what the witness says—this is the bag I had in my pocket (looking at it.)
NOT GUILTY .

2427.
RICHARD HALL was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Collins, about the hour of nine in the night of the 2nd of October, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 waistcoat, value 20s.; 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign; his goods and monies.

RICHARD COLLINS . I am ostler at the Swan in the Old Kent-road, in the parish of St. George, Southwark. I rent the stables there, and the rooms over it, and pay 10s. a week for it to Mr. Elgee, who keeps the Swan—on the 2nd of October I left the place at half-past eight o'clock, and locked the door—there is a window at the side of the stable—I fas
tened that—there is no way into the room except through the door or window—I came back at twenty minutes after nine o'clock, and found the window open, and the bar forced down, which I had put up at the window—it had been nailed up—the window was pushed to—it is a sash-win
dow, and runs backwards and forwards—it was shut when I left it—the bar was nailed up inside—if the window was pushed back a person might force the bar down to get in—I unlocked the door and went into my room, and missed one waistcoat and eleven sovereigns and a half—the sovereigns were kept in a box which was locked—I found it broken open—the waistcoat was also kept in the box—I knew the prisoner be
fore—he had been about the house and about the yard before, as I em
ployed him—he came to me out of em
ployment—I said if he liked to assist me about the yard he might, till he could get employ—I had em
ployed him in that way about nine days—I have since seen the waistcoat on the prisoner's back—I lost it on the 2nd, and saw it on the 3rd, when I saw him in custody.

WILLIAM MORRIS . I am a policeman, to took the prisoner into cus
tody on the 3rd of October, in Bermondsey-street—he was dressed in a dark waistcoat with sleeves in it—I afterwards showed that waistcoat to Collins, and he owned it—I found eight sovereigns and a half in a purse concealed in his pocket—I told him I took him from information that he had stolen eleven sovereigns and a waistcoat from Richard Collins, and he denied it.

RICHARD COLLINS
re-examined. This is the waist coat I lost—I did not lose a purse—I slept in the room—I have no family.

THOMAS GAGE . I am barman at the Swan. I saw the prisoner at work there for eight or nine days before this—I saw him go into the yard between eight and nine o'clock on the 2nd of October—I do not know whether he had money of his own at that time or not—he did not ask to borrow any that I know of.

Prisoner's Defence. I had bought the waistcoat, and shirt likewise, that he gave me in charge for—I had ten sovereigns, and spent half a so
vereign over night—I had saved them up.

GUILTY of breaking and entering, but not burglariously.—Aged.
Confined One Year.

2428.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for feloniously breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
Matthew Fillmer and another, at
St. George the Martyr, Southwark, on the 7th of October, with intent to steal, and steal
ing therein, 1 neck-chain, value 8l.; 1 guard-chain, value 20s.; 1 neck
lace, value 12s.; and 1 pair of ear-rings, value 8s.; their goods.

HUGH ALLAN . I am shopman to Mr. Matthew Fillmer, a pawnbroker, living in Kent-place. I was putting the shop shutters up, on the 7th of October, about half-past six o'clock in the evening—I had put up three, and was putting up the fourth when I heard a smash—I turned round, and saw the pane of glass next to me was broken—it was the sixth lower pane of glass next to the shutter I was putting up—a person could then put his hand in, and take any thing from the show-board—I saw the pri
soner running across the road—I ran after him—he ran down Townsend-street, opposite—I did not lose sight of him—I caught Lim about 300 yards off, and on coming up to him, caught hold of him by his collar—as was taking him back, a person who had hold of him on the other side, asked him what he did it for—he said he had not got any thing—on tak
ing him to my master's I searched him, and found on him a lady's gold neck-chain, a coral necklace, and one gold ear-ring.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me break the window? A. No, but I saw you running away, and pursued you.

MATTHEW FILLMER . I live in the parish of St. George, Southwark, Surrey, and am a pawnbroker—the house belongs to me jointly with my brother—I am in partnership with him. On the evening of the 7th of Oc
tober I was called from the shop, and informed that a window had been broken, and property stolen—I immediately made the best of my way to the front, and after putting a few things from the edge of the window, the wit
ness brought the prisoner back—I saw the articles found on him—this other gold neck-chain was handed to the shop man by a person—the necklace is coral, and has a label attached to it—here is a guard-chain and an ear-ring, the fellow to which was found on the ground outside, in the street, with several other things—I can safely swear to all these articles being our pro
perty—there is a communication between the shop and the rest of the house—you can come into the shop from the house without going out of doors—I have a perfect recollection of seeing the large chain in the win
dow on Saturday morning when I passed the window

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2429.
ALEXANDER LAWSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of September, 1 necklace, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Poile, from the person of
Martha Poile.

SUSAN MARSH . I am in the service of Mr. Thomas Poile. I had his child in my arms in Great Suffolk-street, Borough, on the 20th of Sep
tember—her name is Martha Poile—she was twelve months old last Au
gust—she had a coral necklace on her neck—I was coming home from the Borough, and was just by Mr. Lloyd's, the carpenter's gate, when all at once. I felt something shoved against me—I turned my head round to see what it was, and the prisoner had got the necklace in his hand—he had got it off, and ran down John-street—I never saw him before, but I am certain he is the person—I cried out "Stop thief"—he was followed, and a young man ran after him, but came back again, as he had left his shop—there was no one with the prisoner when he took the necklace, but there were two more on the opposite side of the way, who had been in company with him, and one of them was taken—I did not see them speak together.

SARAH MATTHEWS . I am a widow. I saw Marsh with a child in her arms in Suffolk-street, about eleven o'clock in the forenoon—I saw the pri
soner cross from the side of the road on which I reside—I was coming out of my own door—he crossed over to the side on which the girl was, followed about two hundred yards behind her, then closed with her suddenly, took the necklace from the child's neck, and ran off—I ran across the road to try to take him, but he turned into a street, and was pursued by a butcher's boy—I called,"Stop thief"—but he was not taken that day—I had seen him in the neighbourhood before, and knew his features very well,

Prisoner. Q. What do you know me by? A. I Have seen you about I the neighbourhood selling paper—I live at the corner of Suffolk-street—I saw you cross the road, there was nobody passing at the time, and I saw you had a design upon the girl, for you pointed to her before you closed upon her—I walked about three hundred yards up the street, watching you—there was no one with you at the time you took the necklace, but there were two boys in company with you just before, and one of them was taken and committed for two months.

WILLIAM POUND . I am a constable. On the 20th of September I saw the prisoner in the Borough, opposite St. George's Church, with two others, as near eleven o'clock as possible—they turned back from the church, and came towards Suffolk-street, all three of them—I followed them—they followed a gentleman about three hundred yards, then left him, and went up Suffolk-street—I saw them following Susan Marsh—after following her a few yards, my attention was taken by something else, and I heard a cry of" Stop thief "—I saw the prisoner run away, and the other two cross the road—the prisoner passed the girl, and ran down John-street—I went across, and seeing a mob, thought they had stopped him, but they had not—he got away—I went in the direction the other £ro took, and took one of them—I did not see any body take any thing from the child, but I saw them all in company close to the girl.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in London at the time the robbery was committed—one man was taken at the sametime—the prosecutrix swore to him, and he was committed for two months.

SUSAN MARSH
re-examined. I never said it was any other person.
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

2430.
ELIZA WRIGHT and
ELIAS WRIGHT were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of September, 3 quires of paper, value 4s. 6d.; 12 books, value 8s.; 20 printed books, value 16s.; 18 pens, value 6d.; 12 boxes of paints, value 1s. 6d.; 2 wax pears, value 6d.; 1 yard measure value 2s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; the goods of
Charles Borras, their master.

WILLIAM HENNINGHAM (police-constable L 175.) On the 28th of September, about seven o'clock in the evening, I was on duty in Newing
ton churchyard, and saw the prisoner Eliza Wright loitering at the back of the houses which goes against the churchyard—she was walking up and down—the back of Mr. Borras's house comes close against the churchyard—after a short time, I saw the prisoner Elias Wright give her a bundle over the back wall of Mr. Borras's house—I stopped her, and asked what she had got—she said, "Nothing"—I said, "You must go with me, you have something wrong here"—she said, "For goodness sake say nothing about it; what shall I give you?"—she had the street-door key in her hand, and asked me to let her go into the private door of her master's house—I took her in there and searched the bag, in the pre
sence of her mistress, who brought Elias into the shop to me, and I took them both into custody—Elias said he knew what the contents of the bag were—Mrs. Borras saw every article.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was there not a young lady taken into custody by you? A. Yes, at the same time—I believe she was shopwoman to Mr. Borras—it was not by their direction I took the woman, it was on my own responsibility—when I took Eliza into the shop, and took Elias, the witness Morton said that Eliza had bought the yard measure mentioned in the indictment of her master—I then took Morton into cus
tody, and she was detained all night at the station-house, taken before the Justice, and remanded till the following Tuesday, when the Magistrate dis
charged her, thinking there was not sufficient evidence to detain her—I have a book here, in which entries are made of goods sold.

ELIZA BORRAS . I am the wife of Charles Borras; he has a situation in the City, and we carry on the business of fancy stationers at Newing
ton. The female prisoner was our household servant, and the other the errand-boy—they are brother and sister, and both resided in the house—the policeman brought Eliza in with the bag—I identify the whole of the property as belonging to ray husband—no part of it had been sold by me—I believe the yard measure is entered in the book as sold, and a writing-book also, I believe—our shopwoman was discharged at Union-hall, and has been very ill since—I know this spelling-book—it has my private mark in it—it was never sold by me

Cross-examined. Q. You cannot say whether Miss Morton might not have sold it? A. I cannot say—there is not any entry of a book sold in Miss Morton's writing on Thursday, the 28th—these are the reading-library books, not what are sold in the shop—some of the entries are my own writing—what is entered at the bottom of the page was sold after they were in custody—Miss Morton's entries on the 28th are, "Paper, 1d.; mea
sure, 1s.; paper, 4d. "—the entries are not for books sold, but lent and re
turned home, and paid for.
COURT. Q. Are there three quires of paper entered there? A. No, nor
twenty books, nor the other articles named in the indictment—(looking at the property found in the bag)—these are our articles

ADELAIDE MORTON . I was in the service of Mrs. Borras as shop-woman, and had been so about four months—I was in the habit of selling things over the counter, and of making entries in the book of what I sold—I have seen these things—I sold a few of them to the prisoners—do I not exactly know what they were—there is a yard measure I sold—there I was some paper, but I cannot tell how much—not so much as three quires—I do not know whether I sold as much as a quire—I did not sell the wax pears, nor these books, nor the copy-books—I think I sold some of the pens to Eliza Wright—she paid for what she bought—I did not sell her any thing on the 12th of September, but a yard measure—she paid 1s. for that, and it is down in the book.

COURT. Q. Things sold in the shop might hare been carried out with out going through the churchyard? A. Yes—I am fourteen years old—I entered in the book all the money I received, and all I allowed them to have.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not you let her have on credit the things which do not appear in the book?

COURT. You are not bound to answer the question. (Not answered.) Witness, I did not give the bag produced to the boy—I did not five him the things to give to his sister—I do not know whether he knew his sister had purchased any articles—I did not give him any thing to carry to his sister.

ELIZA BORRAS
re-examined. There is a handkerchief among the things produced in the bag—that is my own private property, and would not be told in the business—it has my maiden name on it—Miss Morton was not authorised to give credit to any body without express directions—the churchyard is at the back of the house—it is not the way goods would be carried out of the house—there is a shop door into the street—it does not lead into the churchyard—persons buying goods at the shop would go out at the shop door—the male prisoner was not in the habit of carrying out goods sold—nothing but newspapers—I do not think we ever sent any thing home—he was not employed to take things home

JURY to WILLIAM HENNINGHAM. Q. What distance is the house from the churchyard wall? A. The front of the house is in High-street, and a long garden goes down to the churchyard—it is a low wall, and there is the rectory-house—I saw the girl walking up and down the churchyard waiting, and saw the boy give the bag into her hands.

ELIZA WRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years. ELIAS WRIGHT.—
NOT GUILTY .

2431
THOMAS BURY was indicted
for feloniously receiving, of an evil-disposed person, on the 18th of September, 5 quires of paper, value 10s.; 6 prints, value 1s. 6d.; 2 prints, framed and glazed, value 3s.; 1 inkstand, value 1s.; 1 umbrella, value 4s.; and other articles; the goods of
Charles Borras; well knowing them to be stolen; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM HENNINGHAM . I am a policeman. After taking Eliza Wright into custody, I went up stairs to search her box, in the presence of Mrs. Borras—I found this letter in it, and several other letters—in conse
quence of which, I went to Trafalgar-street, Walworth-road, and found the prisoner there in bed, about twelve o'clock at night—his mother showed

me to his bed-room—I asked him if he knew Eliza Wright, who lived servant to Mr. Borras, a stationer, at Newington—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Have you any of Mr. Borras's property here, has she brought any?"—he said "No "—I told him to get up, for I should take him into custody, and search his room—when he got up, I said, "I have some letters in my pocket, which I found in her box"—he said, "Well, I was only carrying on courtship with her, and was going to get married to her"—I showed him the letters, and he said they were his handwriting, and she had supplied him with the paper to write them on, and she was always bothering him to write to her—I was going to search his box—he said, "You will find all right here"—at the bottom of his box I found this satin tinted note-paper concealed under the other things—I saw Mrs. Borras take down two pictures from the room—I searched the cupboard, and found a package sealed up in the cupboard, and in that was a toilet-bottle, a pair of pumps, a needle
case, a small pocket-book, a pen-case, a silver toothpick and case, a card
case, another pocket-book, two books, and a shell—I should think them worth more than 1l.—they were sealed up with wax, in brown paper.

COURT. Q. Did you find any articles which were not sealed up? A. Yes—these two pictures—one has the maiden name of Mrs. Borras on it—they hung up in the room—I told him he must go with me—he said Eliza Wright had brought them all there, and he did not know what the package contained—he did not say for what purpose she brought them there—I went to his room again on the Saturday afterwards, and found a gingham umbrella.

ELIZA BORRAS (looking at the property.) This picture is mine—it was my mother's, and has been in the family forty or fifty years—I had it at the house in Newington—it was put into the cupboard, the door of which was locked, and the key in it—I had it in my house after the girl came to live with me—the other picture is mine, and was in the same place—I have looked at the other things—they belong to Mr. Borras—this toilet-bottle and tooth-pick I know—Eliza Wright had not applied to me to purchase such things—the value of the paper found in the prisoner's box is 10s. or 12s.—it is very expensive, and all fancy paper—this umbrella is Mr. Borras's—I never authorised any body to take it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Whose writing is this, "Thurs
day, 27th of September, one umbrella 4s. 9 1/2d.,"in the book? A. I do not see 4s. 91/2d.—"here is umbrella. 1s. "—Miss Morton wrote that, I think, but that is umbrella mending, 1s.—this was never in the shop, it was intended for sale, but had never been put into the shop—the value of it is 7s. 6d.—we never have umbrellas at 1s.
CHARLES BORRAS . This is my umbrella—I never authorised any body to move it from my house, or to sell it.

WILLIAM HENNINGHAM
re-examined. The cupboard in which I found the parcel was not locked—it was the bed-room cupboard, and the pictures hung in the bed-room—the umbrella was down stairs, in the back room.
NOT GUILTY .

2432.
WILLIAM REDSHAW, alias Walters,
was indicted
for rob
bing
Frederick Hazell, on the 18th of September, at
St. Mary, Lambeth, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 breast-pin, value 2s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 9 shillings; and 1 sixpence; his goods and monies.

FREDERICK HAZELL . I am footman to a lady living over the water, and have lived with her nearly three years. On the 18th of September last I was walking in Walcot-place, leading from the Asylum in Kennington-road, to Westminster Bridge—the prisoner came up to me, and said, "How do you do?"—I told him I did not know him—he said he was certain that he did knot? me—I told him, he did not—he then said he had seen me several times about the neighbourhood—I said it was very likely, for I was very often that way—he said he knew me when he was in town before—that he had not been long from the country this time—we walked on some little distance together—he said he lived with his uncle, who kept a grocer's shop near the Obelisk—we had a little more conversation, but I do not know all that passed—we walked as far as Prince's-square, which is About five minutes' walk from where I first met him—we had continued walking on—it was from half-past eight to nine o'clock in the evening—he then asked me if I would have a glass of ale—I said, "No"—he asked me again, and I said, "No; "and the third time he said I had better take a glass of ale, it would not take above a minute—I at last consented to do it, and we went into a public-house together, called the Prince of Wales—he called for a pint of ale, and paid for it—while we were drink
ing the ale, he said he wanted some money—I asked him what he wanted it for—he said he wanted a sovereign, and he must have it; and if I did not give him one, he would follow me home, and charge me with having committed s----y----I told him I had not got any money—he said, it was no use my saying I had not got any, for he must have it, and would have it, and he had got plenty close by, ready to swear to whatever he said, let it be whatever it would—we then walked out of the house, and got into Prince's square—he then said he must have a sovereign, and that he would not leave me till he did have it—I was very much frightened, and gave him 9s. 6d.—I had a gold pin in my shirt—he said he must have that too—that was worth about 2s. 6d.—he said, "You have got a handkerchief, and must have that too"—it was a silk one, and was in my pocket—I gave him the pin and handkerchief—he then left me, and I went home—I saw him again on the 12th of October, in Blackfriars-road—there was another person with him then—I saw him again on the 14th, with two others, at my mistress's house, but he came alone—after seeing him there, I applied to the police, and he was taken into custody that day in Prince's square—I gave him the money, pin, and handkerchief, because I was afraid that he would follow me home, and say what he had threatened—when I met him on the 12th, in Blackfriars-road, he said he would follow me home, and threatened me with what he had the day before.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. A footman—I lived in Prince's-place, Kennington-road, at the time—I lived there about two years and a half—there was another person with him on the 12th—did not owe that person any money—I swear that—I had not bought any property of that person—there was never any arrangement between me and that person that I was to pay any money to the prisoner which I owed him—I gave him (the prisoner) the money on the 18th, because I was afraid he would go home, where I was in service, and state what he had said he would—that was the only thing that operated on my mind—I did not tell him where I lived.
MR. JONES. Q. In any conversation you had with the prisoner, did he ever tell you he was to receive any money which you owed to a third party?

A. No—I had never seen that person before the day I met him with the pri
soner in Blackfriars-road—I never had any transaction with him, directly or indirectly, about money, property, or any thing else.
COURT. Q. Where were you going on the 18th of September, when you met the prisoner? A. I was going home—I had been up to Charlotte-street, Oxford-street.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How long had you been out on that occasion? A. I cannot say exactly, I believe about three hours—I had been on business for my mistress—I went to No. 31, Upper Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square to a doctor's—I was gone three hours on that business—it was to Dr. Micheli's, but it was not to him I went, but to my mistress's son who is apprenticed there—I was in the direct way home from Westminster
bridge to Kennington—I was not more than ten minutes' walk from home when I met the prisoner—I did not see any policeman between the time of my meeting him and getting home—there are several policemen about there—I saw the prisoner twice afterwards—it was the third time I gave him into custody.

MR. JONES. Q. Why not give him into custody when you met him the second time in Blackfriars-road? A. Then there was two of them, and I was more frightened then than the first time—I was alone—I had no other reason for not giving him into custody then—the third time I saw him was at my mistress's house—I saw nobody to give him into custody to then—there was nobody but myself and him there—another person came up to him while I was talking to him, and that person said something to me—there were only two females in the house—there was no man—I gave information to the police after seeing him there, and he was taken in ten minutes after.

JURY. Q. Did you go into the parlour of the public-house to have the glass of ale? A. Into the tap-room—there was no one else present—the door was open, and it is facing the bar—I cannot say whether any one in the bar could have heard our conversation—the tap-room is on one side of the passage, and the bar on the other, but they are very close together—I should say we were about five minutes in the public-house, but not more than that.

Q. Who brought the ale in to you? A. The landlord—it was paid for at the time—I believe the landlord went out directly he got the money—I did not notice him standing about the door—I do not think our conversation was very low, but was not loud—it was a small tap-room—I do not think the landlord returned into the tap-room after taking the money—there was nobody in the tap-room—I do not know whether any person was sitting near.
MR. JONES. Q. Why did you not apply to the landlord for assistance? A. I was afraid of what he said, that he would say what he had threatened to say.

HENRY LUPTON (police-sergeant L 6.) The prosecutor applied to me on the 14th of October, and in consequence of what he said, I and a con
stable appointed to meet him in Prince's-square in the evening—we went there about twenty minutes after six o'clock—when I got to the entrance of the square I observed four men—I think they observed us—we were within twenty yards of them—when we first came to the entrance of the square they were standing still, talking together, apparently in company—after we made our appearance they walked on, two together—the prisoner is one of them, and Page, who is in custody, was another—I do not know

either of the other two—one of them is known, but I do not know him—the prisoner and a taller man turned to the left, towards White Hart-row—Page and the other turned to the right—the prosecutor lives in Prince's place, about four doors from the square—after this the prosecutor came—the prisoner first met him, and turned with him into the entrance of Prince's-square—Page came to the right, and went up to them—the prose
cutor gave a signal which had been agreed on, and I went across the road—Page and the prisoner were walking arm in arm into the square, and I took them into custody—the prisoner said, "It is not me you want, it is the other man"—the taller man—the prosecutor said, "This is the man I have given the money to before, and you must take him to the station"—I saw the other two men standing at the top of the square, just by the public-house—I searched the prisoner at the station-house, and found two handkerchiefs, two gold rings, and the duplicate of a pin, which I produce—also, 26s. in money, and a watch-case—I searched Page, and found a handkerchief, and duplicate of a ring on him—I asked the prisoner where he lived—he said at 43, Little Surrey-street—I went to that house, and saw Mrs. Hayes—I there found the duplicate of a gold watch, and a writing-desk.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the name of any of the other persons there? A. I do not, of my own knowledge—the name of Denton was given, bat his real name is Hunter—I have not seen any thing of him lately.

MR. JONES. Q. Had you known Denton before? A. No, I did not know him of my own knowledge—I have been looking for him since, but I cannot find him—I did not ask the prisoner if he could tell me where to I find him—I had no conversation with him about that person—the pin was pawned on the 13th of July.

FREDERICK HAZELL
re-examined I have not seen my pin since I gave it to the prisoner—neither of the handkerchiefs found on the prisoner is mine—I have not seen my handkerchief since—I have looked over these, but it is not among them.

DIANA HAYES . I am a widow, and live at No. 43, Little Surrey-street, Blackfriars-road. I was examined at the police-office, and bound over to appear here—the prisoner lodged with me between three and four months—we lived together as man and wife—Page also lodged in the house—he and the prisoner came together about the same time—they had lived opposite, at No. 23, in the same street, and came from there to me—the prisoner assisted my shop while he was with me—he had no other means of getting his living while he was with me—he had been in the tea way—I have heard him say he had been in the country within four months of September last—he did not go into the country at all while he lived with me, which was between three and four months, up to this time
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know a man named Denton? A. I saw him come backwards and forwards to my house—I heard the prisoner say that Denton owed him money.

MR. JONES. Q. Who did Denton come to-tee at your house? A. The prisoner—Denton is a tall man, not more than thirty years of age, I think; rather stout, and fair—I do not know what he is—I knew nothing of him before the prisoner came to live with me—the last time I saw him was the Saturday the prisoner was taken into custody, to the best of my recollection—I have not seen him since—he lived in Church-street, Blackfriars-road—he seemed an intimate friend of the prisoner's—I have heard the prisoner say he knew where he lived.

HENRY LUPTON
re-examined. I have heard the witness's description of Denton—there was such a person among the four men that day—I walked close to him.

FREDERICK HAZELL re-examined. When I met the prisoner in Black
friars-road, on the 12th of October, the person Mrs. Hayes describes was with him, and I recognised that person on the day the prisoner was taken in Prince's-square.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Death Recorded.

2433.
WILLIAM REDSHAW was again indicted, with
JAMES PAGE
, for feloniously assaulting
Frederick Hazell, on the 14th of Octo
ber, at
St. Mary, Lambeth, and feloniously threatening to accuse him of an infamous crime, with a view and intent thereby to extort and gain from him divers of his monies.—2nd COUNT, for assaulting and demanding, with menaces, monies from him, with intent to steal the same

FREDERICK HAZELL . On the 14th of October, in consequence of a ring at my mistress's bell, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I went to the street door, and found the prisoner Redshaw there—he said, "How do you do? I want two sovereigns, and I must have them, for I am going into the country this evening"—I said I had not got them—he said he must have them, he was going into the country in the evening—I said, "I have not got them"—he said, "You have got a watch, let me have that, and I will pledge it, and send you back the duplicate "—I said, "I have not got one, where am I to get one?"—he said, "Get it as we do, how you can "—about this period of the conversation another person came up, who I had seen with the prisoner on the 12th, in Blackfriars-road—that person said to me, "How pale you look, how you tremble, give him the money, he will not say any thing "—I was trembling at the time—Redshaw then said, "You must have more clothes than you have got on, let me have them, and I will pledge them and send you back the dupli
cate "—I told him I could not get any money then, but I would meet him at eight o'clock in the evening, and if I could not bring all, I would bring as much as I could—my mistress was not at home at that time—she is a widow lady—there was no man in the house at the time—Redshaw said, "Go and ask your mistress for the money "—I told him she was not at home—it was then I said I would meet him in the evening—I could not say what time my mistress would be at home that evening—she might be home in about an hour or later, I could not tell—Redshaw asked what time she would be at home, and I said, "In the evening"—it was after that I agreed to meet him in Prince's-square, in the evening, and said I would bring him as much money as I could—I asked him to meet me at the corner of White Hart-row, which is the second turning from where I live, at eight o'clock in the evening—he said he could not wait so long as that, he would meet me at half-past six o'clock, at the corner of Prince's-square—they then both went away—while I was in conversation with them, the prisoner Page walked past, and looked at me, and went and stood two doors off—that was after I had been talking to them about three minutes—I do not think he was near enough to hear our conversation—I had never seen him before—I did not see what became of Page when the other two went away—I left home about ten minutes after they were gone, and informed the police—they did not go away in the direction Page was, but the other way

—I did not see Page after I saw him standing two doors off—how long he stood there I cannot say—I went out at the back door when I went out, but I saw Page again—I saw three of them in Prince's-square when I was going to the station-house—they were all three together, looking at some things in a broker's shop—I turned back and went another way, that they should not see me—I was about the middle of Prince's-square, and they at the other end—I was more than a hundred yards from them, but I saw them again before I got to the station-house, at the corner of East-street, Kennington-cross—they were then looking at another broker's shop, all three together, and talking together there—I did not say any thing, but tried to avoid them, and I think I did so—they did not speak to me—I was on the other side of the way—I passed very near to them, within six or seven yards—I saw nothing more of them again, till I met them in the evening—they seemed to me to be all talking together—it was the third man who came to the house, and he is the person I saw in Blackfriars-road—about twenty minutes after six o'clock I went to the corner of Prince's-square, and saw Redshaw there alone, walking up and down—I said, "You are here very soon, what a very great hurry you are in "—he said, "I have been to your house, I could not wait any longer "—he said, "I suppose you were at home, although they said you were not?"—I said, "I was at home "—he then said, "Have you brought the money? I was just coming again "—I answered that I had not got the money, I could not get the two sovereigns, but I had brought him all I could—I did not say how much it was—Redshaw said, "I must have it, for I am going to the west end, and have got to be there by seven o'clock, and I cannot lose that for you"—he then said he would not take any money unless I had got the two sove
reigns—I said, "You had better take what I have got, for I cannot get any more"—I had two marked shillings in my pocket at the time—at that moment Page came up, and said to Redshaw, "Bill and took hold of his arm—they left me directly, and began to walk down Prince's-square—I did not hear what more was said—I had come with the policemen from the station-house to the square—the policemen were within sight of Page at the time—I had come with them to the end of the square, and then we parted—they were in sight of Redshaw when I first saw him, but he could not see them—they were on the opposite side of the way, in Kennington-road, out of Redshaw's sight—they could see him, for they were watching for him—I do not think he could see them—he was not looking that way I—he was paying attention to what I was saying—I did not see Page at that time, but when he came up and touched Redshaw on the shoulder—I suppose he had seen the policemen then, but I cannot say whether he had—I walked close behind him and Redshaw, when they walked away, and said, "You had better take the money"—I had not said what money I had—Redshaw said, "No, I will not take it now; you shall hear from me again soon"—I then gave a signal, by taking off my hat, which had been agreed on, and the policeman came and took them both into custody—when he took them I said Page was not the one, meaning he was not the one that had spoken to me—the policeman said, "I must take them both to the station-house," and then I gave them both in dirge—I had met Redshaw and the other man in Blackfriars-road on the 12th—I did not owe that man any money—I never had any transaction with him—I never made an agreement to pay Redshaw any money that I owed that man—they never said any thing to me about my owing him any money—they and that man's name was Denton—I never owed a person of that name
any money—I appointed to meet Redshaw in the evening, in Prince's-square, in order that I might give him into custody of the police—he did not say why he wanted the two sovereigns.

COURT. Q. You were trembling very much; state what you were afraid of? A. I was afraid of his charging me with what he had said be
fore—that he would charge me with committing s----d----y----he threatened me with that charge on the 18th of September—when I met him in Black
friar's-road on the 12th of October, he then said if I did not give him the money he asked me for, he would follow me home, and charge me with the same as he had threatened before—I was still afraid on the 14th that he would charge me with what he had threatened—it was that which caused me to tremble—I had been ill in consequence of it—I believed he would have done so, had I not promised to meet him as I did

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. I think you said you saw Page I pass by the door when Redshaw called on you? A. Yes, and I saw him twice again before I got to the station-house, in conversation with Redshaw and the other man—I do not recollect mentioning that before to
day—I never saw Page till the 14th of October—I am quite sure it was Page I saw—I cannot be mistaken—I have stated all the conversation that took place at the door between me, Redshaw, and the other man, as far as my memory serves me—they demanded the money—I do not think there was any threat used then—I was under the impression of the threat which had been used on a former day.

MR. JONES. Q. Had the prisoner Redshaw any claim on you for money? A. No—I never owed him any, or had any transaction with him out of which any claim could arise—when I told him I had no money and no watch, he told me he must have it—I told him I could not let him have it, for I never had a watch—he said he must have the money, but he did not use the threat, I believe, on the Saturday—he said he was going into the country in the evening, and could not and would not go without it.
JURY. Q. Did any money pass between you and Redshaw in the square? A. No.

HENRY LUPTON . I am a police-sergeant. In consequence of a communication with the prosecutor, I, accompanied by a constable, went into Prince's-square on the evening of the 14th of October—when I first got there I saw the two prisoners and two other men—they were all together—they could see me as I came into the entrance of the square—one of the others was a person said to be Denton—the prosecutor went with us from the station-house to the top of Prince's-square by Kennington-cross—I saw them standing near Kennington-road, at the bottom of the square—we separated at the Cross—the prosecutor went down White Hart-row into Kennington-road, and I went down Prince's-square by another thoroughfare, so as to meet in the square—as soon as the four persons saw me they went in two two's—Redshaw and the tall man turned to the left towards White Hart row, and Page and the other turned to the right—the tall man who was with Redshaw crossed over to the other side and stood with his arras folded on the other side of the road—Redshaw then walked towards White Hart-row, and met the prosecutor just as he came round the corner—he turned back with the prisoners and walked to the entrance of the square—tall man who was on the opposite side of the road took a little circle, then crossed the road and came into the square, and Page came to the square, and stopped with Redshaw and the prosecutor at the entrance of the square—I was not near enough to see whether Page touched anybody

—he very likely saw me before he went up to them—I could see him, and he might have seen me—the road is thirty or forty feet across—there was nothing between us to obstruct our view of each other—I was within thirty If or forty feet of him—the prosecutor and Redshaw appeared to be talking together till Page came up, and after he came up the prosecutor gave the signal we had agreed to, and the two prisoners walked away arm in arm—they had turned away before the prosecutor gave the signal, and were walking arm in arm into the square—I came up and took them into custody—I Redshaw said, "It is not me you want, it is the tall man "—I had not told I him who or what I wanted him for before he said that—I took them both to, the station-house—I heard Redshaw say to the inspector at the station-house that the prosecutor owed Den ton some money, and he was to receive it on Den ton's account, and he said he had never seen the prosecutor before that day in his life—Page never spoke—the prisoners were told the charge against them, but Page said nothing—I searched him and found 6d. and two farthings, a duplicate and a handkerchief—the money was given back to him—on Redshaw was found two handkerchiefs, a duplicate, one bad sovereign, and 6s. 6d. in silver—I afterwards went to No. 43, Little Sur
rey-street, and found the prisoners lodged there—it is a coal-shed and green-grocer's—I saw a man in the shop there—it is three or four hundred yards from the obelisk.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to that shop in consequence of Page telling you he lodged there? A. They both gave that address—I found it with some difficulty—I was dressed just as I am now—the four men had an opportunity of seeing me when I saw them together.

Redshaw. He said before the Magistrate, last Monday, that there were three of us, and then he said there were four of us together. Witness. I said at first that there were four, and there were four—I distinctly saw them.

MR. JONES. Q. Did you attend at Union-hall Police-office when the charge was heard against these persons? A. I did—the examination was taken down in writing—I heard the prisoner's statements—they were taken down, and they signed them—I stood close to them, and saw them sign it—the examination was before Mr. Wedgwood and Mr. Trail—this is the prisoner's writing, and this is Mr. Wedgwood's signature—(looking at it)—it was read over to them before they signed it.

(Read.)—"The prisoner Redshaw says, 'I never saw the prosecutor in my life till the Thursday when I met him in Blackfriars-road—Denton was with the prosecutor—Denton owed me 2l.—I joined them, and Denton said the prosecutor owed him 3l. 10s., and it was agreed that the prosecutor should pay me the 2l. which Denton owed me—he told Denton, if he had not got the money he would sell his watch, and make it up—I was to go on Saturday afternoon to the prosecutor for the money—I went alone, about three o'clock, and he told me to meet him in the evening; and Page and I met him accordingly, in Prince's-square, when we were apprehended.'
(Signed) WM REDSHAW."

"The prisoner Page says, 'I never saw the prosecutor till Saturday even
ing, in Prince's-square—I went there with-Redshaw—he said he was going there to receive a little money—after he was speaking to the prose
cutor some little time, I said to Redshaw, 'William, are you coming?' and went on.? (Signed) J. PAGE.

FREDERICK HAZELL re-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Did you ever tell Denton, if you had not the money you would sell your watch, and make it up? A. No, I never had a watch—I did not agree to pay Redshaw 2lfor any debt I owed Denton.
any money—I appointed to meet Redshaw in the evening, in Prince's-square, in order that I might give him into custody of the police—he did not say why he wanted the two sovereigns.

COURT. Q. You were trembling very much; state what you were afraid of? A. I was afraid of his charging me with what he had said be
fore—that he would charge me with committing s----d----y----he threatened me with that charge on the 18th of September—when I met him in Black
friar's-road on the 12th of October, he then said if I did not give him the money he asked me for, he would follow me home, and charge me with the same as he had threatened before—I was still afraid on the 14th that he would charge me with what he had threatened—it was that which caused me to tremble—I had been ill in consequence of it—I believed he would have done so, had I not promised to meet him as I did.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. I think you said you saw Page pass by the door when Redshaw called on you? A. Yes, and I saw him twice again before I got to the station-house, in conversation with Redshaw and the other man—I do not recollect mentioning that before to
day—I never saw Page till the 14th of October—I am quite sure it was Page I saw—I cannot be mistaken—I have stated all the conversation that took place at the door between me, Redshaw, and the other man, as far as my memory serves me—they demanded the money—I do not think there was any threat used then—I was under the impression of the threat which had been used on a former day.

MR. JONES. Q. Had the prisoner Redshaw any claim on you for money? A. No—I never owed him any, or had any transaction with him out of which any claim could arise—when I told him I had no money and no watch, he told me he must have it—I told him I could not let him have it, for I never had a watch—he said he must have the money, but he did not use the threat, I believe, on the Saturday—he said he was going into the country in the evening, and could not and would not go without it.
JURY. Q. Did any money pass between you and Redshaw in the square? A. No.

HENRY LUPTON . I am a police-sergeant.
