In consequence of a communication with the prosecutor, I, accompanied by a constable, went into Prince's-square on the evening of the 14th of October—when I first got there I saw the two prisoners and two other men—they were all together—they could see me as I came into the entrance of the square—one of the others was a person said to be Denton—the prosecutor went with us from the station-house to the top of Prince's-square by Kennington-cross—I saw them standing near Kennington-road, at the bottom of the square—we separated at the Cross—the prosecutor went down White Hart-row into Kennington-road, and I went down Prince's-square by another thoroughfare, so as to meet in the square—as soon as the four persons saw me they went in two two's—Redshaw and the tall man turned to the left towards White Hart-row, and Page and the other turned to the right—the tall man who was with Redshaw crossed over to the other side and stood with his arms folded on the other side of the road—Redshaw then walked towards White Hart row, and met the prosecutor just as he came round the corner—he turned back with the prisoners and walked to the entrance of the square—the tall man who was on the opposite side of the road took a little circle, then crossed the road and came into the square, and Page came to the square, and stopped with Redshaw and the prosecutor at the entrance of the square—I was not near enough to see whether Page touched anybody

—he very likely saw me before he went up to them—I could see him, and he might have seen me—the road is thirty or forty feet across—there was nothing between us to obstruct our view of each other—I was within thirty If or forty feet of him—the prosecutor and Redshaw appeared to be talking together till Page came up, and after he came up the prosecutor gave the signal we had agreed to, and the two prisoners walked away arm in arm—they had turned away before the prosecutor gave the signal, and were walking arm in arm into the square—I came up and took them into custody—Redshaw said, "It is not me you want, it is the tall man"—I had not told him who or what I wanted him for before he said that—I took them both to, the station-house—I heard Redshaw say to the inspector at the station-house that the prosecutor owed Denton some money, and he was to receive it on Ben ton's account, and he said he had never seen the prosecutor before that day in his life—Page never spoke—the prisoners were told the charge against them, but Page said nothing—I searched him and found 6d. and two farthings, a duplicate and a handkerchief—the money was given back to him—on Redshaw was found two handkerchiefs, a duplicate, one bad sovereign, and 6s. 6d. in silver—I afterwards went to No. 43, Little Sur
rey-street, and found the prisoners lodged there—it is a coal-shed and green-grocer's—I saw a man in the shop there—it is three or four hundred yards from the obelisk.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to that shop in consequence of Page telling you he lodged there? A. They both gave that address—I found it with some difficulty—I was dressed just as I am now—the four men had an opportunity of seeing me when I saw them together.

Redshaw. He said before the Magistrate, last Monday, that there were three of us, and then he said there were four of us together. Witness. I said at first that there were four, and there were four—I distinctly saw them.

MR. JONES. Q. Did you attend at Union-hall Police-office when the charge was heard against these persons? A. I did—the examination was taken down in writing—I heard the prisoner's statements—they were taken down, and they signed them—I stood close to them, and saw them sign it—the examination was before Mr. Wedgwood and Mr. Trail—this is the prisoner's writing, and this is Mr. Wedgwood's signature—(looking at it)—it was read over to them before they signed it.

(Read.)—"The prisoner Redshaw says, 'I never saw the prosecutor in my life till the Thursday when I met him in Blackfriars-road—Denton was with the prosecutor—Denton owed me 2l.—I joined them, and Denton said the prosecutor owed him 3l. 10s., and it was agreed that the prosecutor should pay me the 2l. which Denton owed me—he told Denton, if he had not got the money he would sell his watch, and make it up—I was to go on Saturday afternoon to the prosecutor for the money—I went alone, about three o'clock, and he told me to meet him in the evening; and Page and I met him accordingly, in Prince's-square, when we were apprehended.'
(Signed) WM. REDSHAW."

"The prisoner Page says, 'I never saw the prosecutor till Saturday evening, in Prince's-square—I went there with Redshaw—he said he was going; there to receive a little money—after he was speaking to the prosecutor some little time, I said to Redshaw, 'William, are you coming?' and went on. (Signed) J. PAGE.

FREDERICK HAZELL
re-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Did you ever tell Denton, if you had not the money you would sell your watch, and make it up? A. No, I never had a watch—I did not agree to pay Redshaw 2l. for any debt I owed Denton.

Redshaw. Q. Did you not meet me on Thursday, about half-past nine o'clock, along with Denton? A. I met him in Blackfriars-road, with a man they call Denton, on Thursday evening—that was acci
dentally, not by appointment—Denton was with the prisoner at that time. Redshaw. Denton was with you—I met you walking together, did I not? A. Denton was walking with Redshaw, not with me—I did not ask them both to go and have something to drink—I had no conversa
tion about 3l. 10s., nor any sum of money owing from me to Denton—I did not tell Redshaw to come down on Saturday, about half-past three o'clock.
Redshaw. It is no use asking him any thing further—he denies every thing.

DIANA HAYES . I am a widow, and live at No. 43, Little Surrey-street. The prisoners lodged with me between three and four months—on Satur
day, the 14th of October, Redshaw left my house about three o'clock, or a little after, to the best of my recollection—I do not recollect whether Page went out with him—I do not think he did—I did not see Redshaw again till he was in custody—I do not know what time Page left—I do not re
collect seeing him since between two and three o'clock—I think I saw him between two and three o'clock—we generally dined together between twelve and one o'clock—I think he dined with me that day—I do not know the exact time he left my house, but I believe it was between two and three o'clock—I will not be certain whether the prisoners left together—I do not recollect seeing them both go out together—I saw Redshaw go out of the parlour—Page was not in the parlour at that time—I cannot say how long he had left it—it might be half an hour—they both lived toge
ther, and were on friendly terms—they did not go out much after they came to my house—they sometimes went out together—neither of the pri
soners have directed me to make any application to the prosecutor since they have been in custody—I have seen the prosecutor, and spoken to him—I did not see him after I had seen the prisoners—I have not seen them all the week since last Monday, at the Hall, and I had not spoken to the prosecutor then—whatever I said to the prosecutor was out of my own head.
Redshaw. Q. Do you know Denton? A. Yes—I saw him last on the Saturday you were taken.

Redshaw. No, it was the Saturday week. Witness. It was on Satur
day morning—I cannot say whether it was the day you were taken—there was some dealing between you, but I was in and out of the shop, and do not know particularly—I saw a rough coat, which you said you had sold him, and a dark pair of trowsers—Denton took them away, I believe—I had seen them before—they were yours.

MR. JONES. Q. Within how many hours before these persons were taken had you seen Denton A. I do not know—I cannot say whether I had seen him that day—I cannot undertake to say on which day it was I saw him—I have been examined here before—I said it was on Saturday, but I do not know the day of the month they were taken—he was fre
quently in the habit of coming to my house—I saw him two or three times a week—I believe I might have seen him within two or three days of the prisoners being taken, but I will not say, for I cannot recollect—it was on a Saturday morning that I saw him, and I believe it was the Saturday they were taken—I have not seen him since the prisoners have been in custody—I
am sure of that—I make no mistake about that—he has never been near I the house since, that I know of.

Redshaw's Defence. The first time of my meeting the prosecutor was on Thursday evening, about half-past nine o'clock, in Blackfriars-road, he and Denton were together—Denton said, "How do you do; will you turn back, and walk with us?—I walked as far as the Elephant and Castle—the prosecutor and Denton were talking about the 3l. 10s. which he owed to Denton, and when we got to the Elephant and Castle, the prosecutor said, "Will you go in and take any thing to drink?"—I said, "No"—Denton said, "I want the money you owe me, for I am going out of town on Saturday—and he said to me, "I dare say you want your money that I owe you"—he owed me 2l—I had seen him the day before about the money—he said to the prosecutor, "Would you pay him; it would do as well as paying me?"—he said, "I will ask mistress for the money"—I left them, and told him before I left that I would come down on Saturday afternoon, and asked him what time—he said, "Half-past three o'clock in the afternoon; and ring the bell at the gate"—I went ac
cording to my appointment, and left the prosecutor and Denton together—I went about half-past three o'clock—the prosecutor answered the bell, and said, "How do you do? you have come for the money, I have not got it; mistress is not within"—I said, "You told me and Denton you would let us have it, or make away with your watch"—he said, "I have not got it, mistress will be in; you had better call in the evening"—accordingly, I called about half-past six o'clock, and that was the second time I ever saw him in my life—I went to Denton, and he was not at home—Page was there—I was going to be married in a short time to Hayes—I went down to tell Denton, and while we sat at tea, he said, I will make you a watch, John has not done yours, which he had to repair"—he said, "I will soon make you a watch"—we both stopped there to tea—it quite slipped my memory—I went out with the watch, as it was still in my pocket—I asked Page to go with me—I was going to receive the money—I saw the servant, and said, "Is the footman within?"—she said not—I said, "What time?"—she said, "I don't know exactly, but I think he will be in in a minute"—on turning from the gate, I saw the prosecutor—he said, "Here you are—I said, "Yes, am I in time?"—she said, "Yes, you are in time, I have not got the money; I can let you have part of it"—I said, "Part of it will be of no use; you had better wait till Denton comes from the coun
try"—he said, "You had better take it"—Page came and said, "William, you had better come on; what are you waiting for?"—and the policeman came and took us—there was nobody with us at all—Page went with me from Mrs. Denton's, as I asked him—the prosecutor had something in his hand in the square, and said, "You had better take it"—the policeman, when he came up, said, "Have they taken it?—he said, "No, but I will give them in charge"—I said, "It is not me, it is the other man you want," meaning Denton, as I had not been with the prosecutor before.

REDSHAW—
GUILTY .

PAGE—
NOT GUILTY .

2434.
ROBERT BIRD and
ROBERT GREENWOOD were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of October, at
St. Mary, Newington, 1 mare, price 50l., the property of
John Campbell.
WILLIAM HENNINGHAM . I am a policeman. On Sunday morning, the

22nd of October, I saw the prisoners High-street, Newington—Green-wood was riding a mare—the other prisoner was walking on the footpath close by, dressed in a smock-frock—it was a dark-grey mare which has since been claimed by the prosecutor—the prisoners were in company—I stopped Green ward and asked Where he came from—he said, "From the White Hart Inn, Lewes, in Sussex"—I asked him what time he started from Lewes—he said at half-past five o'clock in the morning—it was then twenty minutes after ten o'clock—I told him he had, made more haste than a four-horse coach could come—he said he had led the horse part of the way and rode it the other part, and was going to take it to Thetford, had employed him—Bird had got on a little way—I called him, and said, "What part have you come from with this mare?—he said, "From Godstone"—I then took them both into custody on suspicion of stealing the mare, as their stones did not agree—the mare did not appear at all exhausted—when I went to take a description of Bird's person, Greenwood came out and when he was going back to be locked up, he said he wished to speak to me, that he wanted to tell me all about it—I said what he told me would be given in evidence before the Magistrate—he said, at half-past five o'clock in the morning he stood by while Bird went into the field and took the mare out of the field of Colonel Campbell, at Bletchingly, in Surrey

MICHAEL CHARLTON . I am steward to Colonel John Campbell, who lives at Bletchingly, in Surrey. I have seen the grey mare which was de
tained by Henningham—it belongs to my master, and was missed on Sun
day morning, the 22nd, about six o'clock—the field was well fenced round, and the gate fastened with a rope, which I found untied, and the gate a little open—I know nothing of the prisoners—the field is about a quarter of a mile from the high-road—there is a bye-road to it.

WILLIAM HENNINGHAM
re-examined. I was present before the Magis
trate—I did not see what the clerk wrote down—I saw Greenwood sign his name to the statement—,(looking at it)—this is his signature, and this is Birds mark—I saw him make it—it was read over to them before they signed it—(read)—"Both prisoners say, we were together when we took the mare from Captain Campbell's field."

BIRD—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

GREENWOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fifteen Yean.

2435.
JOHN DAVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Octo
ber, 1 canvas bag value 9d.; 115lbs. Weight of sugar, value 4l. 2s.; and 6lbs. weight of tea, value 1l. 12s.; the goods of
John Roffey.

JOHN ROFFEY . I am a carman, and live at Charlwood, in Surrey, two miles from Crawley. I received a bag at the shop of North, Simpson, and Co., to be conveyed according to the address—I went to the Talbot Inn, in the borough, and there put the bag on the top of the load—I then went to an ironmonger's near St. George's Church—I went into the shop, and was absent about five minutes, and when I came out, the bag was gone.

JOHN PRIVET . I am shopman to North, Simpson, and Co., of Bridge-street, Blackfriars. In consequence of directions from Mr. Middleton, of Blowfield-heath, near Crawley, I delivered to Roffey the bag containing 115lbs. of sugar and 6lbs. of tea with the invoice which I made out—it came to 5l. 14s.—this is the bag—(looking at it.)

THOMAS BENJAMIN PERCIVAL . I am an officer of Portsoken-ward. On the evening of the 24th of October, between six and seven o'clock, I was passing along Houndsditch, and the prisoner passed me a few doors from Gravel-lane, about two miles from St. George's Church, carrying this bag with its contents—I ran up Gravel-lane, and stopped him, and asked where he was going—he said, "Just round the corner"—I said that would not do, and asked who employed him—he said he got his living by carry
ing parcels in the street—that a gentleman stopped him near London-bridge, and asked him to carry it—he could not tell where he was to take it to, but afterwards he said something about the Cock and Hoop—I opened it afterwards, and found the invoice.

Prisoners Defence. I was on London-bridge by the steam-wharf—a gentleman came up and said, "My lad, will you carry this parcel down Houndsditch, and I will give you 1s.?"—so I carried it—the gentle
man kept talking to me till I got to Houndsditch, when I was taken hold of, and then he went away—I thought he was following me—when the officer told me to stop, I thought that it was the gentleman speaking to me

T. B. PERCIVAL re-examined. I never saw the prisoner before—I saw one or two parties a few yards from him, but I saw no more of them after
wards—one man in a round jacket was going to follow him up the lane, but he saw me—the prisoner was dressed similar to a porter, in a round hat and fustian coat—on going to the Compter, he said he got his living as a porter, and lived in Rose-lane, Spitalfields.

GUILTY .* Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2436.
EVAN EVANS was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
William Allen.

RICHARD BARLOW . I keep the Rodney Arms New King-street, Dept
ford. I did not know the deceased Allen before Sunday, the 8th of October, when he came to my house, about twenty minutes before seven o'clock in the evening, with a soldier and a girl—the girl went away, and Allen and the soldier went into the tap-room—Allen was very much intox
icated, and the soldier a little in liquor—there were about seven persons in the tap-room—the soldier and Allen were in the same box with the pri
soner, who is a sawyer—in a short time the prisoner and Allen quarreled—I heard them making a noise, and ran into the tap-room—I thought they were quarrelling, because the deceased said, "Never mind, I am determined to fight this man," and he pulled his coat off to fight—I said I would have no fighting there—I took Evans out of the house, and told him to go home—I then went to the deceased, and made him put on his coat, and asked him to sit down for a few minutes, to govern his passion, which he did; in about five minutes he went out of the house, and put his back against the partition as he went out, and said, "I wish I could meet with that man, I would have a fight with him to-night"—he bid me good night, and went out, and in about two minutes, I saw him lying on the ground, about eight feet from my door—the prisoner was intoxicated as well as the other.

Cross-examined by MR. CURWOOD. Q. The deceased took his coat off, and would fight? A. Yes; he was very much intoxicated—I have known the prisoner eight years—he works for me at times—he is a hard-working, peaceable man—for what I know, Allen might have struck him before he got into the tap-room.

THOMAS ALLEN I am a private in the 1st Battalion of the Rifle Bri
gade at Woolwich. I went with William Allen to the public-house in question—he was no relation of mine—I have heard him called by the name of William Allen—he was not sober when he entered the house—I was sober enough to know what passed—the prisoner sat in the same box with us—they tossed for a pot of beer, and Allen charged the prisoner with cheating him—that brought on a quarrel—the prisoner was not sober—he went out by the direction of the landlord—I and Allen came out after
wards, and found the prisoner at the door, and he took and knocked Allen down, directly he got his foot on the step to go out—Allen did not say any thing about fighting the prisoner before he received the blow—I have heard what Barlow has said—it is not true—he did not express any wish to fight the prisoner—he did not say so in the public-house—I did not see him take his coat off—I was in the same box with him—Allen fell to the ground from the blow—I helped to pick him up—the prisoner's son came out of the public-house, and knocked me down—I have since seen the body of William Allen dead—I did not hear Allen express any wish to fight—I do not think he could have taken his coat off unobserved by me—no blow bad been given in the tap-room—the prisoner gave no notice to the deceased before he struck him, nor say any thing to put him on his guard.

Cross-examined. Q. What Barlow has stated you say is not true? A. No, it is not—Barlow was not drunk—I was a little in liquor, but knew what I was doing—I had been with Allen about two hours and a half, drinking with him—he was drunk before I fell in with him—he lived seventeen days after this.

ROBERT GIFFIN . I am a labourer, and live near the Dockyard-gate, in New King-street. I was standing in front of the Rodney Arms on the evening in question, when some people were running to the house—I ran over, and saw the prisoner strike Allen in the face—I cannot say in what part—he fell with the blow, and hit his head against the curb-stone—I did not notice whether the prisoner remained or went away—I was looking at the deceased—I heard a voice before they went up, but could not distin
guish from whom it proceeded.

THOMAS ROSE (police-constable R 154.) I observed some persons col
lected in front of the public-house on the night of the 8th of October, and found the deceased lying on the ground, bleeding profusely from the nose and mouth—I took him to the station—I took the prisoner into custody at the end of Brunswick-square, New-road—he came to me and asked if I wanted him—he said, "I hear you have been looking for me"—I said, "Yes, wanted him," and said, "It is an unfortunate job you have got into"—he said, "I should have supposed the blow never could have injured the man in the way described," and he said he struck but one blow.

Cross-examined, Q. Did you know him before? A. Yes, for nearly eight years, as a hard-working, industrious man—he is given to drink, but I never knew him quarrelsome or troublesome—I have always found him ready to assist me in the execution of my duty.

THOMAS COOK . I am assistant to one of the surgeons of Guy's Hospital. I saw the deceased when he was brought there on the morning of the 9th of October, about ten o'clock—he appeared in a state of stupor—that might arise from drunkenness, or the joint effect of a blow and drunkenness—I afterwards observed a slight external bruise on his left eye—he recovered

from his stupefaction partially—he became much worse afterwards, and then insensible, and was so up to the time of his death, which took place on the 25th of October—I have examined the body since death—the vessels of the brain had burst, both those between the skull and the brain, and also those in the brain itself—between the skull and brain there might be a tea-poonful of blood, and in the substance of the brain a large clot of blood, which would half fill a common tea-cup, and there was a fracture about an inch and a half long on the right side—the immediate cause of death was the extravasated blood, which arose from the rupture of the vessels—if he had received a blow and fell on the curb-stone, that would account for the state in which I found the head—all the parts of the brain were in a healthy state except those in contact with the blood—it was a recent disease.

Q. Having heard that he was in a state of considerable intoxication when he received the blow and fell on the curb, and seeing the state of stupe
faction in which you found him, are those causes together sufficient to have caused death? A. Yes—the appearances were not those of ordinary apo
plexy arising from drunkenness—there must have been external violence to produce the appearances I saw.

Cross-examined. Q. Death was occasioned evidently by pressure of blood on the brain from a ruptured vessel? A. Yes—excitement or drunkenness may rupture vessels—it does so in apoplexy, if the coat of a vessel happens to be thin and defective—his partially recovering and getting vorse again did not indicate a second rupture of the brain—the first state of insensibility was not caused by the pressure, but by the shock or blow—if the vessel had burst in consequence of drunkenness, he would not have recovered in the way he did—I think the spoonful of blood and the half tea-cup full, were caused by a rupture at the same time—it is not at all uncommon for persons receiving a blow to remain in a state of stupor for twenty-four hours, from the effect of the blow alone, without any pressure of blood being thrown out—I attribute the first symptoms to the direct shock of the nervous system.
GEORGE ALLEN . I live in Church-street, Deptford. The deceased, William Allen, was my brother—he was thirty-nine years old, and was a healthy man,
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 48.—Strongly recommended to mercy.
Confined Three Months.

2437.
WILLIAM GALE and
JAMES FARRELL were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of September, 1 gelding, price 1l., the property of
John Gare.

JOHN GARE . I am a green-grocer. I keep a black gelding pony, which I turned out on Wednesday, the 27th of September, into Mr. Phil
lips's field on the Wandsworth-road—it is an open piece of ground—I misted it the same evening—I afterwards went to Giddens and got it—it is worth 1l.—the horse being small might squeeze through the fence.

JAMES GIDDENS . I live in Blackfriars-road. On Wednesday after
noon, the 27th of September, between two and three o'clock, I was passing by the Obelisk at St. George's, Southwark, in a cart—it is in the way to London from the Wandsworth-road, and about two miles from Mr. Phillips's—I saw the two prisoners—Farrell was leading the po
ny, and the other had a stick beating it, as it was going very slow—they

went through the Surrey turnpike, which would lead them to my house in Green-street, Blackfriars-road—at half-past four o'clock the same evening I came home with a horse I had been after, and saw the same pony in my yard—I went to Chelmsford that evening, and returned on Friday night late, and next morning I missed the pony—what became of it I do not know—my wife is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

2438.
WILLIAM GALE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of October, 2 asses, price 1l. 12s., the property of
Thomas Wilmot,

THOMAS WILMOT . I am a dustman, and live in Moss-fields, Vauxhall-walk, Surrey. I had a donkey and colt, which I turned out into Short's fields on the 13th of October—there was nothing to prevent them straying into the road, but they never did so—on the following afternoon I went to Smithfield-market to buy a cart, and saw my donkey there being offered for sale—I stopped it and the man who had charge of it, upon which James Wells came up and said something to me, and I gave Wells into custody—the donkey was given up to me—it was worth about 25s.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far is the field the asses were in from Smithfield? A. About three milesand a half, or four miles—the colt is a small one.

JAMES WELLS . I am a carman, and work for my father, East
mount-terrace, in Whitechapel-road. On Friday, the 14th of October, I was going to Camberwell-grove with a van—I went to Kennington-lane, and met Gale with a donkey and a colt, going from Kennington to Camberwell—he was leading the donkey with the halter, and the colt was following—I said to him, "How much is the donkey?"—he said, "I have sold the little one to a lady for 7s. but I want 1l. for the big one, it be
longs to my brother"—I said, "I will give you 15s. for it"—he said, "My brother will take 16s."—I said, "I won't give more"—he said, "Take it away, I know I shall do right; "and I gave him the money for it—it was my father's money—I had 1l. 15s. in my possession—I went to Camberwell-grove, and loaded some goods—I took the donkey with me—I then led it home to Mr. Solomons, who belonged to the goods in the van—I drove the van home—a young man, named Wright, asked me if I wanted to sell it—I said, "Yes, "I would take 1l. for it—he said he would give 19s.—I would not take it, and he gave me 1l—I went to Smithfield to buy a collar for a pony, and Wright was there with the donkey, and Wilmot owned it—I went up directly, and said, "I bought that donkey, and sold it to that young man"—Wilmot gave me in charge—I was let out on the Saturday.

Cross-examined. Q. How near were you to Wright at the time you were taken into custody? A. About two hundred yards from him—I sold it to him the same afternoon as I bought it—directly I heard it was owned I went up.
NOT GUILTY .

2439.
WILLIAM GALE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of October, 1 mare, price 3l., the property of
Jeffrey Matthews.

JEFFREY MATTHEWS . I had a black mare-pony, which I turned into Mr. Fenlong's field, Clapham-road, on the 19th of October—the field was enclosed—the pony could not get out without assistance—the field was fenced round, and has a gate to it—I saw it safe at ten o'clock on the 20th—in consequence of information I received that day I went to the
field, and she was gone—I went to Giddens, and found her tied up in his yard—it is worth 3l.—I had never seen the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far is you place from Gid
dens's? A. About two miles—I live in Devonshire-place, Vauxhall—I did not observe any appearance of the gate being broken—it was fastened with a hook.

JAMES GIDDENS . I live in Green-street, Blackfriars-road. The pri
soner came to me on the 20th of October with a black mare-cob, about fourteen hands high—he asked if I would buy it—I knew him before, and directly he came in I desired my man to shut the gate—I asked him where he brought it from—he said his brother had sent him to sell it—I asked what he wanted for it—he said 15s.—I asked him his brother's name—he said he lived at No. 1, Devonshire-place, Kennington-cross, and his name was Matthews—I said, "What is your name? "—he said, "Gale"—I said, "How comes your brother's name Matthews?"—he said, "He has been married lately, and that alters his name "—I said, "No, it does not; I shall stop you, and send to know if it is true"—he said, "Don't stop me; you may keep the pony, and I won't tell my brother where it is"—I sent my man to Mr. Matthews, who came and owned it—I asked him, in the prisoner's presence, if he was his brother; and he said he had never seen him before.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you make a memorandum of what passed be
tween you and the boy? A. I did, but I have not brought it here—I boy fifty horses in a week sometimes—the prisoner is the same boy as I had seen in Blackfriars-road.

GUILTY. Aged 11—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Twelve Months; One Month Solitary.

2440.
BENJAMIN LAPPING was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of September, 1 bag, value 2d.; 13 sovereigns; 34 half-sovereigns; and 2 £5 Bank-notes; the goods, monies, and property of
George Edward Noone, in his dwelling-house.

GEORGE EDWARD NOONE . At the time in question I kept the Griffin, in Church-street, in the Borough—I now live at Notting-hill. On the 25th of September I was sitting in the bar-parlour, taking wine with a friend—the prisoner and his brother stood at the bar—they had been in the house all the evening, I believe—I invited them to take a glass of wine—they came and sat down and drank—my friend left while they sat with me—my attention was called to a disturbance at the bar, and I left the prisoner and his brother in the parlour—I took my watch, ring, and a bag, containing the money stated, and gave them to my wife, who took them into the bar parlour—I turned the parties out of the house who made the disturbance, and then returned, and sat down with the prisoner and his brother—they left between one and two o'clock—there had been no
body in the bar but them and my wife—the prisoner sat by the side of the drawers—nobody could go to them without his seeing them—shortly after they were gone the bag of money was missing from the drawer—my watch and ring were there—among the half-sovereigns I lost there was one which I had rubbed on the rim, and I should know it among a hundred—I have since seen one produced by the constable, and am confident it is the same—I selected it from nine others at the office.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had the prisoner's brother lodged

in your house before? A. Yes—the prisoner sat with his back to the drawer—nobody could go to it without removing him—I had been drink
ing that night, but not playing at cards, nor had anybody there, to my knowledge—the disturbance was about some drink at the bar—that was after one o'clock—the house was not open then, but there were people in it—I had kept the house six months—the prisoner's brother lodged with me, off and on, for two or three months—I sold the house on Saturday, and am in search of another—one Miles kept it before me—I have never been in prison for debt—I have been arrested several times, and may be again—I have no intention of going through the Insolvent Court—I was tried in the New Court—in the early part of my life I was left a man of pro
perty, unfortunately I ran through it in being too good to others—I was but a youth when I married—I got into difficulties, and in this critical situation I did what I was not aware was wrong, I pledged some things—I had written to an uncle, who is worth thousands, to relieve me—I expected a £5 note by return of post, and pawned a few things where I was lodging till my uncle sent for me—I did not know the law—I was tried, and his Lordship saw my case—the Jury recommended me to mercy, and I was sentenced to seven days' imprisonment, six of which I had already passed—I have never boasted since how I bamboozled the Jury—I have been a printer, and worked opposite St. George's Church, in the Borough—I went in search of the prisoner's brother the day after the prisoner was in custody—I went in company with one Holmes two or three days after the robbery—I did not say to Holmes that I believed the prisoner to be an honest man, and that I had only taken him into custody to find out what had become of his brother—I did not say I believed it was the brother who had robbed me, and not the prisoner—this man Holmes is a friend of the prisoner, and pleaded hard for him—I told him I did not consider the pri
soner so culpable as the other man; and further told him, all I blamed the prisoner for was (when they said his brother had taken the money) not owning that the money found on him was given him by his brother—I do not know Mrs. Ruth Fielder (looking at a woman)—I know that woman—she never asked me why I took the prisoner into custody—I did not say it was merely to obtain information of the brother, who had robbed me—I did not say the prisoner had not done it himself, for I always considered him a square man—she did not ask me what I meant by a square man, nor did I say, "An honest man, to be sure"—I swear nothing of the kind ever occurred—I never recommended a person to hire a false witness for 5s. to support a case—I know Davey in the New Cut, and I have, at the pre
sent time, an execution against him for robbing me—I have not caused him to be arrested for a pretended debt to prevent his giving evidence against me—he swindled me out of money eighteen months ago—I have never bad him taken up, on my oath—on my oath I never produced a witness for 5s. to say he was present at an assault, when he never was present—I never suborned a witness.

Prisoner. Q. How many persons are in the habit of attending your house at night? A. How can I answer that question?—sometimes twenty, sometimes thirty, and sometimes fifty—they were not sitting up stairs drink
ing—never further than the bar—I have not got a bagatelle-board there—I once had one in the house, but it was never used.

JURY. Q. We understand you to say, at half-past one o'clock in the morning the house was closed? A. Yes, it was not open, but there were men in it—the door was shut, but it was open for business—while I
keep my house quiet, there is no law to prevent me having people in it, except on Sunday.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Is this the first time you have stated about the pri
soner sitting next to the drawers, so that nobody could have got to them without his knowledge? A. It is—it slipped my memory at the time the depositions were taken, but being mentioned to me afterwards, I recol
lected it—there is no betting-club at my house, which meets after twelve o'clock—never since the house has been mine.

CHARLOTTE NOONE . I am the prosecutor's wife. I recollect the pri
soner and his brother being in the bar-parlour with my husband on the night in question—in consequence of a disturbance my husband came out, and gave me his bag of money, watch, and ring, to take care of, while he put the people out—I put the property into the drawer of the bar-parlour, and turned the key, but did not take the key out—there was nobody in the room but the prisoner and his brother—nobody else came there until the money was missed, which was about half an hour after they were gone—the prisoner sat with his back to the drawer—nobody could get to it till he moved—when I put it in he asked me if he should rise—I said, "No, lean forward if you please, and I can get at the drawer"—his brother was sitting opposite to him, very near to him—there was a light in the room—it would be utterly impossible for one of them to open the drawer and take the bag oat without the knowledge of the other—they were left alone in the bar-par
lour while I went to the bar to serve customers—my husband vat on, the other side of the bar at that time

Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever said a word before about its being utterly impossible to get to the drawer without his knowledge? A. I be
lieve I have not—the prisoner's brother had lodged some time in our house.

JAMES ANDREWS . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on Tuesday, the 26th of September—I told him the charge—he said he was very willing to go wherever I liked, he knew nothing about it—I was coming down from his house with him, and got as far as Newington-cause
way, he said he would not go further till he had something to drink—I persuaded him to go further, and again he said he would have something to drink—I said, "Well, you can stand a drain, I suppose you have. plenty of money then, as you want to drink"—he said "No, I have only 18d."we went into a public-house, searched him, and found on him three half-sovereigns, and 1l. 12s. in silver—I asked how he got it—he said he had saved it up to pay his rent—I have the money here—Mr. Noone examined it in the Inspector's room—before he examined it, he said some of the gold he could swear to—I then handed it to him, and he pointed out half a sovereign—he did not state why he could swear to it before he had looked at it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say any thing when you were examined before about his desiring to get something to drink? A. No, I did not—I took him at his own house, about six o'clock, on the day of the robbery.

JURY. Q. Was he your prisoner at the time you asked him to stand a dram, as you call it? A. No, he was not—when I went to the house it was my intention to get the brother, if I could—I was not in my uniform, and I represented myself as a friend of his brother's—he said he had left his brother half an hour ago in the Borough—I asked him to take me to where he was, and we had agreed to go together, and nearly at every house we came to he wished to have something, and at Newington-causeway he said what I have stated—we only had a glass of spruce—I could not

persuade him to go further with me, till I told him the nature of the charge; and he then said, "Very well, I am willing to go"—I drank with him at the Two Eagles, close to his own house—Mr. Noone paid for the spruce—he was with us—it was not done for the sake of drink, but to get information.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you take any money from the house? A. Yes—one half-sovereign—I told the Magistrate I found it in the house—after he was locked up I went to his lodging, and on the first-floor mantel-shelf, under an ornament, I found a half-sovereign, and took it, and also a carpet-bag—his wife was in the house at the time—I produced that half-sove
reign before the Magistrate, and produce it here to-day.

GEORGE EDWARD NOONE
re-examined. You will find on the reverse side the edge is smoother than any other part of the half-sovereign—I had rubbed it, to prove whether it was a gilt sixpence or gold.
NOT GUILTY .

2441.
WILLIAM FRIEDLANDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of July, 3 watches, value 9l., the goods of
Bernard Lawley.

BERNARD LAWLEY . I am a watch manufacturer, and live in High-street, Borough. On the 26th of last July I went to the prisoner's counting-house, No. 24, Lime-street—he said he wanted some flat silver watches, to show to a friend of his in Liverpool, to see if they would suit the American market—I said I had not got any ready to send out for samples, but he should have some next Saturday—I could not get them ready then—the prisoner called on me on the Monday following—I said I could not get the watches ready, and I bad sent him a note to that effect—he said he had not received it—he then said, "Let me see the watches"—I did so, and he said, "I will take them as they are"—they were not in a fit state to send out for samples, and I told him so—he said his friend was a dealer in watches, and was a judge, and, of course, he did not expect new watches to look like those which I only sent for samples—upon that representation I delivered him three watches—he asked me to let him have them for eight or ten days—I said he might have them fourteen days, and then I was to have them back—I considered I had only lent them to him as samples, for fourteen days—they were to come back if approved, to make some of the same sort by—they were not in a state to be sold, neither as samples or otherwise—they required cleaning up—the silver dials wanted cleaning—they were not in a fit state even for samples, but he pressed so hard on me—he said if they suited, he would give me an order for fifteen or twenty dozen—I said they were to be returned in four
teen days, to a day—I particularly stated that—three of them were worth 15l.—finding they did not come back, about three weeks after, I went to the prisoner's counting house, and asked him if the watches had come back, and whether they suited—he said they had not come back, but they would be back in a few days, but they did not answer, they were too dear—he read a part of a letter to me in the German language, and it appeared to me to be his own hand-writing; it was written on another letter—it was never intended that the prisoner or his friend should become the purchaser of these particular watches—they were to be returned at all events, whether approved of or not as a pattern to make others by, if I got the order—he only said, "I want these watches as samples for my friend, I have not any interest in them "—these arc two of the watches—(looking at them)—the third has not been found.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you make the watches your
self? A. No, but I employed people to make them—I keep watches in my shop for sale—these three watches were hanging in my window—I should not have sold them as they were—I would have sold them to a watch-maker, but not without cleaning and examining them—I have never applied for the money for them—I did not ask the prisoner if the watches would suit—I asked him if they had come back.

Q. Have you given nobody an account, "Three silver watches, 11l. 15s.?" A. There was one of the prisoner's party who pressed on me, saying, "How much loss have you sustained by Friedlander? "—I asked his name—he refused to give it me, and I said I had nothing to say to him—he then said, "You can tell me the amount, that is nothing"—I said, "I will tell you the amount he swindled me out of," and I have a person here who heard me say so—I did not tell the person that the prisoner owed me 27l., and that I had a claim on him for three clocks, which he had to deliver to another person—the person told me to put down the amount, and I did so.

COURT. Q. You say you never were asked to sell, nor agreed to sell these particular watches, but they were to come back again? A. Yes—I would not have sold them in the state they were in, except to a watch maker who understood them.

JOHN ELLIOT . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Kingsland-road. I haw a watch which was pawned by the prisoner, on the 1st of August, for 2l., 10s. in the name of John Delaspie, No. 10, Kingsland-road—I am quite sure It was the prisoner—I know him well.

GEORGE ATTENBOROUGH . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Crown-street, Finsbury-square. I have a silver watch which was pawned by the prisoner on the 1st of August, for 2l., in the name of John Delaspie, Charles-street.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know him before? A. Yes, and have taken in goods of him before.

MR. PAYNE to BERNARD LAWLEY. Q. Did you ever sell the prisoner a watch on credit? A. I sold him one for which he gave me a forged bill—he was tried on that and acquitted, because I could not bring the present evidence.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2442.
HANNAH WELLS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of October, 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 pair of socks, value 6d.; the goods of
George Jermyn, her master.

GEORGE JERMYN . I live at Camberwell. The prisoner was about a month in my service—we keep two servants—I spent the evening out on the 6th of October, leaving Miss Smith at home—I returned about twelve o'clock, and Miss Smith gave me information—I was retiring to bed, and observing the prisoner's bed-room door open, I requested Miss Smith to go into her room—she found her up, though she had been sent to bed a very long time, and I requested to know what she had done with the two hand
kerchiefs that were missing—she said she had put them under the bed in Miss Smith's room—when she went to Miss Smith's room, they were not there—I insisted upon having the handkerchiefs found—she said she supposed they were in the kitchen—I followed her there—she looked about—they were not found there—I followed her into her bed-room

—she took her keys from the basket, and unlocked the box, and took out the handkerchiefs—she turned some more of her clothes out—there was nothing more found belonging to me—she said, "There are your handkerchiefs, God knows I have no need of gentlemen's handkerchiefs"—I desired her to walk into the parlour—she said she hoped I would not notice so trivial an affair—I then called for the officer, who went with me into her bed-room—I was there—I requested Miss Smith to look over her things, and the officer found a pair of socks, which are my property—both these handkerchiefs were found in the box—they are both mine.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. This was very late? A. Yes—she first stated she did not know how the socks came there—after that she said she meant to take them down to wash—she said she had wiped out the washhand basin with them.
ALFRED DRAPER RYCROFT (police-constable P 238) I was sent for and went into her room—the box was open before I went up—I found one pair of socks—she said nothing about them.
NOT GUILTY .

2443.
HANNAH WELLS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of June, 1 spoon, value 2s. 6d.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 ring, value 6d.; 1 medal, value 1d.; 1 pair of scales and case, value 1s.; 2 marbles, value 6d.; 1 slipper, value 3d.; 3 towels, value 3s.; 1 d'oiley, value 16d.; 1 shift, value 5s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 tin box, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pincushion, value 6d.; 3/4 of a yard of ribbon, value 6d.; and 1 pillow case, value 1s.; the goods of
Benjamin Fuller Hopkins, her master.

BENJAMIN FULLER HOPKINS . I live in Lambeth. The prisoner was a servant of mine—she came about April, and continued till June—my wife gave her warning, and she left—we did not miss this property at the moment—but shortly after she left us a policeman called, stating that seve
ral articles were found in the prisoner's box.

ALFRED DRAPER RYCROFT . I apprehended the prisoner at Mr. Jer
myn's house on the 7th of October—I saw the silver spoon found—and the other property was in her box—I did not ask her how she came by it—I found out the prosecutor from information from Mr. Jermyn.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did not she request you to keep the box unlocked as it was? A. Yes—I had it unlocked—Mr. Jermyn proposed that it should be locked again—and she said, "No."

BENJAMIN FULLER HOPKINS
re-examined. This is my spoon—I have looked at all this property—it is mine.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you miss this spoon? A. Long be
fore the policeman came—I had a good character with her—as far as I knew she deserved a good character—when she left we gave her a good character—my initials are on the handkerchief—I could not speak positively to certain dresses that were found in her box, but I can to the spoon and handkerchief—nothing is here that was not before the Magistrate—we had not then inspected her boxes—there were some handkerchiefs I could not swear to, because the corners had been cut off—but I can to these.
MRS. HOPKINS. These are my property.
(James Payne, of Kingston-terrace, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

2444.
JOSIAH SPURDEN FREEMAN was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October, 1 ¼ yards of woollen cloth, value 16s.; 2 3/4 yards of woollen cloth called Harrington, value 1l. 6s. 1d.; 2 5/8 yards of cloth called Tweed, value 7s. 10d.; 1 yard of satin, value 10s.; 1 1/2 yards of silk, called serge, value 6s.; and 2 yards 3-6ths of kerseymere, value 15s. 5d.; the goods of
William Bennett, the elder, and
William Bennett, the younger; and
ROBERT RYDER
as an accessary before the fact
NOT GUILTY .

2445.
GEORGE BAILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of October, 5 chairs, value 3l.; 1 box, value 1s.; I looking-glass and frame, value 3l.; and 1 knife, value 2s.; the goods of
Jane Sickler Tonkin.

JANE SICKLER TONKIN . I am the daughter of an officer in the Navy I came into the possession of property from my father and my uncle—the prisoner was left my trustee—I cannot recollect when my father died—it may be ten years since—I am not married—I have had a child, and the prisoner is the father of it—I went abroad with him last year, in the begin
ning of September—I had been living before that at No. 10, Wellington-terrace, Lambeth—I occupied the second floor—my landlord's name was William Cottle—all the furniture that was there was my own—the pri
soner purchased it for me with my own money—I had two houses, of which he received the rents, which amounted together to 41l. a-year—I was living with him—my mother was alive when my father died—she has now been dead two years—she considered that I was the prisoner's wife—we got a false certificate to show her, to persuade her we were married—I think that is five years ago—I did not live with him entirely till we went abroad—he resided in Devonshire chiefly, but was occasionally at my apartments—he was at that time a conveyancer in Devonshire—all the furniture was mine—I desired my landlord to let no one remove it till I returned—the prisoner remained abroad with me about a fortnight—he then left me in Paris, as his own affairs he said required his attendance in England—I had left the key of my apartment in the door, and desired the landlord and his wife to take possession of it—I had no key of the apart
ment—I had received 180l. of my own, which the prisoner took from me about a fortnight before he left me—I arrived here on the 3rd of February—I went to my lodgings, and found a great part of my property was gone—I never authorised the prisoner or any other person to take an article of it—I have since seen part of the articles which I left, in a house at Poplar that he was occupying, with his wife and family, but which was taken in his sister's name—I knew he was a married man almost as soon as I knew him—I found these articles about three weeks ago.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. May I ask how old you are? A. About 32—I was born in 1802—I have been living about seven years with the prisoner—it was two years after I had been living with the prisoner that I joined him in the false certificate—I knew he had a wife at the time—my mother had an annuity of twenty-five pounds a year, which ceased at her death—I was living in the same house with her and the pri
soner—I have always worked with my needle, by which I get about 12s. a week—I was paying 16l. a year rent—the prisoner was there occasion
ally—he did not supply means for our mutual subsistence—I have fre
quently been without food—I swear he never did contribute to my sup
port

—when I had him taken up I was taken in out of charity by the pri
soner's wife—I was waiting there till I could find a house—I had been living with her about five days, I think—I first knew of the loss of these chairs when I returned from Paris in February, but I could not have had the prisoner taken before, as I was not in a fit state to contend with him—I have not seen him since the beginning of April—I cannot say I did not see him—he came to my apartment—I did not cohabit with him between February and April—that I swear—I believe I dined with him once, that was after I knew of the loss—I saw him four or five times—not more—four of these chairs were in the lodging in which 1 was with Mrs. Bailey—I was there on charity—I did not know the prisoner had the key of my room—I told him I left it in care of the landlord—I am not living with his wife now—I left her the day the chairs were taken, which was the day after he was given in charge—I have not been living with her for the last ten days.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You came home in February? A. Yes—I was in the eighth month of pregnancy, and had no means of finding necessa
ries for my child—I was delivered on the 12th of April—he knew the state I was in—he had sold my houses before this—all the money I re
ceived from him was 180l., just before I left England, and that he took from me—he never supplied me with any means of living except what arose from the proceeds of my own property—when I came to England I did not know where to find him—I sent a letter to him immediately on my return, directed to Mr. Deacon, to deliver to him—Mr. Deacon is a clerk to Mr. Robinson, in whose employ he had been as clerk—I discovered the loss of my property in February—about three weeks ago he was taken in France—I found the other part of the property at his nephew's, in Monta
gue-mews—I did not authorise him to take any of the property I charge him with stealing—from the time of my connexion with him he has not supplied me with so much as the amount of the proceeds of my own property—I was confined at No, 16, Wellington-terrace—he called the doctor and nurse, and I never saw him again till I gave him into custody.

WILLIAM COTTLE . I am landlord of the house in Wellington-terrace where the prosecutrix now lives. (I have kept her there out of charity)—he prisoner used to come to her once in six months sometimes, and very likely has been away, twelve months—I remember her leaving to go to France—she left some furniture, and before she left, charged me to let no one have it without her orders, and in her presence—some time after, the prisoner came in with the key, as usual, and bolted up stairs with authority—he was there all night, and he took away the furniture constantly—there not a time that he went without some—we went up stairs to secure the property, and found the key was gone and the door locked, and he came with the key—when the prosecutrix left she said, "I have left the key in the door"—we went up, and it was gone, and he was off to Paris—it was from his producing the key that we supposed he had authority to take the things—when I found he had taken many things, and was about to take more, I prevented him—when the prosecutrix returned in February she came to my house in a most distressing situation—she was delivered there, and there she lay, and had no means to support the child—she was obliged to sell her things to pay her passage over—she was able to get up about three months after her confinement—when she went into the room she made a complaint to me of the loss of her property.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has she been living in your house?

A. I suppose about three years and a half—she represented herself to me as a married woman—I questioned her upon it—there is no one living in my house who was there then—I know the prisoner's wife—she has not been living in my house—when we found her out at Poplar, she had compassion to provide for the prosecutrix and the infant at Poplar, but the prosecu
trix continued to sleep in my house—the wife has been into my house, to and fro, anxious to see how the child was—I rather think she was at my house last Saturday—the prisoner quite deserted the prosecutrix—I think he has visited her once or twice—not a dozen times—I do not think he has ever dined there—not to my knowledge—she never received any of her rents all the time they were living together—I advanced 5l. to help to pay the medical man—the prisoner had sent for him.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know whether, before she went to Paris, any sum of money was received on her account? A. Yes, I heard so from herself—she did not leave my house for two or three days together—not to pass a night out—she was relieved by the prisoner's wife—she went three times, and I believe the third time she met with the wife.

JOHN NESBITT . I am an officer of Hatton-garden. On the 16th of October went to No. 9, Montague-mews North—I had a search-war
rant—I found George Bailey living there—I found a pier chimney-glass and a mahogany arm-chair there—they were identified by the prosecutrix as her property—I took them and took Bailey, who is the prisoner's nephew—he gave me an account of how he came possessed of them—the prisoner at the bar was in custody—I searched the nephew, and found on him three £20 Bank of England notes—he gave me an account of how he got them—I found part of a chest of plate—he gave me an account of how he became possessed of that.

WILLIAM COTTLE
re-examined. Among other things the prisoner took away a pier glass, worth 5l.—he took away an arm-chair, which any broker would give 2l. for, and the four chairs were worth 2l.—we ques
tioned him about them—he said he was going to have them new seated.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

ELIZA TALBOT . I am a widow, and live in Adam-street East, Manchester-square. I know the prisoner—I am no relation of his—I have seen the four chairs in the custody of the officer—I bought them in Chancery-lane, at Mr. Standage's sale-rooms, in October, 1835—they were brought to my house, in Adam-street—I bought them at the prisoner's request—I never demanded the money for them—he was sent to the Fleet prison—I saw him there—the chairs went to the Fleet—I saw them at Lisson-grove and Poplar.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What business do you carry on? A. A milliner and dress-maker—these chairs were never in Wellington-terrace, that I know of—I never saw them there—I was never there myself—I did not know he had a child by the prosecutrix, nor that he was living with her—he has been at Adam-street a long time, on and off—I became acquainted with him by his coming to lodge with me—I knew his sister previously—she lodged with me—I knew he was a marred man—he never left his wife, only as business required—I have been at Poplar—his sister lived there—no one else—I never saw his wife there—he requested the chairs to be bought for a counting-house, as he was about going into business—I never asked him for the money—I intended to receive it—I do not occupy the whole house in Adam-street—it is let out in apartments—I live with my mother there—I considered the money quite as safe with him as with me—I took charge of the chairs while he was in the Fleet—he went there

in January or December—I never knew of his being trustee to the prose
cutrix—I never heard of such a person—I saw the chairs in the Fleet a clay or two before he left—that was in February, 1830—he came from there to my house—he paid the rent regularly—he did not seem to want money particularly—I do not keep a shop—I have got my name, as milliner and dress-maker, over my door—I have never been in any diffi
culty in point of money matters in my life—I cannot tell you what my in
come is—I have nothing but what I work for—I paid, I think, 1l. 12s. for the chairs—I have not the bill of sale—I destroyed it a few days ago—I did not hear that I was to be called as a witness till Sunday—the pri
soner did not tell me he took the chairs to Wellington-terrace—I paid for no glass for him—I bought a bedstead for his sister—I cannot tell how much I paid on that occasion—I never made any present to him—my house consists of ten rooms—I occupy two rooms on the first floor, and the kitchen—my family consists of my mother, myself and daughter, and niece, who is an apprentice.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. His sister was living with you? A. They had two different rooms.
JANE BAILEY . I am the prisoner's sister. I was living at Adam-street with him.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What were you doing? A. Nothing; I was not very well—I have been living with him at Boulogne—I went there about three weeks ago—I remember an inquiry about the pier glass and chairs, about a week before we went, and then we went—I have no occasion to do any thing for my living—I have an income—I went for a trip, and the prisoner went to place his daughter at school there—I knew Miss Tonkin some years ago—I heard something about the prisoner being her trustee—I did not hear it from himself—if I heard it from any body, it was from her—it may be four or five, or five or six years ago—I did not hear he had her property—I heard she had a child, but I did not know it was by him—I saw the child when she came to see me a month ago—she said he had taken away a chair and glass, and went to Boulogne.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What property have you? A. 100l. a year.

WILLIAM MILLS . I live in Drury-lane, and am a broker. I had this arm chair in my possession—the prisoner ordered it from me in the name of Burton, and I sent it to Wellington-terrace, on Saturday, April 23, 1836—in October, 1836, I sent to the same place for four chairs to be repaired—I repaired them—they are the four chairs I have seen out of Court.

GEORGE BAILEY . I am the prisoner's nephew. In 1829, I remember the prisoner giving the prosecutrix a cheque for 75l. at Stonehouse, in De
vonshire—I know of his giving her other sums, but I cannot say to what amount—I have put letters for him into the post-office with enclosures—I have seen the Bank notes cut and put in.
COURT. Q. When was that? A. I cannot say the date, but it was ten years ago.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Last June do you know that the prisoner sent her any money? A. I know there was money sent about nine years ago, and 2l. last September.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know the person behind Mr. Phillips? A. Yes; I was served with a subpoena to come here—he told me not to attend when the officer came; and afterwards when the solicitor's clerk came, he said I must go—I bought the property found at my house of the prisoner—I keep a livery-stable in Montague-mews, and am partner with a man

of the name of Gullett—before that I was a sadler at Crediton, Devon
shire—I have kept livery-stables about three months—I had 1000l. left me by my uncle—I bought 75l. worth of property—when I got this glass and chairs, I paid him 48l. 10s., and gave him a bill for the remainder on the 1st of September—it was all for furniture—when the officer came and found the property, and asked how I came by it, I said my uncle had left it with me for safety, merely to prevent his taking me into custody—he told me I was not bound to say any thing that would criminate myself—I did not then say he had brought them to my house—I said I bought them—he asked me how I became possessed of a box of plate?—I did not tell him my uncle had directed me to go to a hotel where I should get it—I went to a hotel to get it—I do not know that I told the officer that my uncle told me to keep it till he had determined what to do with it, but he did so—he searched me—he did not find in my pocket any £20 of Bank of England notes—he searched me at the station-house, and found 60l. sealed up in a letter, and the officer broke it open—I got it from the pri
soner—he told me I was to keep it till I had directions to deliver it to the party it was directed to—I did not tell the officer the date on which he gave it me—I did not say I had been acting very wrong—I did not say I wished I had never seen the money—on my way to Bow-street I said I had sold a great deal of property by the desire of my uncle—articles of furniture—I did not tell the officer I was sorry I had done it—I asked him whether he thought I should be remanded.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you afraid they would have remanded you? A.I was rather—my uncle lived with his sister at Poplar at the time I sold the furniture—it was for that house that I sold it—it was the officer took the 60l. from me—this is the letter in which the three £20 notes were—I have kept it safe ever since—the letter is addressed to R. God
son, Esq.
(Thomas Lord, a solicitor, living in Northumberland-street; and—Wayte, an attorney's clerk, of Foley-street, Portland-place, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2446.
CHARLES WELLER was indicted
for embezzlement.

HENRY GODFREY . I am the son of David Godfrey, a butcher, at Peck
ham. The prisoner was his apprentice about twelve months—it was his duty to receive money on account of my father—it should be given to my father or me the same day.

SOPHIA COLLINS . I am servant to Mr. Hardcastle. I paid the pri
soner 6s. 8d. about twelve o'clock on the 9th of October, for a leg of mutton—he gave me a little ticket, but we did not keep it
Prisoner. It was the 2nd of October. Witness. It was Monday the 9th, I believe.

HENRY GODFREY
re-examined. The prisoner never paid us this money—my father was not at home—one day the prisoner came in for a shoulder of mutton for Mr. Hardcastle, and two chops with it—I did not like the look of it, and when the bill went in they said they had paid it—I spoke to the prisoner about it—he said he had had the money, and was sorry for it.

GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Two Days.

2447.
JOHN LANGDON was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of October, 1 key, value 1d.; 7 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the goods and mo
nies of
Thomas Puddicombe, his master.

THOMAS PUDDICOMBE . I am in the newspaper business, and live in Bridge-house-place, Newington. The prisoner used to carry out news
papers for me—last Wednesday evening I was in the shop, and was called to the parlour, and while I was there I heard a noise—I went out, and he had been at the till, and the till dropped down—it was inside the counter—he was in the shop, but on the other side, when I went away—I said, "John, have you been at my till? "—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Have you ever been there before? "—he said, "Yes, five times"—I asked what he had taken out then—he pulled out 7s. 6d. from his pocket, and said that was it—he had been with me a year and a half, and I had a good opinion of him.

EDMUND M'DONNELL . I am a policeman. I found the 7s. 6d. on the prisoner, and a purse containing 16s. 6d., also a key which locks and un
locks the till.
(Mr. Price gave him a good character, and promised to take him.)

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Whipped and discharged.

2448.
JAMES COCKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Octo
ber, 2 sovereigns, 15 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the monies of
Robert Ray
ner, his master.

ROBERT RAYNER . I am a baker. The prisoner was my journeyman—there was a customer of the name of Hook—on the 9th of October he went and delivered some bread, and the bill as I thought—he came back and said the lady would settle the bill if I would give him the change of a £5 note—I gave him 2l. 15s. 6d.—he never returned to me—I took him on the 20th of October.

THOMAS SHERIFF . I am a policeman. On the 10th I received inform
ation that the prisoner had absconded, taking 2l. 15s. 6d. and some other money—I received information that he had gone to Boulogne—on the 20th I found him in Southwark—he said he had received the money of his master, and likewise for the bill.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months; Two Months Solitary.

2449.
GEORGE POWELL was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. CHAMBERS and SHEA conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGIANA MURRELL . I am in the service of Eliza Rogan, a grocer, at Tooting Graveny. On the 9th of October, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came for a pennyworth of cheese—he laid a shilling on the counter—I took it up, and thought it looked rather bad—I gave him a sixpence and 5d. in half-pence—I laid the shilling in one cor
ner of the till—there was no other money there, I am sure—in a little time the policeman came in and I gave him the same shilling—no one had been to the till during the interval—I marked it before I gave it him—I am sure the prisoner is the man—I never had the slightest doubt about it.
KINGSTON MARK (police-constable V 178.) I received the shilling from Georgiana Murrell.
CAROLINE CLIFF DAVIS . I am the daughter of Richard James Thomas Davis, who keeps the Rising Sun inn, at Tooting. On Monday, the 9th of

October, between five and six in the afternoon, the prisoner came in, and asked for a pennyworth of peppermint—he put down a shilling—I gave him the peppermint, he drank it—I took up the shilling, and said it was very black—I gave it my mother—she looked at it, and said it was a dreadful bad one—she gave it me back, and I gave it to the prisoner—he I said, "Is it a bad one?" and bent it on the counter—he gave me a good shilling—I gave him change, and he went away—I saw no more of him till he was in custody.

RICHARD JAMES THOMPSON DAVIS . I was at the bar on that day, and heard the prisoner call for the peppermint—I looked at the shilling, and saw it was bad—my wife asked him where he took it—he said he took it at Croydon, with some other silver, he hardly knew where—after he left I followed him, and gave information to Alfred Smith to inform the police—I still followed him—I went to the station-house, and was there when he was searched—he said he had thrown the shilling away.
Prisoner. Q. Did you follow me out of the public-house? A. Yes—I did not keep my eye upon you long.

ANN BRIDGE . I am the daughter of Mr. Bridge, a beer-seller. On the 9th of October the prisoner came to our house, between five and six o'clock, and asked for half a pint of beer—I served him—he paid me a bad shilling—I examined it at the time and found it bad, by biting it—I re
fused it—he gave me 1d. and went off.
Prisoner. I was never in your shop. Witness, Yes—he had the same handkerchief and shirt as he has now on.

SARAH BLAKE . I live in Tooting Graveny, my husband is a baker. The prisoner came to my shop, on the 9th of October, at ten minutes before six o'clock—he bought a penny-loaf, and put a shilling into my hand—I rang it on the counter, and laid it in the till, on a five-shilling piece, not liking the appearance of it—there were other shillings, but I laid this separate—I gave him a sixpence and 5d.—I then saw Alfred Smith, and he said something to me—I gave him the shilling—he looked at it between the lights, and could not discern whether it was bad or not—I then bit it, and called my husband—he bent it, and pursued the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Did you put it into the till? A. Yes, I did not throw it in—I laid it on a five-shilling-pieces—I took it out when Alfred Smith came to the door.

THOMAS JOHN PAGE (police-constable V. 77.) On the afternoon of the 9th of October I saw the prisoner, and Mr. Blake, and Smith, in High-street, Tooting Graveny—Mr. Blake gave me a shilling, and said the pri
soner had been passing it to his wife—he gave him in charge—I searched him—he put his hand into his pocket, while I put my hand into another, he took something out and put into his mouth—I caught him by the throat, and held him between five and ten minutes, to prevent his swal
lowing it—Smith put his fingers into his mouth, and said he could feel something in the shape of a coin, but it was not got out—I then found he had something in his hand—I forced it out, and it was good money—I found on him one shilling and seven good sixpences, and 2d. in copper, and this box of composition.
Prisoner. I never put any thing into my mouth—if I had he could have pulled it out. Witness. He bit too hard—he bit one's fingers.

ALFRED SMITH . I was watching the prisoner, and saw him go to Mrs. Blake—I made inquiry there, and Mrs. Blake showed me a shilling—I went with Mr. Blake with that shilling, and found the prisoner—at the

time the witness had him he put something into his mouth—that induced me to put my fingers in—I could feel something apparently like a coin—his teeth were too active to let me get it out—he bit very sharply—I did not observe him swallow any thing.
RICHARD BLAKE . I received a shilling from my wife—I gave the same to the policeman.
Prisoner. The shilling had been passed into two or three hands, and it might have been changed—it was not marked till it was got out of the till
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

2450.
GEORGE NEWMAN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ELIZA PORLETT . I am the wife of John Porlett, a baker, living in Mint-street, Southwark. About half-past ten o'clock at night on the 22nd of September, the prisoner came for 1d. worth of bread—I served him—he gave me a bad shilling—I gave him the change, and then saw it was bad—I told him so—he said it was not a bad one—I told him it was—he contradicted me several times—he said he was not destitute of a shilling—he took up the change, and was going to put it into his pocket—I told him not to put my change into his pocket; I could not afford to give him good money for bad—he then gave me another shilling—I said that was bad—he said it was not; that I did not know good money from bad—I said, "Give me back my change?"—he would not—I told him to go, or I would charge him with the police—he said he would not; I might do as I thought proper—there was no policeman—I beckoned to a neighbour out of the window, and was going to send him, but some other person fetched the policeman.

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS (police-constable M 47.) I went to the shop—Mrs. Porlett gave me two shillings—I took the prisoner, and found on him a sixpence and 5d. in copper—he said, "It serves me right, if I am hanged; I had a chance to get away, and would not take it."
MR. FIELD. These are both counterfeit—I cannot say they are from the same mould.
(The prisoner pleaded poverty.)

GUILTY . Aged 65.—
Confined One Year.

2451.
CHARLES COX was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ANN HOAD . I am the wife of John Hoad, of Garden-row, London-road, a baker. About nine o'clock, on the 28th of September, the prisoner came for a penny loaf, and gave me a shilling—I gave him a sixpence, and 5d. in halfpence—I had emptied the till just before—there was neither six-pence nor shilling in it—I put his shilling into the till, and he left—I then examined the shilling, took it out, and bit it—I found it bad, and put it again into the till, with a piece of paper round it, and called the policeman—he marked it, and told me to take care of it—soon after a police
man named Brooks and another came in—I gave the shilling to Brooks—I am quite certain it was the one the prisoner gave me—on the following evening, the 29th, I saw the prisoner in my shop again—I told him to wait a minute, and I would servo him—he had a shilling in his hand, and wanted a penny loaf—I called my husband—he came—the prisoner put the
shilling into his mouth—my husband held the prisoner—I went to the door, and called the policeman, who took him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time did he come on the 28th? A. About nine o'clock in the evening—we had the gas lighted—I went out directly, and saw the policeman mark the shilling—he came at much the same time on the 29th.
JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I recollect going into the shop on the 28th—I received a shilling from Mr. Hoad—this is it

SARAH ANN KNIGHT . I live in Garden-row. On the 28th of Sep
tember, about nine o'clock in the evening, I was playing at hoop in Garden row—the prisoner came and asked me to go and get a pennyworth of apples—he told me to go up the street—there is a green-grocer's there—he gave me a shilling, and said he would give me a halfpenny if I would make baste, and he would walk up and down while I went with it—Mrs. Beaumont keeps that shop—I gave the shilling to her—I had no other—in consequence of something Mrs. Beaumont said, I went after the prisoner, and saw him standing still by the court—I afterwards saw him at the top of the street—I looked at him, and he ran away—he did not wait for the change or the apples—I am sure he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. No, not till he gave me the shilling—he was not far off when I saw him at the end of the street—about a week after I saw him before the Magistrate the policeman asked whether I saw anybody like him—I said, "Yes, I think that is him."

MR. PAYNE to ANN HOAD. Q. Did you see the man put the shilling into his mouth? A. Yes—I was behind the counter—my husband was just coming through the passage—I said, "Wait a bit," and then I called my husband—when he saw my husband coming I saw him put it into his mouth—the parlour window is at the end of the shop—I tapped there for my husband—the policeman found a good shilling on him.

ALICE ANN BEAUMONT . I recollect Sarah Ann Knight coming to me on the evening of the 28th of September, at nine o'clock—she gave me a shilling—I gave it to my husband—he gave it me again, and I gave it to Robett Penning.

HARMSTON BEAUMONT . I am the husband of Alice Ann Beaumont. On the 28th of September I was sitting in a room adjoining my shop—my wife gave me a shilling—I went down the street—I bent the shilling first, and gave it to my wife again—I am sure it was the shilling she gave me—I saw her give it to Penning.
ROBERT PENNING . Mrs. Beaumont gave me a shilling on the 28th of September—I kept it about half an hour—I gave it to Goff the officer—I marked it at the time
Cross-examined. Q. Did any other boy have it? A. No—we did not play with it—we were going to play.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 31) On the 28th of Sep
tember I went to the house where Penning lived—he gave me this shilling—he marked it before he gave it me

CHARLES HITCHES (police-constable L 154.) I went to Mrs. Hoad's on the 28th of September—in consequence of that I looked after the prisoner—on the following evening I was called into the shop, and found the prisoner there—I observed his mouth, and seized him by the throat—I could not see that he had any thing in his mouth, but he appeared very red in

the face, and to have tears in his eyes, as if he had been swallowing some
thing—I found on him a good shilling.
JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit, and both from the same mould

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

2452.
ROBERT HAYNES was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of July, 6 1 1/2 yards of lawn, value 10s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas. Brooks.

THOMAS BROOKS . I live in High-street, Borough. The prisoner was engaged as porter in my house, by my traveller, about the beginning of June—on the 20th of June I purchased six pieces of lawn at Messrs. Lainson's, in Bread-street—they were deposited in the warehouse—I repeatedly missed goods, and on the 17th of July this one was pawned at a pawn
broker's in the New Cut, it is mine—the selling mark has been rubbed out with india-rubber, but they have left the other mark.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I believe you had other servants? A. Yes, a great many—I was here last session against the same boy, and I was positive about the other article—the mark on this is "21d. a yard, and my private mark, in my writing—the moment I saw it at the pawn
