broker's I looked for the mark, and they had attempted to deface it—I had a person named Patrick in my employ—nearly the whole of the persons who were in my service then are there now—I have discharged two or three, I think—I have perhaps twenty persons—my private mark is one that no one else has in the trade—it is one of my own making—the lawn in the warehouse was folded up in three pieces of ornamental paper—I think blue paper twice round the ends, and once in the middle—the prisoner was the only person I suspected of this, and till I received informa
tion I had not the slightest suspicion even of him—the prisoner was in my service in June, not before—I had the information from two boys, about the middle of August—he had left me in July, but I took him back again—I had no bad opinion of him—there are six yards of this—here is my own private mark on it, which refers to the cost price, and the 52 the average mark—I had two marks on it, but one has been rubbed out—I remember the result of the trial last Sessions perfectly well—when a woman shook her fist at me, I said, when I could find the boy Goodman he should hear more about it—I said I should have him up here again—I did not say if it would cost me a thousand pounds I would.
COURT. Q. What was he tried here before for? A. For stealing a shawl, I think.

JAMES JENNINGS . I am a policeman. Last Tuesday afternoon, at half past four o'clock, I saw the prisoner coming past Newington gate—I had had information from Mr. Brooks that he wished to take him again—I took him—he said, "What is this upon—is it for Mr. Brooks?"—I said, "I believe it is"—he said, "I do not care about that—I have been tried and acquitted about that"—I said, "Do you know that Goodman is at home?"—he said, "There is nobody can hurt me but the boy Goodman"—I said, "You must have had some transactions with him"—he said, "That is to myself."
Cross-examined. Q. What was he doing? A. Dragging a truck—I do not believe he follows any particular occupation—I cannot say that he is a hard working boy.
WILLIAM HENRY GOODMAN . I work with my father—he takes in mending and making—I know the prisoner—I used to lodge at his

mother's—I remember meeting him some time in July—he was carrying a parcel pretty nearly a 1/2cwt.—I went with him to the place and helped him to carry the parcel—in coming back he pulled out a small parcel from his pocket and said, "Will you be so good as to pawn this for me, for Mr. Patrick, as Mr. Patrick has got a summons out against him, and be want this money to pay it"—he gave me 6d. and I pawned it in the New Cut opposite Rowland Hill's Chapel—I do not know the name of the shop but it was the master who took it—I pawned it for 5s.—it was a piece of lawn, he told me—I gave him the 5s.—he gave me 6d.

Cross-examined. Q. You have come here to speak the truth? A. Yes—I met him first coming from Mr. Brooks's shop with a parcel—he went to his house and I was at home, and then we went away together—I met him first by the Dover-road, near St. George's Church—I know Surrey-square—that is where I went with the prisoner—it may be more than half a mile from the Borough end of the Dover-road—the first time I met him in the Dover-road he had a heavy weight with him—I went with him to the back of Surrey-square—I did not meet him in the square—he left the parcel at the house—the gentleman was not at home—the lady took it in, and she said there was nobody at home—I had left my work in Suffolk-street then—it was about the 15th of September, I think—I cannot tell—I cannot read—I think it was some time about the election—I never told anybody another day on which I pawned this—it was the day I met him—I think it was July—it was either September or July—he told me to pledge it in the name of John Clark, No. 9, somewhere near Suffolk-street—I think I told the pawnbroker High-street—I got 5s.—it was a false name and address—I have been sorry since I did it—I have been working lately with my father as a shoemaker, since last Saturday—I went down before that to St. Alban's for a fortnight—I am not known there—before that I was lodg
ing at the prisoner's mother's, working up Suffolk-street at shoemaking—I was about a month there—I had always been with my father before that—I had been to work at different places, and went home to my father—I have worked next door to my father, No. 3, Newington-grove—I have been in a good many situations in Surrey—I know what an oath is—I have worked in Horsemonger-lane jail, because one day I was ill and was very hungry, there was a pair of gaiters, and I took them and got 2d. to buy some victuals—I was in Horsemonger-lane jail four days and had a flogging.
JOSEPH BURTON . I took in the lawn in the name of" John Clark," on the 17th of July—I cannot say who pawned it—it was a piece of lawn for 5s.—it was a boy or a man.
Cross-examined. Q. You asked him the usual questions? A. Yes—he said it was for Mr. Clark, who had sent him—he did not say he was sent by his mother, or we should have put it down.

THOMAS BROOKS
re-examined. The prisoner was porter to my traveller, and was often left alone in the warehouse where this was.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months; One Month Solitary.

2453.
MARY COOPER and
MARY ANN COOPER were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of October, 2 veils, value 10s.; 2 aprons, value 3s.; 1 frock, value 1s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; 1 pelerine, value 3s.; 5 pairs of stockings, value 1s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 8s.; 3 yards of rib
bon, value 6d.; 2 towels, value 53; and 2 printed books, value 2s.; the goods of
Harriet Bainbridge.

ELIZABETH BAINBRIDGE . I am the daughter of Mrs. Harriet Bain
bridge, who resides at Clapham-rise. The prisoner Mary Cooper was called in to nurse my mother, and her daughter Mary Ann frequently came to our house—I have given Mary various articles—she had been four days in the house before I commenced—I gave her some shirts and socks, and several things—I cannot recollect all—I did not give her either of these articles—I never gave her the books—they are my own—I am fifteen years old, and am living with my mother—she keeps me—I never gave the prisoner this silk veil—it is my mother's—I know it by the colour—my mother has had it many years—I saw it about six weeks ago in my mother's house—this gauze veil I saw about a month ago—that is my mother's—this apron I never gave her—it is my mother's—my sister marked it—there is the mark, "H. B." on it—these three other aprons are all my mother's—I did not give her any of them.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you known her? A. About a twelvemonth ago, for a week, she had been nursing my mother—I gave her seventeen shirts—I cannot say how many pairs of socks, and a great many other things—I never gave her any aprons—these are muslin aprons—I never made any charge against her till the policeman brought her there—this is one of the three aprons with these holes darned in it—I saw it last about a fortnight ago—Mary Ann Cooper was taken into custody last Monday—I did not tell the mother there was an old clothes-bag up stairs containing a parcel of things which I did not want, and that she might have them—nothing of the kind—I never gave her any things in a clothes-bag—I gave her some carpet, which was in a press, not a bag—it was outside the door in a closet—there were old things chiefly in that closet—I have not made out a list of the things that occurred to my re
collection that I had given her—my brother made out a list of the things that were at the station-house—I have given her things on two or three occasions—she staid with my mother nearly a week the first time, twelve months ago—I gave her a great many old pieces of rag, but no body-linen—my mother is of weak intellect—she has been so about three weeks—I used to go out, from time to time, while the prisoner was in attendance—Mary Ann lived at home with her mother—some of the things that I gave away were at the bottom of the foul clothes cupboard—my mother is not able to come here—this is a huckaback towel—about half a yard long, of the value of 5s.—I do not know that it may be got for about 7d. a yard—these are the two books—one was given to me at school, and the other my brother gave me about three months ago—this ribbon is my mother's—these are the handkerchiefs—the five pairs of stockings, valued at 1s., are very old worn-out things—this handkerchief cost 10s., when it was new—it was bought about three years ago—the stockings, pillow-case, and handkerchiefs belonged to my mother, and the pelerine—it is five or six years old, and the two veils—this frock, I think, I gave her—I never forgot that—neither my brother nor I selected it as one of the articles to charge her with—I cannot tell how the frock got into the in
dictment—I gave it to the younger prisoner on the Friday before the Monday she was taken—there was only an apron that I was uncertain about—the elder prisoner lives in the same place now that she did twelve months ago—I never heard that her husband has an annuity of 50l. a

year—he is a cripple—they live in Hanscombe-crescent, Clapham—she used to have the management of the house when she came, and of the family, and Mary Ann sat up one or two nights to assist her—she was taken into custody between three and four o'clock last Monday—she had come to speak to her mother about something, and I saw her go away with a small parcel in brown paper, wrapped up in an apron—I did not take particular notice of the size—that was the only one I could see—she was dressed in a green merino frock, and a shawl, and a straw bonnet trimmed with blue—she was brought back between ten minutes and a quarter of an hour.

MR. RAWLINGS Q. DO you recollect giving the prisoner any silk stockings? A. No; they were all cotton that I gave her—I did not see the frock at Union-ball; but the frock and other articles, to the best of my knowledge, have been in the hands of the policeman ever since—I was not aware of the frock being present when I was asked if I gave these things, and said, "No"—I did not observe her take a parcel out of the house—I saw it when she came back—I did not mean to say I saw her go out with a parcel.
MR. CLARKSON Q. Where was she when she went? A. She came up stairs, went into the passage, and went away directly—she went oat of our street-door—I was in the parlour—I spoke to her in the kitchen.
COURT Q. What could induce you to give her seventeen shirts and these other things? A. She told me her husband was very ill, and had not a shirt to put on his back.

WILLIAM BAINBRIDGE I have slept at my mother's for the last fort
night—I gave none of the things to the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not tell the policeman to put that frock in the indictment, did you? A. No, I did not.

JOSEPH BIGGS (police-constable V 26.) On Monday last I received in
formation that something was going on wrong at a house in the Clapham-road—I met the prisoner Mary Ann in James-street, near her mother's house, with a parcel in her hand.—I asked her what she had got there—she said, "What do you mean?"—I said, "Where did you bring that from?"—she said her mother gave it her—I then said we would go back to Mrs. Bainbridge's, and see if it was all right—we went back to the house, saw Miss Bainbridge, and asked if she gave her these things—she said, "Yes all but the apron "—they were little muslin things—I do not know that any of those things are here—the prisoner Mary said Miss Bainbridge had given her a great many things—I then said, "If Miss Bainbridge had given a great many things, perhaps you have no objection to let Miss Bainbridge go to your house, and see what she has given you"—we went back, and found a large box—I asked for the key, and opened it and took out a great many articles which Mr. Bainbridge said were his mother's—the stockings were in that box—I then went into a front room—there was another box—I asked who it belonged to—the lodgers said to Mrs. Cooper—I asked for the key, and opened it—there were silk stockings and various things, which I took out, and Mr. Bainbridge said they were his mother's—I found these articles in the boxes, which Mary said were hers, but the lace veil was down-stairs, on the top of a bed which was turned up—I found a shirt or two, and some other little articles—there were some things in the coal-hole, but I believe they are not mentioned in the indictment—they made frequent observations that the things were all given to them.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell whether the apron that Miss Bain
bridge

selected from the property is one of the articles she said she gave her? A. She said she did not give it her—I cannot identify that apron from the rest of the things—Miss Bain bridge stated, when the bundle was produced, that she had given her all the things except the apron—there was a frock which was identified by Miss Bainbridge—she said nothing parti
cular, only that she had not given it her—I stated that at the office, and she said, "I did not give her this, or this"—she did not point out that in particular—she said she did not give her the frock.

MR. RAWLINGS. Q. You apprehended the younger prisoner with a parcel? A. Yes, with little articles of net, like cap borders—these knots I tied myself, in the apron that had the little parcel—I am positive that is the apron I took from the prisoner's hand—I saw the frock produced at Union-hall—that is the same—there was a list made out of what Miss Bainbridge said she had not given the prisoner, and what she had.

THOMAS EMERSON (police-constable V 149.) I was sent for—I assisted in apprehending the prisoner, and went to the station-house, and took part of the property—I stopped at the station-house with the prisoners—I saw the bundle—I could not swear to the apron more than any other—I went to the house, and assisted in taking part of the property to the station-house, and remained there while he went back and fetched some more.
Cross-examined. Q. You took care of the women? A. Yes; there was no other policeman—the Inspector told me he wanted assistance—they were both in the house at the time—I cannot tell all the articles.
COURT to JOSEPH BIGGS. Q. When you got to the house, and these things were pulled out, what said the prisoners? A. That they were given by the daughter.

ELIZABETH BAINBRIDGE
re-examined. I did not go to the house—I have not seen any of the property this twelvemonths—I saw this marked cambric handkerchief three weeks ago, and one of the other handkerchiefs last Sunday fortnight.
NOT GUILTY .

2454.
WILLIAM GABELL was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM NELSON . I am a publican. The prisoner was my pot-boy, and had been three weeks and three days—it was his duty to settle every night before he went to bed, which he did till the day he ab
sconded.

THOMAS MANSELL . I take beer of the prosecutor. On the 15th of Oc
tober I paid the prisoner ninepence for beer which I received that day.
WILLIAM FRICKLEY . I deal with Mr. Nelson. I paid the prisoner eightpence on the 15th of October for two pots of beer.
THOMAS THATCHER . I deal with Mr. Nelson. I paid the prisoner twopence on the 15th of October, for some beer which he brought me that day.

WILLIAM NELSON
re-examined. He absconded with 15s. 8d. He brought the tray of pots in, and went away—I paid him weekly—his week ended on Wednesday, and he went away on Sunday night.

Prisoner. He left me to find the customers—some I took the money from, some I did not—I had to pay for those that did not pay me—that night I got drinking with a young man who was going on board a ship, and drank rather too much—I went to go back on Monday, and met the same young man again—I had no wages while I was there.
WILLIAM NELSON . I paid him four shillings a week. I paid him on the Wednesday before.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2455.
MICHAEL FITZGERALD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

2456.
JAMES ARTHUR was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of October, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and 4 pence, the monies of
John Hiscock, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1837.
